reviewText:
**UPDATE** - This review was written with the game running on Hard"

This is the worst game I've played that bears Sid Meier's name.

"Surely it's not that bad" You say.

I'm afraid it is.

In the build up to the release of the game there was little doubt that it was going to be a less involved game to play then the typical Sid Meier fare
date: more Ace Patrol then Civilization 5. When developers were discussing the game
recommended:
that was pretty clear and I have no qualms with that.

In fact I was quite happy with the idea of a strategy game designed so I could play over an evening after work.

The 3 hour play time of this review was playing a game to completion on a "large" map.

Initial impressions are poor. The game launching in a tiny window and into a bare
hoursPlayed:
personality-less main menu that could have been ripped from any sci-fi title (it reminded me of the Sword of the Stars 2 menu). I sought out the settings menu and within that I found volume controls and "Windowed Full Screen mode".

I'm sorry what?

I know the game was being made for tablet as well
voteText: but this is Firaxis. I asked another friend playing it "Am I missing a settings menu somewhere?" bemusedly. "Nope" He replied "It really is that sparse"\n\nOh well. Not a great first impression
helpfulPercent: but not necessarily the end of the world. I setup a game.\n\nSetup lets you pick a faction and a leader. Each faction gets the same leaders
votesHelpful: with slightly rejigged artwork. Which comes across as a bit lazy. The factions have a unique bonus with the leaders adding an additional bonus of their own. I was a little bemused at what the various bonuses meant as I only knew about one aspect of the game (crew morale) from previews nothing else made a lot of sense and there was nothing to explain the benefits of a choice
votesTotal: no tooltips
votesFunny: nothing.\n\nThe lack of tooltips persists throughout
commentsCount: with a general lack of accessible information.\n\nI setup my game
column16:
stabbing blindly in the dark at things that sounded useful

The galactic playing field looks alright and I wait for the useful tutorial to kick in and explain things to me over my first few turns. I get nothing. I understand there's an info button to click but I don't understand why there's a lack of tutorial and I fumble around the first few turns getting to grips with the games systems.

As the game is all about moving a fleet around space bringing disparate planets into a federation you'd expect load out/designing of the ships to be one of the most involved aspects of the game. Instead
column17: you're presented with a list of things to click away at to upgrade or downgrade (removing components nets you some resources back to spend elsewhere) different aspects of each ship.\n\nMy fleet consisted of three ships throughout the course of the game
column18: starting as corvette's
column19: ending as battleships through upgrades and the games automatic ship classification. All 3 focused on speed
column20: one was paticularly tough and loaded with close range weaponry. One was less tough
column21: also had close range weaponry and could cloak. One had longer range weapons. The limitation to what you can actually do with ships meant all of them had max speed
column22: and were stupidly tough by about mid way through. But this simple setup felt game breaking. I could defeat any mission or enemy fleet
column23: outside of the missions where you have to defend an outpost that can only survive two hits with fast enemies that just head straight for it.\n\nThe empire building aspect of the game is no more involved. "Click this to make numbers go up
column24: because numbers" about sums up this aspect of the game. There's no interesting trade off between balancing metal
column25: food or energy. Get lots of whatever you can
column26: click stuff to have more stuff.\n\nI actually beat my game accidentally. I was working my way from planet to planet
column27: building one ludcriously over powered wonder after another because why not
column28:
then a conquered a planet which also had a wonder and triggered the wonder victory.

Well victory nets you a much more rewarding end then it does in Beyond Earth at least. You get 10 seconds of video which is better then a text box. But does it really matter when the rest of the game is so unengaging?

Overall
column29: it's an ok game to have on a tablet
column31: even where there isn't much competition. But on the PC there's tons. Weird Worlds in Infinite space did something similar but better years ago and it's Early Access sequel likely will to. There is no reason to buy this game for the PC

reviewText:
I decided to give this game a few hours of play, and a couple of days to judge if my opinions about it were sufficiently objective, and I've deliberately avoided reading other reviews so as not to colour my judgement.

At a very cursory glance, it's an ok, fun, civ: beyond earth themed mini game, that will provide a slightly different way to  sink a few hours in to a game for a little bit.

I tend to think of games in terms of wether they break even" for me or not - am I going to get sufficient gameplay out of a title that the cost per hour played is less than or equal to an arbitrary value.

For me
date: I tend to consider this value at a nice easy £1 per hour
recommended: pretty much the price of a cheap cup of coffee... if a game beats that
hoursPlayed: it's broken even or possibly even done a lot better. If it works out higher than that
voteText: the cost to own is too high and not worth the expense.\n\nOn those terms
helpfulPercent: this title doesn't even come close... as I doubt I'll play beyond the 3 hours or so I've put into it so far
votesHelpful:
leaving me at a cost to own of over £3 per hour...

I'll try to embellish more below.

Do you remember the free companion app for Mass Effect 3 that was released a few years ago? Called Mass Effect: Datapad
votesTotal: it allowed you to play a basic mini game on a tablet or mobile device that could influence events in the main game.\n\nSimply put
votesFunny: Starships is the "next gen" version of that.  There game is a little more complicated than Datapad
commentsCount: but in essence all there is to it is a vehicle for delivering unlockable content in Beyond Earth

column18: and add a few slightly different starting options for civ's in any new game you start after the unlock (eg a "sponsor" option when setting up your civ to start with ultrasonic fences
column19: instead of the vanilla options)  Unlike datapad though
column20: it doesn't add the Beyond Earth equivalent of ME's codex
column21: and does nothing else to really expand on the game or the overall experience.\n\nWhen you consider that

reviewText:
Starships is a game with a lot of potential, but falls short of what it could be. The game lacks a decent tutorial outside of standard tooltips, but the gameplay is fairly shallow without too much curve. Most of the non-combat gameplay is simply buying improvements/investments for better resources, which you can use to buy improvements and investments.

The battles themselves are largely a matter of flying in and out of cover, shooting targets from behind/the side and randomly crippling their abilities while they do the same to you. Torpedoes can be used to created delayed explosions, granting you a degree of control over enemy movement, and there's some shenanigans with cloaking and radar.

The maps are very similar, with the main features being shifting asteroids and portals that randomly teleport you to other portals. The former are very simple: red and green circles let you know that every turn, a path will be opened or closed. The latter is more of an annoyance than anything, due to the random aspect and the game's willingness to send your ship through one if you don't carefully plot your movement across individual hexes.

The game is connected to Beyond Earth, itself an iffy prospect at the time of writing. Completing tasks in BE will unlock bonuses in Starships, and vice versa. The BE unlocks are generally underwhelming, save for Pioneers. You can also choose to continue" a BE save in Starships
date: playing as your chosen leader and maintaining the same diplomatic relations with AI leaders
recommended: though this is pointless with Starships being a step down from BE.\n\nUltimately
hoursPlayed: Starships isn't a particularly deep or intriguing game. The visuals and music aren't bad
voteText: and the missions have decent variety
helpfulPercent: but everything else is lackluster and the options are barebones. There's no multiplayer
votesHelpful: no option to continue after winning
votesTotal: and no real depth.\n\nIt might be worth a look on Steam sale
votesFunny: particularly if you don't want to get a BE mod or mess with XML files to unlock the bonuses
commentsCount: but Starships can't break from the orbit of its iOS port origins."

reviewText:
What The Game Is NOTI suspect many of my fellow reviewers simply saw Sid's name on it, and expected a large and complex 4X game in space.  Which, if they had paid even half-attention to anything the developer said prior to release, they would have realised was never meant to be the case.

This game was never meant to be something like Endless Space, or Galactic Civilizations, or Master of Orion.  Firaxis was quite clear about that during the development process, in everything they said to their fans.

What The Game ISStarships is a light/casual strategy game, suitable to playing when you have a few spare moments - during a lunch break, for example.  It's less about grand strategy than it is abut tactical combat with a small fleet.  And within that framework, it is a very, very good little game.  Just, lighter fare than most of my fellow strategy-game enthusiasts will be used to.

Moral of the Story:Never buy a game just for the title, especially, just for whose name is on it.  Always take the time to at least learn what it's publisher claims the game is supposed to be.

To all of those people who bought this, expecting a dep and complicated 4X game requiring multiple hours, and hundreds of turns, just to complete a single playthrough, I say:  CAVEAT EMPTOR; the only person to blame for your poor experience, is yourself.

Next time, do your homework, and at least learn what the game itself actually claims to be, before setting yourself up for disappointment when it turns out not to match your unfounded expectations.

reviewText:
This is a hard game to recomend. Unless they make some improvmens to the game, I have to say do not buy this unless it is on sale.

You can think of Sid Meier's Sarships as a 4x Light turn-based strategy game.  The best thing I can compair it to is a Simplified iOS version of Endless Space. Even the 4 resources look and sound like Endless Space.  You have Food, Science, Metal, and Engery. Each turn your planets give you all the resources that they have produced based on their population and improvment you built.  There are only 5 improvment to build, one each for production of each resource and a Planetary defence one for the fifth.

You move your fleet of ships from planet to plant completing quest they give you to get influince with them until they become one of your planets.  You only have one fleet and it starts with two ships. Each turn you can use your enerigy to improve your ships or build a new one to join your fleet.  You never seem to loose a ship, if it is destroyed in battel, it will be back in your fleet at the end of the battle.

You can also link this game with Sid Meier’s Civilization: Beyond Earth using the My2K account. Playing this game will let you unlock some things in Beyond Earth.

There are parts of the game that I did enjoy.  The simplified version of the 4X game means the game move at a fast pace, focuing mainly on battles. My main problems with the game is that you can tell they put all their focus on the iOS version, and left out a lot of standard featurs you expect to have on a PC game, especially from a Firaxis and 2K game. These are not small Indie startups making their first Greenlight game.

Right now the main problems I have with the game:

-There are no resolution options and no Fullscreen. There is what they call Fullscreen Windowed
-You can set victory conditions, but the AI ignors them and can win any way it want. So victory conditions are just a way to handycap yourself.
-There is no way to rebind keys and there are no hot keys.  Right now they only keys that work are they arrow keys to move the map, and the ESC that lets you exit the game.
-No multi-player.  I can tell this game is going to get old realy fast. multi-player was something they were going to put in, but decided not to for some reason. I hope they change their mind on this.

Had I bought this on iOS, I would say it a great game and have a lot of fun with it, but as a pc game it feels off some how. Like we have a really good Beta, but you are just waiting for them to finish it now.

reviewText:
Short version:  This game should NOT be purchased at this time. Wait 2 or 3 months for 2K to either abandon support or actually finish testing this game.  This game is NOT in Early Access and should be a finished and tested product. However, most of the Early Access games I have played were far more stable.

Longer version:
I've never written a review on a Sid Meier game before and it's a shame that this has to be the first one. The bugs that are inherent in this game indicate that very little testing was done prior to launch. In an attempt to stem the tide of negative posts, one of the 2K devs sticky'd a thread to try to capture all technical issues. I don't think he's actually replying to anything there. This thread has been out since 3/12 (today is 3/16) and is up to 32 pages so far and growing.

I entered a support ticket on the 2K page after reading their FAQ/Known Issues thread.  I'm suffering from two of the frequent issues. The game doesn't play fullscreen for me -- the Windows taskbar always shows up. The FAQ said that if I hide my taskbar in Windows, this would resolve it. Really?  Why the heck would I do that? Shouldn't they just write the game to overlap it fullscreen?  You know, just like every other game developer already does?  The other issue is far more irritating though. The game crashes after the second set of logos... just about 4 or 5 words into the intro. 100% of the time despite an uninstall/reinstall. So I've not watched the intro yet. The only way to get past this is to spam the Escape key as soon as the second set of logos comes up. I don't get the intro but I can play the game... for a while.  Yes, dear friends, the crash-to-desktop bug persists into the game itself.  Randomly, the game just shuts itself down with no error messages. Not so bad if you save frequently but later into the game when you have control of a bunch of worlds and a decent-sized fleet, it gets to be a real PITA to save just to go from one world to the next then save and move to the next... But you have to do this if you want to store your progression because you never know when you'll be dumped right out.  When you enter a ticket on this at the 2K support site (which I heartily recommend as they need a swift boot to the tail for this), you'll notice that if you select crash" as an option
date:
they even already have drop-downs for "crash after second logos" and "crash during gameplay."   This game should have never ever ever launched in this state. These aren't minor bugs to be worked around -- they are show-stoppers.

Now on to the game itself... It feels more like a tablet game than a Windows game.  The price point is about right -- this isn't a deep simulation or world builder. You're not in-game to get invested and watch your planets grow (except for maybe your homeworld).  The combat is what the game is all about. It's relatively simple and straight-forward in the basic mode.  I haven't tried hard mode yet since I haven't been able to sustain the game long enough to complete a normal campaign. (see the paragraph about the perisistent crashing above)
"

reviewText: To me, this game is simply a stain on Sid Meier's name. reviewText:
And in the seventh day Firaxis and Sid got tired...

I want to love this game. Really. Spaceships and planets! Exploring with your fleet and investigate different civilizations! Sounds a cool concept, also the maps looks amazing. I did not expect a really complex 4x game, but rather something with fun rules, easy gameplay but challenging enough.

And possibly, hopefully Starships executes that... but there is no real way to find it as the game full with bugs (and no, not the bugs from Beyond the Earth). It crashes for many people with the current built, so honestly I can't advice to anyone to buy at it's current state. Wait a couple of days to see what will happen.

Civ: Beyond the Earth was somewhat a disappointment and I am sad to say but Starships seems to go to the same route. A could be great and fun game who never fullfils it's promise. Please prove me otherwise Sid.

reviewText:
Alright, so, I finished one playthrough and tried to start few new games with different settings, here is the impression so far:

Gameplay:
+Simple to understand resource management
+-Some super basic diplomacy that creates a light feeling of space empire game, although, you can break peace and attack your opponent the very same turn which kind of completely defeats the point of a diplomacy
+Few different ways to build up your ecocnomy\strength
+Fleet upgrades are very flexible and allows for some interesting ship specialites
+Fights are decently strategic
although:
-(huge minus, I ragequit the game few minutes ago because of that) Asteroid moving system(unless it is a bug). So, let me make an example: I hid my fleet behind a formation of really big asteroids, launched a few fighters, checked my LOS and every ship on the enemy team was untargetable. Clicked Next Turn. First thing I see is that an asteroid that was right in front of my fleet dissapeared and now 5 enemy ships are shooting me with 100% damage modifier. Now. If it is a system, there has to be some form of an indicator of which ones are moving(not necessary the location, but just an idea of which cover cannot be reliably used). If it was made for preventing people from defensive camping - good, but in this case you might remove all the asteroids as there is no way to predict your enemy's next turn(it is a strategy game , afterall). If it is a bug - GOD, this has to be fixed as soon as possible. I am EXTREMELY interested in the point of view of any developer\community manager on that topic.

UI:
+planetary management is simple enough and UI does it's job
-No HP/Weapons/Modules indicators (that I've seen) on enemy ships aside from the info on a pre-mission briefing. How can I tell if the ship is going down soon? How can I tell if that ship is stronger at close combat? Which ship should I target?
-Line of sight is really hard to manage, there is no visible indicator if the ship is in range of attack OR if the ship will be able to attack after the move (again, it is a strategy game not an aracde shooter). Defeats the idea of tactical movement, you just HOPE that your lasers will reach
-No Indicator of which weapon will be used at the certain distance, Would be great to see a tri-colour targetting arrow that shows which weapon will you fire at what range. I think it is a simple to implement and yet very important feature(again, we are trying to make tactical decisions in a STRATEGY game)
-Diplomacy screen is super-simple(also, very small for some reason) and a bit hard to understand from the first glance, and I am used to the complex screens of CIV and other 4x games
+Global view gives just enough information to the player, very functional and not cluttered.

Graphics:
+- Functional, nothing to praise, nothing to complain about
-No options. I want to skip\speed-up animation on a global view, same in the battle screen. Every CIV game has it...


Overall:
I REALLY want to like this game, I was excited from the moment I heard about it. I have done the pre-order and... I think it was a mistake. The game has potential, but it is buried behind tons of questionable decisions. In ideal world it is a fun, fast, strategy game, that can be finished within an hour. As it stands, I have very little desire to start a new playthough after I learned some of the flaws. I helped design\QA some UI for Network Software and I am genuinely surpised how most of the things I mentioned as a negative were missed
ot mentioned during the development process.

You might have a different experience than I did, maybe it is just a matter of personality.

Regards,

Dark Sun

reviewText: I hate to say it, but this game is simply too simple.  It is the strategorical equivalent of Monopoly.  Yes, it's light, it's simple, and the tactical battles can be a little fun.  But there is no real resource management or troop management or build management.  Everything you want to build, is built instantly on your turn.  New ships, ship upgrades, planetary upgrades, cities, even wonders.  If you have the resources, you could win by building a ton of cities or wonders in a handful of turns.  There are no tough decisions about building 5 small units or planetary upgrades instantly or building 1 large unit or wonder that will take a few turns to generate.  All of my turns devolved into - have energy, build/upgrade my fleet - DONE!  Have food?  Add cities.  Have science?  Research something - BOOM, added to all your ships or planets.  It is way way too simple.\n\nIf they ever add multiplayer, it might might give this some more potential.  As it is, skip it if you truly enjoy 4x games.  I feel I get more strategy from Clash of Clans than Starships...and for a Firaxis and Sid Meier title, that is a deplorable thing to consider.

reviewText:
A number of reviews have underscored that the game plays as a tablet/smartphone game.

And unfortunately, it's true. It does feel like you're playing a 3€ indie iOS game. Unfortunately, what I purchased was theoretically a 15€ PC game from a major PC game studio.

The game, per se, isn't too bad. But it is definitively not worth the current price. Wait until it's a 80% steam sale. Uninstalled here after 1 hour.

reviewText:
NO Civ or Usual PC-StrategyStarships is a Fast-paced, Turn-based, tactical and strategical game aimed at modern players, who prefer a short campaign with a strategical depth that they can grasp while playing it casual.
Something that a Fan of Sid Meier, Civ, Firaxis and PC-Strategy just isn't used to. And therein might be the reason for most negative reviews: every feature is reduced to its bare essentials to provide a dense and fast strategy experience. It doesn't want to fill your evenings! It want's your small chunks of spare-time, entertaining for 30 to 90mins at a time. Your trip to work, your break, or that 40mins that you can steal away while your kids watch their favored show.

Unusual Design Decisions(Things you should get accustomed to, to enjoy it)

Just one Fleet
Starships strategy core is to use your one fleet most efficient. Your effectiveness at the meta-gameplay is defined by accomplishing as much as possible with this one fleet each turn. No matter how big your empire, your turn has always the same amount of moves and actions. No uneventful early turns or tedious later turns.
Every turn counts!

Tactical Movement
The tactical combat is all about movement: range and angle for the shot but most of all cover, mixed with some divide&conquer. Unusual for a spaceship game, but it ensures that how you move is always more important than the strength of your fleet!

Simplified Progression
Starships has 4 paths of progression: The Fleet (invest energy), Research(invest science), more Planets(conquered), and Production(invest food and metal). where each part of progression isn't much more than a counter with increasing price for every point. But everything is well crafted into one big progression circle. The progression is simple and easy to comprehend, but exactly the right amount for a fast strategy game like this.
Closing WordsI love strategy games, no longer hardcore, but normal" ones like Civ. And yes
recommended: at least not for that part of me. It can't fuel a strategy addiction with dozens of hours
hoursPlayed: but Starships never wanted to! It tries to offer tactics&strategy to casual and short-time players; Or old ones

reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews, but in this case I needed to make an exception.

97 minutes.

Yep, that's how long it took to start up the game, futz around with it a bit looking for settings, reading the options for your new commander and then win.

I know - it's a bit slow, but in my defense, I did actually read the initial missions thinking there would be something deeper there.  There isn't.

Get enough energy to build your ships up to battleships, take enemy home planet (which gives you instantly everything they own) and rinse / repeat for however many players there are.  No need to build wonders, cities, or anything else meaningful (though I did waste at least half of that 97 minutes doing just that thinking it would matter.)

Makes you wonder as to the replay value, though I suppose if I'm truly bored I can try a variety of the missions just to try them out.

Sorry, Sid.  For as much entertainment your games have provided me over the years - this one just plain stinks.

reviewText: In the long line of Sid Meier sticking his name into game titles comes Sid Meier's Starships
date:
a hexigrid turn based galactic strategy in the vein of Civilization. The twist here is there are planets to join your galactic federation and turn based starship battles with your armada against an opponents.  Building your armada and competing in battles is by far the most fun of the game. I'd say it is the real game and everything else is just fluff. You can buy vessels, then upgrade engines, shields, armor, lasers, cannons, torpedoes, scanners, stealth and fighters.

The world is never enough and the universe is yours to conquer, purify or unify. There are several victory states such as domination, population, building wonders or scoring the top tier of a few science fields. While its nice to have all these ways to win, it feels like the game is geared toward conquering the galaxy. There's an entire space battle system in place and its silly to overlook it and play diplomatic. The only real way to ensure that I'll have a science or wonder victory is to make that the only type of victory allowed.

Battles take place on a hexigrid map, which in a way is illogical since space has a Z axis, but whatever. You can make use of heavy asteroids, planets and moons as cover. In a way its laughable that planets are as wide as four vessels. Smaller asteroids give less cover, but you're still prone to attack, but take less damage.

If a vessel is hiding behind cover, you can fire a limited amount of torpedoes that will breach cover. The only catch is you need to detonate the torpedo one turn later, so that gives your foes a chance to move. You get to see your torpedo fly and then push the button to make it explode. Its a great dynamic to have. Even when I'm out of range, I'm firing torpedoes just to do something. Torpedoes are limited to the number you have upgraded on that star ship.

Each ship gets a turn with a movement and an action in either order. During an action it depends what the vessel has upgraded. You can attack, impulse an extra move space, cloak hide, scan for cloaked vessels and release ships. If you chose to move, you can attack as you move you move between two cover points, but I never felt a need to get that complicated. Releasing ships adds a small cluster of fighters with long range movement, little health and no shields.

Vessels have shields, so if your weapon's attack power is less than the shield, its ineffective. Once shields are down, then you can do some big damage. The armor rating amounts to hit points. The more upgrades you have to a ship, the slower it moves, so you'll need to upgrade engines. Then there's stealth that conceals a ship unless an enemy is near it and upgraded scanners will compensate for finding stealth enemies. Its a good dichotomy.

Other notable features on a map include anomalies that when you fly into them, you appear out of a different one. Its good for speeding things along if there's one ship left, but your comrades are across the map. Even if you pop out in a random location, its still closer and a chance to flank enemies.

Battles have a victory condition, a map condition and a card. Most of the time you earn victory by annihilating the opposition. Other times its defend an outpost, escort a vessel to an outpost, guard warp gates, destroy a single vessel or get a ship of yours into a warp gate. The maps feel generated and the map conditions are things like enemy torpedoes are undetectable, more asteroids, less asteroids, shields are less effective. It adds some diversity to the battles. Then there are the cards which feel forgotten about. You get one or so cards during each battle and its a gamble when you use them. I wish I could say more, but in seven hours of playing, I never made use of them beyond a curiosity.

The idea of the game is that your entire armada flies from planet to planet. After these battles win or lose, you keep all your ships, but you need to repair them for the damage that they've taken. So a major loss requires you to repair everything. Well if your armada wrecks the armada of a competitor that leaves that same competitor open for more attacks on the same turn. Blood thirsty players like myself will keep pushing through, but to prevent the entire universal conquest on a single turn, your crew's efficiency goes down with each battle. Once its as low as it gets, you're forced to take a shore leave and end your turn.

Like a lot of these hexigrid games, you're competing and aligning with other competitors. You start the game by visiting planets, gaining their support which seems rather easy. Just win a battle and you're halfway there! Take a shore leave on a planet that you have 50% devotion with and you can gain an extra 25%. Some planets end up contested where four competitors can have a stake in it.

Once you've taken quarter of a planet you can spend food to plant cities; I'm sure that's how it works. Cities increase workers I guess. I was never too sure. The game just told me to build cities, so I did.

From there there are upgrades to a planet. Upgrades cost metal and give you more resources across various types that never felt of any consequence. Other planet upgrades include planetary defense craft, giving you a home field advantage with an extra vessel if an enemy ever attacks. Constructing a warp gate can bring your fleet to a planet under attack.

Spend science points on technology upgrades that will boost armada stats by 25% of a single category. Plenty of planets will reward you with a technology of your choosing. Even if you are about to enter a battle with someone, you can negotiate and they will give you technology or food to leave the planet. If you agree, that's some sort of a peace treaty right there. Other times if you have a 95% chance of winning, the game lets you have the planet without a fight.

It feels like I managed the bare minimum of micromanagement and got away with it. Rather than clicking on each planet to build this or that, I just clicked on one and upgraded until I was broke. There is an information icon to click on that will advise you what you should do, but it should just be on the screen without me having to click something. Perhaps a hide button would be better for players that want to play it their own way. Even with no guide and little to no tutorials I still managed to get through it.

When you start a new game, you select map size, up to six opponents, difficulty and victories. Enormous still felt small, but I suppose on normal took me four hours to conquer the galaxy while easy took only three. Easy mode is laughable. My first time playing, none of my vessels were ever damaged, let alone destroyed. Its a good way to get your feet wet, but about an hour in, there was no challenge. Normal felt like a good challenge, but there are still two difficulties.

You have a selection between twenty-four characters, eight within each of the three motivations for supremacy, harmony and purity. Each one has their own stat boost. One character has a 25% better this or that. Sometimes less cost, other times more of whatever. Some start with an extra vessel.

I feel less stress and more joy playing this game than I do with Civilization games. Those other games feel like there's always a cold war and you need to prepare before the invaders come, while I feel like here I have my destiny in my own hands. I'm smart enough to win battles even when the game tells me that I have a 25% chance of winning. Its also a small game. When other publisher and developer are 4 GB large, this one fits on a CD at 650 MB. Must be all that blank space rather than terrain.

reviewText: Pros: It's a cheap DLC package essentially.\nCons: The games are so short when playing against the computer, it almost makes no sense. It's mind-numbingly repetative tasks and very little in the way of actual gameplay. You basically have a small, static technology tree that you invest credits into. You have planets that you perform very basic tasks with and you essentially fly around the galaxy map as quickly as possible to friend or conquer as many planets as you can to win the game. The game seems very broken too. EPIC maps are fairly small and picking a victory condition seems to have no bearing on the ending at all. I've lost a number of games now where I picked domination as the victory and computer players have beaten me building wonders or having large populations despite not controlling most of the galaxy. Games rarely last 30 minutes or more. When you capture a number of planets, there is no central management screen, so you have to hop from planet to planet to build new cities or other improvements. It's really not what I expected. If you want a starship game, with control of resources, ship customization, civilization customizations and deep technology trees, then find Master of Orion III or Endless Space. This felt like a really cheap, unfinished knockoff of past, great titles and thankfully I only spent $14 on such a disappointment.

reviewText: A board game set in space with Sid Meier's name attached. As far as board games go it's decent, if repetitive. But as a game bearing the brand of Sid Meier... well, it's lackluster. It doesn't have the strategic depth of the Civilization series nor does it have those little details that draw you into the game world being portrayed, like Pirates did. Starships felt like something an indie studio would have done and I would have been pleased purchasing this game as a $4 iPad app. But with the expectations of a Sid Meier game, well, it left a bad taste in my mouth.

reviewText:
I don't even know where to start with this one. I bought this one being a space-game junkie and a Sid Meier fan. I don't know what I expected

Let's start with the menu options. Namely the settings. Is there a resolution setting? There is not. Is there a LOD setting? There is not. Is there Vsync, or literally ANYTHING ELSE FOR THAT MATTER to optimize graphics? There is not.

The only settings you can change is the volume. Unbelievable.

Let's talk about the gameplay. This is so very obviously a mobile title hastily ported over to PC/Mac. There is no avoiding it. The simplistic GUI/gameplay mechanics drive this point home. Most of the core civ mechanics are there, like... building improvements and wonders. And resources.

Another thing I found odd (probably a holdover from it being a mobile port) is that you(or AI) can only control one fleet at a time. Greeeaaaat. The combat is fun but not very solid. You upgrade your ships with energy that you get each game turn. However, as the game goes on, combat becomes exceedingly easier.

Capturing a capital causes you to annex the ENTIRE opposing empire. Not a percentage of it. ALL of it. Meaning that you can achieve victory VERY quickly. My first playthrough on hard only lasted two hours(!). My quickest Civ 5 playthrough EVER was 6.

Also of note is that my computer crashed twice while playing the game. Not the game, the actual computer had a kernel panic.

My final, most egregious sin that I found in this game is that it is a Sid Meier game without a One more turn..." option.

I canot recommend this game in any way. It is a pure cash grab."

reviewText:
A 1080p video review of Sid Meier's Starships:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jjpwfsr78ow

Sid Meier's Starships is a recently released light-4X turn-based strategy game. It takes a stab at integrating FTL-like space exploration, Heroes of Might & Magic-style combat, and minimal 4X strategy elements... but is extremely lightweight in all regards. This PC version is a mobile port that's seen less than the bare minimum amount of effort put into it: 30fps limit, no fullscreen, no graphics options (not even resolutions!), UI designed for touch devices & small screens, and dated graphics even by mobile gaming standards. The gameplay proved interesting for a few campaigns, but quickly fell apart.

See the video review above for more details - and some visual examples of what I'm talking about.


Recommendation
If you'd like to play a lightweight 4X space strategy on the go... then you might like the mobile version.
There's nothing here that should appeal to PC gamers with an interest in the genre on PC.
Despite its low price point there are many superior alternatives at even lower price points:
4X strategy in space: Galactic Civilizations 2, Sins of a Solar Empire, Sword of the Stars, etc.
Space exploration: Faster Than Light, Space Rangers, etc.

Technical Droning
120Hz - No
60 fps - No, it's limited to 30fps
Fullscreen - No
Borderless Window - Yes, but badly implemented
Graphics Options - None
Texture Quality - Low

reviewText:
It's essentially a mobile game ported to PC and an offshoot of Civilization:Beyond Earth. From the settings, over the game setup down to the entire gameplay concept the game feels very light in terms of substance. You control a fleet and send it around the map to take over planets via tactical combat. You develop planets and do research. There is diplomacy, a market system and different victory conditions.

You may now think: This is wonderful! Exactly what I am expecting from a turnbased strategy game! Unfortunately, since it's a mobile port, the game lacks in all mentioned aspects.

The AI in tactical combat is not very clever and can be easily outmaneuvered, leading to repetitive combat making it, due to the lack of auto-combat, appearing like a chore after a while since scenarios differ very little. This cannot be offset at any time by the fact that you can customize your ships even though even that feels a little bland as it's more or less pushing weapons and speed to the maximum of level of 8 for each ship. Your ships also do not get destroyed per se but only suffer from repairable damage and based on random chance may also level up.

Planet development is based on four resources (metal, food, research and cash). Each resource has a resort function, food allows you to spam cities which in return allow higher production of all resources, metal allows you to build a select few different buildings up to an amount of 8. Research allows you to tech certain aspects of your ship up to a level of 6 while cash is solely used to upgrade different modules of your ships whereas ship class is almost meaningless as each ship has exact the same amount and type of modules.

The diplomacy system is as deep as billboard and the market system at some point a pain to use due to static and low exchange rates.

Even though overall gameplay can be further tweaked through selection of affinities, victory types, difficulty level, map size and number of opponents I find its replayability degrading quickly. You are in fact better off playing a better space combat sim or just BE(RT).

Overall the game can be quickly summarized and in terms of essentially being a mobile game: its gameplay depth and replayability is far lower than say Fallout Shelter is and that one, despite also being a different genre, is free.

I don't expect much depth from a low-budget PC game but there are better choices for 14.99 €. I suggest not to buy it outside special sales events at a maximum of 7.49 €. If you are a hardcore TBS player I would skip it really unless you really feel the need to unlock those traits for BE(RT).

Firaxis can do better but this game is really not adding anything positive to the genre, at least not on PC.

reviewText:
This game is classic Sid Meier's - its not Civ - nothing like Civ.  To me, Sid did not disappoint with this title.   I probably should have played Beyond Earth first (bought them in a bundle), but for now, I'm having too much fun with this game.

Overall: Lovely little game.
Play time:  Few hours per game - sometimes it finishes before I'd like.
Complexity:  Pretty simple.  Learn the few basics and you are good to go.
Replayability:  Can see it get boring fast.
Graphics:  Nothing spectacular.  Quite immersive at a 4K resolution.
Multiplayer:  None.  I wish there was.
Glitches/Bugs: Next to none - the screen shakes too long when your ships are destroyed.  That's it.
Stability: Perfectly stable for me.  No hangups or crashes at all.

It should be called Sid Meier's Starships!  (with an exclamaation).  The simple game depth and design reminds me more of Pirates! and Railroads! ... all quick little games that are great fun.

reviewText:
I have followed (and enjoyed immensely) Sid Meier games from the very first one in the early 1980s and I must say that StarShips is my first major let down.

At a glance, this game looks like a hybrid between Civilization Lite and Ace Patrol. After playing a few games, Starships fails to live up to either one of those titles; it is an unbalanced mess with very little replayability. The only reason to replay it is to unlock perks in Civ : BE. (Scroll to the end of the the review for info on this feature).

An iPad app at best, Starships is devoid of personality, customization and meaningful choices for the player.

Ship upgrades could have been this title's saving grace but after a certain point, all your ships will have impenetrable shields, lethal lasers and cannons and enough fighter squadrons to avoid combat almost entirely. For a game which is supposedly centered on tactical gameplay, this seems like a pretty major flaw.

Sadly, after a few rounds, brute force seems to be the only way to win the game. Once you have built a few key wonders and expanded your empire beyond 3-4 systems, the game becomes one of patience as the player waits to see his galaxy coverage slowly reach 51%.

Pros :

- Great Art for mission summarys. Might not be your cup of tea but I really like it.

- A full game session from start to finish can take from an hour to an hour and a half.

- Playing Starships unlocks new perks/loadouts and maps in Civ : Beyond Earth.

Cons :

- No option to play fullscreen. The settings menu makes it painfully clear that this is a port of a tablet game. For a company like 2k/Firaxis, this is inexcusable.

- Most of the textual descriptions and story elements" are nothing but flavor text.

- Diplomacy only serves to artificially lenghten the game.

- No customization; you cannot rename starships
date:
planets or change the colors of your spaceships. Funny as this is one of the bullet points on the game's store page.

- The end game often occurs without player input. More than once I've won the game because the AI did something which triggered something else which gave me victory. No way of knowing what exactly happened.

- Sound guy annoyance : A capital ship explodes and the sound it emits is that of a single person screaming in agony. Rookie mistake.

To sum it up
hoursPlayed: untested
voteText:
unbalanced and unpolished. I have nothing against shorter games or games with more limited scopes (Ace Patrol was a great example of this) but this just feels rushed. There are many ways to better spend 15$.


A note on My2K
The connectivity between  StarShips and Beyond Earth is one of the redeeming (I use the term verrrrry loosely) values of this game. Achieving certain things in either game will unlock content in the other. The downside is that there doesn't seem to be a way to know what the requirements are for unlocking content
helpfulPercent: forcing you to play blindly and hope that you eventually unlock something.\n\nNote that if you are currently playing a game of Civ : BE
votesHelpful: a new option in the menu will allow you to <Continue Playing in Starships>. This saves the current factions
votesTotal: their affinities and alliances and allow you to start a new game of Starships with these parameters. Cool idea but it makes absolutely no sense in either game's narrative."

reviewText:
As others wisely said (sadly, after it was too late for me) Avoid this pitfall of a game. This has got to be by far the dumbest-downed Sid Meier's game in history. Let me just list some things this game lacks that are just inexcusable in this age of gaming, no matter the price:

1. Any form of Diplomacy or for that matter, interaction with other factions and AI players.
2. The tutorial is hilariously lacking, even as a Civ 5/BE player with well over 1000 hours I struggled to understand what all I had to do and how to control the game both in battle and out of battle.
3. Customization of your units by picking Harmony, Supremacy, or Purity at the beginning of the game ends there
4. Basic information in tool tips is non existent
5. Graphic Settings. Yes, that's right, there are absolutely no graphic settings. No resolution, no v-sync, heck you can't even change the brightness of the game. The only setting is full screen or not.
6. Auto-Saves. Yep, there is no autosaves in the game, and no options to turn it on
Loading from an In-Progress game. Made a mistake and want to reload? Sorry, exit to main menu and reload.
7. Balancing is non-existent. On hard mode, factions will declare war with you within 5 turns of the game starting and will have ships that do ten times the damage yours are capable of. They will also take all of the planets possible, leaving you no resources to upgrade after your first turn.
8. Settings in general are missing entirely. No key bindings, no controls explanation, no sound adjustments beyond volume level, no game customization beyond Race, Bonus, and opponents.

Honestly, Beyond Earth stripped away dozens of features and I thought that this game was thier answer, that this would plug the gaping holes in thier most recent 4x Game. Unfortunately, they stripped it down even further to it's barest of bones, literally leaving you with a game so very simple that you can play with one hand on your mouse as you beat your head with a hammer held by the other hand for buying this game.

Do not buy this game unless it's in the $2-$4 range, I'm not kidding, it's that terrible.

reviewText:
Review from Whiskey Reviews[wskosc.blogspot.co.uk]

Sid Meier's name has become a stamp of instant approval over the years, ever since Pirates! we've accepted it as a seal of quality on Civilization games. Beyond Earth was hugely disappointing, so can the follow-up mend Sid's damaged appeal or is it time to hit end turn? Follow the link to find out.

Lets be upfront; Starships is a huge disappointment. Like a good PC gamer the first thing you'll want to do is hit the options button and change resolution and bindings and the like; good luck getting any of that. The game is simply full screen or windowed, though you can resize the window it has the feel of playing a tablet game on your PC - and I've looked favourably upon many a tablet/phone port in the past but Starships stinks of lazy.
It's not a bad looking game, resembling Civ 5 on medium settings but tough ♥♥♥♥ if your PC can't handle it because there's no graphical quality options to tinker with.
While we're being upfront, there's no multiplayer either. If you're mainly a Civ multiplayer person then you'll probably want to skip right to the score and replace whatever number I pick with a big fat zero.

The most thrilling Starships ever gets.

That feeling doesn't subside with the actual gameplay either, you have one fleet of starships that you can upgrade and move around a randomly generated map. You can build more ships but they always go into this one fleet and no matter how much you upgrade them they're always one of a couple of classes and strategy is rather basic.
Like Civilization combat takes place on a hexagonal grid, this time littered with asteroid fields of varying density that you can hide behind and which will lower the power of or block your shots entirely. Unlike Civilization 5 weapons have gigantic ranges of half a dozen tiles or more and more than one unit can occupy the same tile, eliminating what few tactical advantages the hex grid system had.
There's no point building a flimsy cruiser loaded down with torpedoes because the enemy can just shoot its long range lasers past your friendly units and take it down, for example.
Your two main tactics come in the form of asteroids and stealth.
Asteroids as previously mentioned will lower a shots power or block it entirely. It's not always a perfect solution but you can hide weaker ships behind partial asteroid fields and launch fast but flimsy fighters or torpedoes from safety.
Stealth meanwhile is a game breaking ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t button. Hitting the stealth button puts a ring around your ship, enemy ships have to get into this ring to detect your ship and fire upon it. It doesn't take many upgrades to bring this down to a one-hex or even half-hex size, making your ships almost entirely undetectable since the AI seems to forget sensors exist.
Coupled with long range lasers, or even powerful short-range plasma weapons and you have a recipe for domination no matter what the odds. Throw in a wonder that allows you to enter stealth at no cost, activating it for free when you move which allows you to remain invisible and fire at the same time and you've got an instant win that'll allow as little as two or three moderately equipped ships to rampage across the galaxy freeing planets from your enemies influence often with no opposition as the AI attempts to preserve resources by not facing you for fear of being dominated.

Remember that options screen from earlier?

Some flavour is added to the combat via each encounter's random modifier, for example you might not be allowed to move directly right (referred to as east" in game) or asteroid fields might disappear as the battle goes on
date: or shields might not work as well. They're minor
recommended: sometimes annoying and calling them flavour might have been a bit too generous because after four or five matches you'll stop reading them and just hit next.\nSecond on the flavour menu is battle cards
hoursPlayed: again random effects that buff your fleet for varying effects; perhaps adding an extra shield level or allowing you to move two spaces further or even repairing your ships or damaging the enemies. They're useful in the right situation but I've gone whole campaigns without even using one
voteText:
mainly because my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t stealth fleet was untouchable.


Ooh! Choices! Those are the default selections by the way.

The metagame is likewise light on stategy and content; you have crew morale/fatigue and that limits how many times you can move your fleet each turn. The idea being to jump between planets and secure influence to bring them into your empire in order to gain their resources and benefits.
You do this by taking part in randomly selected missions for rewards. Having them randomly selected is nice but the serious lack of them
helpfulPercent: I think there's only about 7 or 8 in total
votesHelpful: makes for a lot of repetition even in a medium sized galaxy let alone over multiple games. The missions generally come in three flavours; blow something up
votesTotal: run away
votesFunny: or play king of the hill with an AI too stupid to capture more than one of the points.\nOne mission type I particularly hate
commentsCount: to the point that I let AIs actually take that planet and start a war to get it back later is the maze type. You either get limited sensor range or a limited number of turns and have to navigate a dense asteroid field set up like a maze

column17:
or Shining Force.

Gameplay: Still not that good.

Resources come in four flavours and have a single use each:

Energy allows you to upgrade your ships or add new ones to the fleet.
Metals allow you to buy planetary upgrades and build wonders.
Food allows you to build cities

a ding in the paintwork.

reviewText:
TLDR: A neat little game with some cool ideas, but mobile-game production values and a lack of long-term depth don't justify the $15 asking price. Worth picking up on sale or if you're desperate for some bite-sized light strategy, though.

Store page description aside, Sid Meier's Starships is a turn-based strategy game wherein you try to conquer the galaxy. There are multiple ways to do this, but they all essentially boil down to building an unstoppable battle fleet and destroying your enemies.

The game is divided into two layers. On the greater strategic layer, you see the galaxy itself, taking your fleet from planet to planet and performing missions to convince the inhabitants to join your empire. The tactical layer puts you on a hex-based battlescape and maneuvering your individual ships to do whatever needs to be done (and almost always involves the destruction of enemy ships). Complete a mission to gain influence with the planet's population. Gather enough influence and the planet will join your empire wholesale. Of course, your rivals will be doing the same thing in their section of space.

The first half of Starships is basically a race for territory and resources, like in any classic 4X. Players will try to expand their empires, pulling in neutral planets and building infrastructure to fuel further conquest. Eventually, borders will start pressing up against each other, the galaxy will run out of neutral planets, and from there, it's a matter of the major players fighting it out to settle who will become space overlord of humanity. This is where things start to fall apart, as massive power swings can come out of nowhere and end a game without warning.

There are four victory conditions. Capturing all other players' homeworlds obviously wins you the game, as does maxing out three fields of technology, controlling seven wonders, or governing over half of the galaxy's total population. The big swings come out of the way homeworld battles work. When a player captures another player's homeworld, the losing player's empire is immediately turned over to the conqueror in its entirety. A player with 15% of the galaxy's population can shoot up to 40% or more in a single battle, or zoom past the seven-wonder victory threshold before anyone knows what's going on.

The actual starship combat is simple and easy to learn. Lasers have long effective ranges, while plasma cannons boast superior firepower once you can bring them to bear. Firing one means not being able to fire the other that turn. Torpedoes have a delay before they can be detonated, but are effective at area denial. Cloaking technology can make ships untargetable if there's no sensor-equipped enemy nearby to reveal them. Strike craft are weak, but they're fast and they can be replaced and repaired for free. Attacking a ship from the sides or rear generally provides hefty increases in damage done, and doing more damage increases the chance of scoring a critical hit and damaging the effectiveness of a ship's systems. Controlling various wonders, as usual, allows a player to break some of these rules.

The economy side of the game exists purely to support the combat side of the game. You will not be building fantastic monuments and converting heathens to your banner using the power of your culture. You will not unlock the mysteries of the universe that bring your people to a new stage of enlightenment. You will research bigger guns, heavier armor, and more efficient engines for the ships. You will build ships, or you will build factories that build ships, or you will build factories that build factories that build ships. All roads lead to ship. The ship is love, the ship is life.

Speaking of the ships, customization here is kind of weak. Rather than picking and choosing modules that change the way the ships function, you simply pick a category, choose a rating from 0-8, spend the requisite amount of ship-specific currency, and move on to the next. There's a certain amount of technique involved in weighing tradeoffs between speed and armor, or pure firepower versus stealth capabilities, or fighters versus torpedoes, but if you're looking for omnidirectional shields, stealth torpedoes, point defense cannons or any kind of customization that's any more complex than making one number larger than the others, you'll have to hope that there's a wonder that'll serve your purposes.

Sid Meier's Starships was released simultaneously on PC and iOS, and it really shows. The UI is clearly designed for a mobile crowd, and it values clean visuals and uncluttered space above all else (including, at times, functionality). The ingame options menu is a joke, consisting of volume sliders and the options to turn tutorials and fullscreen mode on or off. There are no resolution or detail settings, which might be for the best because there's not a whole lot of detail to be had in the first place.

Installing modules on a ship changes the model itself, but those changes don't exactly carry into the battles themselves. A battleship bristling with weaponry won't show off all of its guns firing with separate particle and lighting effects, just a slightly-larger salvo of lasers inexplicably curving in space as they approach their target. The backdrops and leader portraits have a painted look that washes them clean of finer details. All leader audio has been lifted from Civilization: Beyond Earth, and the only other voicework ingame consists of short combat barks along the lines of critical damage" or "nice shot." Completing the game
hoursPlayed: or faction
voteText: yields the same unskippable victory cutscene (yes
helpfulPercent: a PC-centric developer released a game with unskippable cutscenes). If another player wins

reviewText:
If you're looking for an epic 4x space strategy game like Endless Space, Galactic Civilizations 1-3, or something else, this is not that game. If you are looking for a game with spreadsheets and lists, this is not that game. If you're looking for a game where you command hundreds of ships divided into multiple fleets, this is not that game. If however you're looking for a lite 4x space strategy game that includes tactical combat and can be played start to finish in a few hours, then this might be worth consideration.

The unique element of this game is how it's focused around your single fleet of ships. In the beginning of the game, the fleet is not very strong. However given enough resources it can grow in size (up to 8 ships) and strength to become a formidable force in the galaxy. You'll be faced with the decision of choosing between engines, shields, armor, and different weapons. Do you continue to upgrade your existing ships or buy more ships to add to the fleet? Do you choose speed over armor? Do you build out your ships for specific roles? What tech do you research to compliment your upgrade strategy? Then there are wonders which further enhance your fleet and can provide huge advantages. You'll also find battle cards which provide bonuses during missions.

Another fun element of the game are the missions. When you visit other planets you'll be faced with missions that range from escorting transport ships while protecting them from pirates, escaping with sympathizers aboard your flagship, defeating waves of attacking ships, and so on. Successfully completing missions will provide influence or other rewards.

As for the complaints about this being a tablet or mobile game, it is true that the options screen is missing some common options available on PC games, the game isn't a true full screen in that the taskbar isn't hidden, and the screen doesn't scroll automagically when the mouse hits the edge. However none of these things have prevented me from playing the game. The map can be moved with either the arrow keys or the left mouse button. The taskbar can be set to auto-hide if it's that distracting (or just deal with it). In regards to price, I do think that PC gamers unfortunately do end up paying a premium over the mobile platforms. This isn't the first game and it won't be the last.

Finally, in regards to expectations, I think people saw Sid Meier's name along with this being set in space and left their expectations unchecked. First, the low price point should have been a major indicator that this wasn't going to be anywhere near the scale of a Civilization game. Second, a Sid Meier games doesn't automatically infer an epic game. The past few years 2K/Firaxis have had smaller Sid Meier titles such as Ace Patrol, Ace Patrol: Pacific Skies, and Civilization Revolutions which were on the mobile platform.

reviewText: I've been playing Sid Meier's games for a long long time. They ARE basically what I look for in a PC game and have brought me years of enjoyment. Now we have Sid Meier's Starships, which I'd been waiting for excitedly after the surprisingly great jump to space in Beyond Earth. Unfortunately this game is absolutely horrible. The game lacks that compelling desire its predecessors have to play and defeat it in all ways possible, or even explore the game or the world(s) within, because the interface is awful and the story" throws you into space to do unexplained busy work. reviewText:
*sigh*  I've played several games at this point and feel that I have a really good handle on the AI in the game.  I *do* find the game enjoyable as a general time-waster, but the game is basically unfinished.  I really, really, really wanted to be able to recommend this game....  I honestly did, but as it stands right now the game is far too buggy, its rules too simplistic, its tactical combat far too imbalanced, and that results in an experience that is frustrating and extremely shallow.

I've been playing on easy and, as expected, the AI hasn't really surprised me.  In 10 hours I haven't lost a single battle.  However, I've also lost every single game.  How can this be possible?!?  Well, it's because the victory condition system is horribly broken for the type of game this is (similar to how it's horribly broken in Beyond Earth, only worse).

In every single case, I've been defeated by a Wonder victory.

Disable Wonder victories and just allow a Domination victory then!  Problem solved!"

reviewText:
No, no, no. Sid. You're better than this mate.

Don't have an immense amount of time to write a review. But I will say this. When Civ V came out, many people (myself included) saw it as a dumbed down and lesser version of Civ IV. Then they largely fixed this by the time of the last DLC. When Beyond Earth came out it was and is a dumbed down reskin of Civ V with no relation to Alpha Centauri like we were all hoping. Only time will tell if they fix that.

This...I can't even draw a comparison to previous games. Its an insult to Beyond Earth that it is in any way tied to that game just as much as Beyond Earth was an insult to Alpha and Civ V.

Terrible, terrible game. Glad I got it at a reduced rate but I still feel like I have been ripped off at £8. Please do avoid this. If Sid continues to add his name to anything he can 'cash-in' on then we're going to be left with a poor legacy indeed.

reviewText:
I will not write an extensive review of this game for a few reasons, one being that the problems with this game are already being vocally expressed, and secondly because I believe the game in it's current state is very incomplete and has the potential for change over the coming months if the developers are open to feedback and implementing it.

I will probably just focus on the one thing that bothers me most about this game and that is Immersion.

Civilization 5 is already universally accepted as being a great success in the Civ franchise, while lacking in some of the hardcore elements of the previous titles, it still makes for an enjoyable and immersive experience from start to finish, with engaging mechanics and DLC.

Civ:BE - A game I wanted so much to fall in love with, being a huge fan of SMAC, lacked in new and engaging mechanics, and felt slightly hollow, despite it's somewhat empty nature I still found my experience with Beyond Earth to be fairly immersive, and this immersion is what drives me to commit a few hours to enjoying the games content.

Now onto SM: Starships, unfortunately the immersion for this game ends not long after you've chosen your leader and faction, and gained your first territory, after that you begin to realise the game offers very little after that in terms of a feeling of progression, success or any kind of immersion in the world.

I like the mechanics of how the missions are fought, I like turn based strategy games played on grids so I enjoyed these aspects somewhat, but found they were not very challenging or interesting enough to remain immersed in the action and cause of the game.

The AI at this points seems fairly dead, they will make their presence known and then afterwards there isn't much diplomatic use for them. You will find at some point you're either going to have to betray your allies or make peace agreements with them which completely block you from travelling into or through their territory to reach new unclaimed planets, this can lead to you getting completely isolated and unable to progress.

The game needs a lot of work, it has the workings of a great game, but it feels as if it hasn't been worked on enough yet, the UI needs to be more engaging and helpful, think back to Civ 4 and 5, while Civ 5 did not offer as much as Civ 4 did in terms of the advanced customization of how you can play the game, both titles gave you enough to build yourself an engaging and immersive experience. It seems the developers have been limiting that customizable freedom which has been such a defining feature of the Sid Meiers Franchise, starting with Civ: Beyond Earth and now with Starships, I hope the devs are able to look back to the past and remember what made their games so successful and work on keeping their reputation alive.

One of the main criticisms of this game right now is that it feels more like a mobile app which is what it has also been released for, and right now it seems as if it has been limited more for the mobile app platform, rather than developed as a fully functioning game that can stand the test of time on both platforms. While smart to break into the booming market of mobile applications and mobile gaming, I feel they should of perhaps decided on either releasing a standalone mobile app, a desktop exclusive release, or simply put more effort into developing the game mechanics and elements further.

At the moment I cannot recommend it, for the very simple reasons that I don't believe you will get much enjoyment out of it for too long in it's current state, and is certainly not worth it's current price in what it offers.

I look forward to following where this game goes next, and what the supposed cross-game functionality with Beyond Earth will offer (it seems to me that whatever that feature is has not yet been released), but for now I'll be letting this one sit in my library.

reviewText:
Overall, this is a good mobile game, 6/10 for PC. Unfortunately, it is not worth $15.00. I would pay maybe $5 for this.

I'm just including the negatives, I had a good time play/learning but I don't think I'll be investing too much more time into this as it doesn't have the Yes I've won" satisfaction of other strategy games I've played even though it has a really fun combat concept (execution was a bit off but you'll read why below). The "grand strategy" portion was very mobile-y which is okay since it never claimed to be anything more but a man can dream...

What I didn't like:

The game features only 8 leaders. The affinities from Beyond Earth are there but I didn't really notice a worthwhile impact of including them when it comes to gameplay.

No tutorial
date: just "this how things do" page before the start of a game.\n\nCustomizability of the ships is awesome but not reflected in gameplay (lack of clarity of weapons/shields
recommended: vision not really helpful).\n\nThe wonders offer diverse spread of gameplay modifiers
hoursPlayed: however some are way more powerful than others and the planets determine what wonder is available so there is a luck factor involved (not bad
voteText:
but annoying).

Price scaling on techs/wonders didn't seem logical at all to me.

In terms of combat gameplay
helpfulPercent: there are a few graphical glitches that were distracting but not hindering.\n\nNo obvious tell of what weapon I would use in what situation
votesHelpful:
so I kinda just upgraded both (lasers and plasma cannons).

Scanners and stealth didn't seem that relevant in combat unless the always active stealth wonder was owned.

The lack of pre-battle deployment was the biggest negative of the combat. Sometimes my "carrier" type ship would be spawned on the frontlines with my "corvette" type ships in the back. Or the wonderful spawning of my destroyer with asteroids on 5 sides."

reviewText: Unless they vastly expand the content (for free), stay away from this one unless it's on sale for $5 or less.  It's got the depth of a tablet game, and a casual one at that, not a modern PC game.  You also can't change certain starting parameters like Victory Conditions for the AI, only yourself, so even the huge" maps (which are actually very small) will only last a couple hours even if you're trying to draw out the game through a domination victory.\n\nThe initial gameplay is actually quite fun
recommended: but you'll achieve everything possible within a couple hours at most and as soon as you realize that there's nothing new to discover about the game that initial excitement quickly fades.\n\nI squeezed 6.3 hours out of it and I'm not sure I'd play it again unless something changes.  Even for $15

reviewText:
I started on an epic galaxy with six computer players.  One of them spawned on either side of me, and both of them took influence away from me on the first planet I visited and gained influence.  Then I took a mission where you had to escort a colony ship to a jump gate, and every move took 2 HP away from every ship.  There was no way to heal, and there were too many spaces between the ship and the gate for it to survive.

I cannot believe how dumb this game is.  I was expecting a 4x game, like a Civilization in space.  Instead, I got an epic failure of a game.  I was very excited to play it, and now I'm completely turned off.  This all happened in about 10 minutes of gameplay.  I don't even want to give it another chance, because it's not even the right type of game.  It looks like a 4x, but wow does it fail.

Also I want to add that the user interface blows.  I expected to be able to interact with and rotate planets when I was zoomed into them, but no.  However, you can slide the top of one of the lists up and down in a klunky, unnecessary and superfluous way.

Sid Meier made one of the most brilliant games ever in Civilization.  He's cloned that model so many times now, that it seems he has forgotten what a fun game is.  He got money from me this time purely because of his name, but he won't again.  I'm bitterly disappointed.

reviewText: Sid Meier's Starships is a terrible port of a mobile game. To start off, the game's options are lackluster - there are basically none! When you select to fullscreen the game, it's fullscreen windowed and the taskbar is still shown. Also, there is no Quit Game button so you must hit escape of Alt+F4. The gameplay is very one dimensional, you have 1 fleet that goes around to different planets to accquire them by completing a mission. The missions are tedious as your ships have to slowly move around to destroy the enemies. There's almost no strategy involved and with no auto-complete option it's a chore. At the macro level, all you do is level up your planets and fleet - that's essentially the game in a nut shell so it's a very slimmed down version of any Civilization game.

reviewText:
From what I've seen of Sid Meiers Starships, I have to wonder why it wasn't just a DLC for Civ Beyond Earth. It's pretty basic.   In fact it feels like it was designed for the Commodore Amiga  30 years ago... If I had played this game 30 years ago I probably would have thought it was brilliant.

It's missing many of the things that we take for granted in PC games, like fully adjustable graphics options and the ability to run in full screen.  The mouse controls are clumsy and you can't scroll by moving to the edge of the screen like in other Sid Meier games.

At least if it had been a DLC it would have been able to use the in-game display settings of the base game.

Sadly I cannot recommend this game. It's the first Sid Meier game that I'v ever been disappointed with...

----

A quick addition for people who think this game could never have been done as DLC:

It wouldn't have been hard to get this to work as a DLC.

The game may look different, but it uses the same basic engine (albeit greatly slimmed down). All they've really done is replace the flat terrain maps of Civ with a star field and planets and replaced the normal ground and water based units with space ships. It's basically CIv trying to give the impression of space when it's actually just a 2D hex based RTS like all the other games in the series. Basically the ships aren't flying through space, they're moving along an invisible ground plane, or the equivalent of, with a star background replacing the terrain we normally see. With all that in mind, it wouldn't have been all that difficult to add the maps, units and other features to the main game. There's nothing in Starships that couldn't have been accomplished in the base game.

It could have been an add-on for the base game, and added new gameplay features, in the same way that The Sims add-ons often add in new features that weren't built into the base game, but expand upon the original game mechnics.

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong, its a great game and consept, but the way its presented, is poor and can be at times, easy! I believe the consept is great, its good to have a civ game where the focus are on planets and rulling the galaxy! But. its just to bare, and I believe it could be more like a pure civ game, wheres it more about tactics and, dare I say it, more complicated!

The vast majority of this game is all about war, (Which, in my oppion is the best part in civ! :P ) but there is no way to forge allys and cordinate your attacks. Negoations and Diplomacy is the strongest bit in civ games, which can decide the game and be the difference between Victory, or Death off you civilizations! (Which is normally the latter with Domanation!) But the one MAJOR flaw, is that it has NO multiplayer! Which many games strive on, which has proven to be a major asset for this series!

Still, for the price, it is good for people who want a quick game which has great pick up and play value! For those who like  simpler games, its great! In my oppion, it would benfit greatly on mobile, as it has the great potienal for it! In conclusion, its great for people wanting to get into turn-base and resource management, but its just to simple! I would advice you to save up for another civ game, Civ 5 if you can!

reviewText:
Overview:

A decent turn-based strategy game that doesn't require days to play through. However, after about 4 hours, the fun is starting to wear off for me. There's more cons than pros for this game. I'm really on the fence about recommending this or simply saying skip it. On the one hand, it's fun for a few hours, on the other it gets repetative and isnt very immersive. I'll only recommend it if you want a change of pace and have the $15 to blow.

Pros:

Strategy-based gameplay is fun at first. You have to plan your moves around asteroids, debris fields, etc. You have to pay attention to which way your ship is facing, manage your weapons systems and keep track of enemy movements. Once you get past the initial learning curve (there's really no tutorial aside from some advice" boxes) it's easy to play through. Upgrading your fleet and managing your systems is easy (perhaps too easy).

Early on the game is challenging. Go into the wrong system and you might run into a fleet of carriers while you only have three cruisers. However
date:
there is no shortage of "easier" battles to build up your fleet.

Cons:

It's repetative. After you expand your fleet and upgrade your ships
recommended: every battle becomes repetative and very one-sided (in the player's favor). I was pretty much destroying every fleet I encountered with little resistance (this was on the medium difficulty setting). I have a feeling regardless of the difficulty
