reviewText:
I think this best way to sum up this game would be to simply called it pocket/mini sized strategy."

Starships comes at a weird time Firaxis and 2K games.  Beyond Earth left many consumers wanting more and genuinely confused.  Why did they charge for a full price game that amounted to nothing more than an expansion pack for Civ 5?   SO what do they do?  They make a game even smaller in scale than BE and charge much less for it.  I assume the strategy now is: "the price should match the experience" and what you get with Starships pretty much feels like a $15 game.

I'll get this out of the way immediately: this is a mobile game that happens to playable on the PC.  What does that mean?  Well
date: it means that a lot of the complexity of the Civ series is stripped out and the player is left to make spot decisions and map movement choices.  The interface was clearly designed for tablet touchscreen.  The buttons are in weird places and the menus/screens are stripped to the bar bones essentials.  That said
recommended:
there is an enjoyable strategy game to be played here.  Let's take a moment to talk about it...

The gameplay:
Players familiar with Civ 5 will immediately recognize the hex grid format.  The player starts on the grid with a small fleet of starships and a planet.  Each "turn" basically boils down to this pattern:
- Spend Resources on starships
hoursPlayed: planets and various upgrades\n- Move your war fleet to a new planet\n- Complete the mission on that planet (aka combat
voteText: more on this in a moment)
helpfulPercent:
thus gaining influence over that planet
- MAYBE move again and do a new mission on a different planet
- End Turn (aka Shore Leave)

Let me touch on the combat scenarios (missions) on each planet:
When the players arrives on a new planet that isn't already in their empire
votesHelpful: the citizens of the planet will request help in the form of some type of starship mission.  This is where the real strategy of the game comes into play and the theme of "starships" really plays out.  Whatever war fleet the player has assembled is now used in a turn based mini strategy game.  It is important to note that SOMETIMES the mission doesn't use the player's war fleet but instead presents some type of puzzle.  But most (>70%) of the time the player must use his/her forces to defeat a squadron of NPC starships.\n\nThe battle scenarios are most similar to "war" in Civ 5.  Each mission is played on its own hex map (separate from the overworld map) where the player manuevers their starships and fires various weapons to destroy the enemy NPCs.    Each starship is its own character on the map so if the player has five starships in their fleet
votesTotal: they now can battle with five ships on the combat map. This is defintely the BEST part of the game.  This is where all the time spent buying new ships and upgrading them pays off.  The player can choose to stay back and use long range weapons to try and get up close and personal with fighters or close range weapons.  If the player is successful
votesFunny: they "win" influence over the planet and eventually it folds into their empire.\n\nThe players wins the entire game when they control most of the overworld map (or lose if they fail to do so).  I *think* its 70%. (Update: There are several victory conditions present but in my play time
commentsCount: so far
column16: I have usually won by accidentally acquiriing 70% of the map.)  When playing on easy mode it is very easy.  Medium and Hard present much better challenges.\n\nThe truth is that the game isn't very deep.  Upgrading planets and ships usually involves just buying everything.  There aren't really any penalties or drawbacks.  Even if the player concentrates on
column17: for example
column18: energy production
column19: eventually it all evens out.  And that's where Starships is arguably very weak.  This is not a deep game.  The best part of the game is the combat and the starships.  Everything else is nothing much more than a big map the player simply uses to move and drive the game.\n\nI found the $15 is worth it.  The strategy of the starship combat is fun albeit not engaging.  The game does retain the "one more turn" type gameplay but that's where it ends.  The overall
column20:
4x strategy simply isn't present.

Bottom line?

This is a $15 strategy game and I recommend it based on the starship combat.  If you want a bigger strategy
column21: with more depth
column22: look somewhere else.\n\nFinal Score: C"

reviewText:
*sigh*

I wanted to like this game dispite what the masses were saying on how it was not what was expected.

Mr. Meier, I really wanted to like your game. You and I have been doing business for many a year now, but Starships made me sad.

Maybe it was the lack of options when choosing a leader (It seemed pretty redundent). Perhaps it was that I was able to win in less then 30 minutes and then instead of being to just roam and explore (as your other games allow) I am forced to start all over again.

To the Development Staff, The game is awesome looking. You did make sure that the game is smooth and very eye catching. Thank you for that. But maybe if you don't feel the need, you could maybe let this game open up so we can have the people step in and add to the game, open it up for more possiblilties. Like I stated before, I would personally like to see more of a playability then 30 minutes. Set my enemies further apart. Allow allies and alliances maybe? Trading? etc...

Hard mode, 4 players on an Epic sized map... All 4 were bunched around my planet.. for an epic map?

Please Mr. Meier Keep your money, I feel I got what I deserved for not listening to others. But do me a favor? Put that money to good use making an even better Civ VI!

Thank you

reviewText: I bought this game based on the Sid Meier's branding. I guess my expectations were too high for a $15 game. reviewText: When I first heard about this game, I was pretty excited. I really liked Civ V and the idea of a less complex, faster to play strategy game made me very curious. Eventually I got the game and have spent 14 hours with it. They really did strip down a lot of complex features. In theory, removing unnecessary stuff is a good thing to make the experience smoother and in this case less time-consuming. But for me, they also stripped down the fun part of the game. You have one fleet of ships that you can progressively upgrade. The upgrades don't really allow for specialization. The upgrade system of the planets is even less interesting. The initial thought of the game is still very enticing but the realization doesn't appeal to me at all...

reviewText: I waited over a month for this game after hearing that it would be released.  I was eager for it. As a fan of BSG and Mass Effect, I felt the idea of a nomadic fleet finding purchase on cooperative starsystems would be a unique experience.  After just an half-hour playing the game I can say it is a feeble attempt.  I expected more from Sid Meier.  This game is a shallow, flimsy attempt to expand on the Beyond Earth franchise.  The resource management is rudimentary. The story is nonexistent. The language is belittling (I feel it's condescending and dumbed down). There is ultimately no difference between choosing any of the affinities as the leaders all give the same rewards no matter which affinity one selects. This is a sad, sad iOS port to PC.  It's a vapid shell.   The starbattles are tactically childish.  I might have some challenge with the game if I were 10 years old and suffering from some kind of brain trauma.  Starships is a poor title as a few minutes of playing the game is sufficient to eliminate any exclamation the player might have expected.  Meier must have lent his name and his name only to this hunk of junk, but frankly, a man that I have idolized for years as a trend-setter and revolutionary designer has seriously let me down.  I would never have attached my name to such a trivial, casual game, not that casual games themselves are bad.  Just this one.

reviewText:
10/10  Yes, that's right ney-sayers, I repeat 10/10.

[Notice that I have a fair number of games, but I don't write a lot of reviews and almost all of those are negative.]

I noticed a consistency when I read the other reviews for this game.  The players who tried it more than 10 hours recommend it, the others don't.  And why not, because it isn't Civ V, plain and simple and they went into it ready to not like it and bash it.

I don't understand what people don't like about this game.  It is not Civ V, so what?  Who cares?  It is a totally different game, and exactly what the devs said it would be (not Civ V, so get over your selves, you whiny bytches).  And guess what?  It is brilliant.  Let me repeat that, it is brilliant!  It is easy to get into, quick to understand, quick to play, and down right fun.  It brings back memories of the first Masters of Orion (MOO).  Really.  Seriously.  Try it, you will like it.

It is a very simple 4x game, but it is not Civ V, which is a much more complex, detailed-oriented, resource managing, city and army building, click-fest, that in my opinion was fun for one play through, but then... who has time?  So it beats me why they want to compare the two and then be bummed out it isn't the same?

This is a simple, straightforward, fun game with nice UI controls, nice graphics, no bugs, etc.  You have a fleet, you move it to planets, you fight various types of battles, you win the hearts and minds of the local planetarians, they join your Federation, and you move on to the next system rinse and repeat until all of the free systems are taken.  Then you duke it out with the other expanding empires.

Once you conquer a planet, you build cities and upgrades on your planet (each system only has one planet, so again, it is very easy and fast to manage your planets).  You build wonders.  You invest in research (a very simple science tree of maybe 10-12 categories which increase your ship powers.  You can buy and sell a few commodities like science, metal, fuel, and food, all of which are needed though to build cities, ships, upgrades, etc.

Building ships is the fantastic part.  It is dead simple.  You use metal to add points to your defenses (hull and shields), engine, weapons, hangers, tubes, sensors and stealth, and that is about it.  You can upgrade your ships to super dreadnaughts, or create lots of smaller ships to swarm the enemy.  You can add fighter bays and launch fighters.  You can add long range lazer weapons or short range kenetic weapons that do a lot of damage up close.  You can also add torpedo tubes.  At first I didn't like them, now they are my go-to weapon.  I sit back and launch spreads of torpedos, watch them run, and then manually detonate them when they get into range of enemy ships (if you aimed accurately).

I built 4 battleships that were well rounded and I was able to conquest a medium-sized galaxy in a couple of hours on easy mode.  You can too!  Try it today (or at least the next time it is on sale).  For $15 it is worth is straight up, but on sale, it is a no brainer.  Good luck, have fun!  My tip to the biginner, start with the ruler who gives you 3 ships, not 2.  ;-)

Sid, guess what, I like this lite 4x" version more than your big fancy games
date: lol.  You knocked this one out of the park.  What a joy to play.  I am going back in now to play a bigger
hoursPlayed: now that I know the basics.  =)   10/10"

reviewText:
10/10  Yes, that's right ney-sayers, I repeat 10/10.

[Notice that I have a fair number of games, but I don't write a lot of reviews and almost all of those are negative.]

I noticed a consistency when I read the other reviews for this game.  The players who tried it more than 10 hours recommend it, the others don't.  And why not, because it isn't Civ V, plain and simple and they went into it ready to not like it and bash it.

I don't understand what people don't like about this game.  It is not Civ V, so what?  Who cares?  It is a totally different game, and exactly what the devs said it would be (not Civ V, so get over your selves, you whiny bytches).  And guess what?  It is brilliant.  Let me repeat that, it is brilliant!  It is easy to get into, quick to understand, quick to play, and down right fun.  It brings back memories of the first Masters of Orion (MOO).  Really.  Seriously.  Try it, you will like it.

It is a very simple 4x game, but it is not Civ V, which is a much more complex, detailed-oriented, resource managing, city and army building, click-fest, that in my opinion was fun for one play through, but then... who has time?  So it beats me why they want to compare the two and then be bummed out it isn't the same?

This is a simple, straightforward, fun game with nice UI controls, nice graphics, no bugs, etc.  You have a fleet, you move it to planets, you fight various types of battles, you win the hearts and minds of the local planetarians, they join your Federation, and you move on to the next system rinse and repeat until all of the free systems are taken.  Then you duke it out with the other expanding empires.

Once you conquer a planet, you build cities and upgrades on your planet (each system only has one planet, so again, it is very easy and fast to manage your planets).  You build wonders.  You invest in research (a very simple science tree of maybe 10-12 categories which increase your ship powers.  You can buy and sell a few commodities like science, metal, fuel, and food, all of which are needed though to build cities, ships, upgrades, etc.

Building ships is the fantastic part.  It is dead simple.  You use metal to add points to your defenses (hull and shields), engine, weapons, hangers, tubes, sensors and stealth, and that is about it.  You can upgrade your ships to super dreadnaughts, or create lots of smaller ships to swarm the enemy.  You can add fighter bays and launch fighters.  You can add long range lazer weapons or short range kenetic weapons that do a lot of damage up close.  You can also add torpedo tubes.  At first I didn't like them, now they are my go-to weapon.  I sit back and launch spreads of torpedos, watch them run, and then manually detonate them when they get into range of enemy ships (if you aimed accurately).

I built 4 battleships that were well rounded and I was able to conquest a medium-sized galaxy in a couple of hours on easy mode.  You can too!  Try it today (or at least the next time it is on sale).  For $15 it is worth is straight up, but on sale, it is a no brainer.  Good luck, have fun!  My tip to the biginner, start with the ruler who gives you 3 ships, not 2.  ;-)

Sid, guess what, I like this lite 4x" version more than your big fancy games
date: lol.  You knocked this one out of the park.  What a joy to play.  I am going back in now to play a bigger
hoursPlayed: now that I know the basics.  =)   10/10"

reviewText: Yet another flawed game under the Sid Meier name, once a mark of quality. Now it seems to be used to shovel out poor flawed unfun products, that may or may not be fixed somewhat by later DLCs.\n\nThis game manages to feel pointless, meaningless, and leaves the player with a sense of total disconnect. Inferior to Star Control I, and that's saying something. It tries to look good, but doesn't have any fun factor, or depth. Its pretty disappointing when you understand all there is to know about a 4x game in your first one. This game is very primitive, and you'll get bored with it quickly. The tech is simplistic so is the economy. The tactical combat is tedious and predictable. There isn't really one aspect of the game I thought was worthwhile.

reviewText:
I picked this up in a Humble Bundle and I don't regret it at all.

A bit easy on the normal difficulty and the ships don't offer a lot of special qualitites but the simplified Civ style  combined with turn based tactical space combat is very enjoyable and never feels unfair.

Decent value  at 15$  despite short playtime
10$  is the really recommend price as it won't feel like a rip off even if you are a one and done person.
5$ is a no brainer buy.

reviewText:
I was expecting more.  At $15, this isn't a game you should buy. Its not a bad game. It just isn't a $15 game for running on a PC. It feels more like a $5 for a tablet and I'd give a a thumbs up there if that was what it was.

It doesn't have great graphics. They are ok. It doesn't have great gameplay (think very light MOO - a much better game, even to this day), but again... its not bad.

If you want something that is a light 4x game, I wouldn't exactly recommend it... and you might be able to find something better for your money. Wait for a Steam sale. Wait to see if the game shows up on your favorite tablet for $5. Don't get this at this price point unless you have a driving need to have a section of your library that has every Sid Meier branded game.

reviewText:
Overall, it's a good game.  But I do wonder if this is a pet project under one of Sid Meier's proteges.

Strategy and negotiation are bit limited for space faring races battling for domination.
While it is a good idea to keep the screen readout in a technical/tactical format, the graphics leave a few things to be desired.  They're not bad, but for a Sid Meier's project, I expected more time and effort and definitely smoother eye candy.  I like the idea of controlling planet economies with food, metal, science, energy but I couldn't tell if I had a true effect nor how to make an effect.  The only way to distinguish yourself is choosing Superiority, Harmony or Purity.  But even then, I couldn't see any true benefit other than changing the character's profile or ship designs.

IMHO:  It doesn't engage the player to want to be a part of any side in particular.  Again, I couldn't see any advantages or disadvantages to choosing a particular affinity.  Perhaps what's missing here is more to the Beyond Earth story?

Bottom line:  This is certainly worth a look if you're into the strategy/space/sci-fi/turn based strategy sort of thing.  Consider waiting for a special offer.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A simple game where you use a single fleet of ships to conquor the universe. If your looking for a long, well thought out game where you masterfully plot galatic conquest through a combination of diplomacy, military strength and technological superiority you'll have to go elsewhere. If your looking for a simple strategy game that offers more than one path to success and can be finsihed in less than 6 hours this might be for you.

One of the things I like most about this game is the multiple upgrade paths for the ships. Every weapon has its strength and is a valid path to take to victory. Both focused and broad upgrade paths are viable. Wonders can make a strategy go from good to overwhelming. Which path you choose to follow can be heavily influenced by the worlds you have access to. All in all, it is very much a light" version of civilization. What it lacks in depth and polish it makes up for in easy of play.

I haven't played the hardest settings in the game yet
date: but one definate flaw is the enemy AI. The AI is fairly simple and after a while mostly predictable. It does occasionally do something I wouldn't predict but generally how it moves is perdictable. Also there is a wonder to allow you to move first
recommended: but I find that I'd rather go second most of the time as enemy ships usually start behind cover and their first move exposes them."

reviewText:
As usual, Steam's rating system is woefully inadequate.

Do I recommend this?  Yes.  Buuuut... get it on sale.  I got this on sale as part of a bundle and am quite happy with that.  Had I paid the original... what was it? $20 I think.... I would have been p(censored)ed.  But as it is I'm pleased.  For what, a few years ago, I would have spent for an evening at an arcade, I got a good solid evening entertainment out of it.  And I will probably play it again… one day when I’m bored but too lazy for a console game.

Is this a great strategy game?  Eh… no.  Tech trees are linear, ship upgrades are entirely statistical and you get one and only one fleet.  you can add ships and upgrade them individually.  but you can only ever have the 1 fleet.  Planets can have bots defending them but they, as far as I can tell, they (the bots) can not be upgraded.  (Planets can.) And on the subject of planets, each planet gets it's own personal exclusive wonder that you can build.  1 per.  No options as to what.  Happy Birthday.

That said, the battles are fun.  Which is good since this is pretty combat heavy,  The opposing AI is not stupid.  (Which is refreshing for a space game.)  Lots of asteroids and stuff to fly around.  AND for this first time in a space strategy game (outside of MOO3 which I believe I am one of 4 people on Earth that did not hate) fighters actually are worth a c(censored)p.

So... Is it recommended?  Yes.  Is it worthy of the Sid Meier name?  Eeeehhhh... no.  More like high end Kongregate stuff.    (Though the voice acting is good.)

Oh... sort of an after thought here.  The story... you know the bit about hearing a distant call for help and stuff...  Makes no sense what so ever.  It certainly doesn't seem to have ANYTHING to do with the game.  Who were these guys?  No idea.  Do you ever encounter them?  Not that I have seen.  Or maybe I did and it just wasn't mentioned.  Played through.  Peace reins supreme throughout the galaxy.  No Idea who these guys were.  Never heard from them or about them again.

So, in short, wait for a good sale, skip the intro and assume Sid hit his head on something and will make a full recovery... later.

Thanks for listening... err... reading.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
So I've played this game a few times now and I have a love-hate relationship with it.

Things I love:

1. It's relatively easy to learn how to play
2. The controls are straight forward
3. It's a quest like, planet upgrade system based, sci-fi starship combat game
4. You can customise your ships with a range of weapons and/or defenses
5. Turn-based tactical combat

Things I hate:

1. Ship upgrades have absolutely the bare minimum of information attached to them.  Want to know how much damage an extra point of lasers" will do on your ship - sorry
date: that's just too much information for you to handle
recommended: so no.  Want to know how much damage a point of shields can handle - "you want to know the truth? well you can't handle the truth!"\n\nShield upgrade information says "damaged shields regenerate each turn"
hoursPlayed:
but during combat you have no idea what the strengths of the shields are or  by how much they've been damaged.

The truth is that there is about as much information on things like shield strength and weapon strengths that they may as well have said that this weapon upgrade will improve your firepower by three bananas and a pineapple and that would still have been more information than you're currently given!

2. The tech tree is very simplistic
voteText: and every time you buy a tech
helpfulPercent: every other tech goes up in cost - there's of course no information that this is going to happen or by how much
votesHelpful: because information is a dangerous thing in the wrong hands!\n\n3. Ship combat - well
votesTotal: suffice to say that I have found the path to victory is fighters - upgrade them to the max and equip a couple of fighters on each ship - by tech level 6
votesFunny: they're deadly and you can literally spam them out in sufficient quantities to overwhelm your foes without ever really risking your capital ships to any damage.  Of course YMMV...\n\n4. Wonders...they range from meh to OMGWTFBBQ!  And the great/sad news is they all cost similar amounts.  So if you're lucky enough to get the "two actions" wonder early on - congrats
commentsCount: you've probably just won the space race!\n\n5. The diplomatic options are so underwhelming
column16:
it's like some kids from kindergarden got together to try and form the UN and then realised that politics is just way too complicated for them and decided to go back to just playing cops & robbers.

6. No multiplayer options :(

Overall I rate this game about 6 out of 10 for the style more than the substance.  If you're looking for something deep
column17: this isn't the game for you."

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Starships is a game wherein you use ships that travel between planets (and presumably stars) on a map to do missions where you shoot lasers and torpedoes and other spacenaval things at other craft that ply the space trails. There's also some lightweight empire management in the shape of upgrading planets and making your ships shootier/faster/have invisible torpedoes, but 90% of your gametime is going to consist of: going to a planet, kicking in the teeth of anyone who looks at you funny, repeat until there are no more people who need to be kicked this turn.

It's definitely not a very complex space game—it's an iOS port, what were you expecting?—but it's pretty fun as a hex-based Battlefleet Gothic. Without firing arcs or the accursed cannon table. Or much inter-faction variation. But it''s got the torpedoes! By god does it have torpedoes.

Good: Lightweight, Hexagonal Space Combat!
Bad: May not be crunchy enough for the embittled space grognard.

Reccomended for: People looking to ease themselvesinto the inky void of space, People who play Civ:BE and want Ultrasonic Emitters[civilization.wikia.com]
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Though it's hardly a full-on Civ title, Starships remains a fun and enjoyable diversion from the lackluster Beyond Earth. With tactical potential a bit beyond the usual Civ title (Not that that's anything to write home about), the conquest of far-flung star systems and the control of Earth's descendants should keep anyone relatively happy. For a few hours, at least.

That said, the battles are fun.  Which is good since this is pretty combat heavy,  The opposing AI is not stupid.  (Which is refreshing for a space game.)  Lots of asteroids and stuff to fly around.  AND for this first time in a space strategy game (outside of MOO3 which I believe I am one of 4 people on Earth that did not hate) fighters actually are worth a c(censored)p.

So... Is it recommended?  Yes.  Is it worthy of the Sid Meier name?  Eeeehhhh... no.  More like high end Kongregate stuff.    (Though the voice acting is good.)

Oh... sort of an after thought here.  The story... you know the bit about hearing a distant call for help and stuff...  Makes no sense what so ever.  It certainly doesn't seem to have ANYTHING to do with the game.  Who were these guys?  No idea.  Do you ever encounter them?  Not that I have seen.  Or maybe I did and it just wasn't mentioned.  Played through.  Peace reins supreme throughout the galaxy.  No Idea who these guys were.  Never heard from them or about them again.

So, in short, wait for a good sale, skip the intro and assume Sid hit his head on something and will make a full recovery... later.

Thanks for listening... err... reading.

reviewText:
A neat, small-scale game
Sid Meier's Starships is a simple, quick, fun little strategy game. Don't go into this game expecting a 40-hour campaign and hours of careful planning, because that's not what this game is made for.

Starships feels and plays like a very casual game-in fact, everything from the UI to the simplistic controls and systems screams that this game was built for a tablet or phone rather than a full blown PC. This isn't exactly a bad thing as the UI is clean and easy to navigate, with oversized text and icons.

Combat is on a 2d hex grid, with various objects(asteroids, planets, etc.) either blocking vision and fire, or reducing the damage dealt when firing through them. Positioning, shields, and weapon types all factor in as well, giving just enough depth to combat to keep it from getting too stale.

There's not really any alien species, just different flavors of humans. All the ships have similar looks and feel, though you can upgrade their weapons and systems in anyway you want, which is neat. I'd have liked more variety but what you get is servicable.You can only have one 'fleet' on the campaign map though, which is a bit annoying.

Really my biggest gripe with this game is in the achievements, as you need Beyond Earth (or at least a save game from it) to perfect it.

Final Verdict:
Decent buy, especially on sale. Scratches that strategy itch without needing 40+ free hours.

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Starships isn't a bad game, but it isn't a particularly good game either.  It certainly isn't worth the $15 asking price.  The gameplay is incredibly shallow, and although the missions appear to be randomized, each game feels more or less the same because there are only a few types of missions.  Faction and leader choice don't make much of a difference which further harms replayability.  Games can be completed within as little as one hour, and I don't think many people will feel compelled to play through the game more than a couple of times.

There is very little ship customization--all you can do is add new ships and increase stats.  Missions are so basic that strategy is almost non-existent.  The AI is horrible; I once watched an AI controlled ship fire a torpedo into a planet in a vain effort to hit one of my ships that was behind it.  Although given how little depth there is to the game, I don't know what could be reasonably expected of the AI.  You can use asteroids for cover (which can be bypassed by certain upgrades and torpedoes), and there are warps placed around the map.  Ships entering a warp are randomly sent to another warp; strategy is somewhat limited because of this.

Starships is a streamlined mobile game and it shows.  In addition to the lack of depth, it is not well optimized for PC.  The fullscreen option is weird and the game won't cover the task bar (you need to set the taskbar to auto hide in order to get real fullscreen).  Some of the text is also very hard to read, and there are no options for graphics settings.

I got Starships in a bundle and I don't regret playing it, but don't go out of your way to buy it or spend much on it.

reviewText: I waited to buy this game when it was on sale because of the mixed reviews but I was pleasantly surprized at how much fun the game is.  There is depth to this game in many key areas.  While not MOO, Masters of Orion, it manages to create its own niche in this genre.  What I really like is how you can customize each ship, even within the same class.  For example you can have 2 corvettes, one a long range attacker and another a carrier.  There are many more options available to you.  Also planetary upgrading is fun and important strategically as well as tactically.  There is a lot to be said for this game that is positive.  But suffice to say, that you should not wait for it to go in the bargain basement to get it.

reviewText:
8.5/10
Overview: I recommend this game because it has a surprising amount of strategic and tactical depth yet is simple to pick up. Steam's returns policy makes it well-worth trying out and returning if you don't like it.

I am not a huge 4X fan; but I enjoy Starships because while it provides a light introduction to the genre it also, IMO, provides a satisfying degree of strategy at the map level and tactics at the system levels of the game. Some people don't like the game because they claim it lacks depth, but I believe they haven't tried to play on tough enough difficulty levels. One of the things I've noticed about several 4X games is that there are a lot of turns where you don't do anything, you simply press the End Turn button and let things develop. There is NONE of that in Starships; every move and action count.

The game requires you to balance your ship capabilities with your play style. Do you like to use lasers at long distance? Or do you build ships and armor and Plasma cannons to mix it up in close? Fighters and Torpedoes can be cannon fodder and simple barriers to your opponents movement or, properly built, can be decisive scouts and salvo weapons that can devastate your enemies. The hex grid at the system combat level makes it look like a board game, but that is a refreshing change IMO.

Balancing resources appears simple, but at higher difficulty, you have to build the right improvements on the proper planets to get maximum resource benefits. You should also connect your planets with Warp Nexus' to allow movement with no morale point penalties.

Strategically, you can assault your opponent's planets to take Wonders away or deprive them of resources; or you can drive accross their empire, cutting off their fleet and allowing you to defeat the AI in detail.

In all, this is a simple introduction to the 4X genre, and on the Mac, where options are a bit limited, it is a good start.

reviewText:
It's a very fun and easy to play game, however it's quite simple, there aren't even video settings in it. Just pick up and play. Would be really cool on a Surface or something of that nature.

Don't expect Civ 5 in Space, it's not even going to come close to that. It's a very short casual game. No tutorial really, just tooltips, but with those it takes around 30 minutes to figure the game out so it's not really a bad thing.

The game definitely could've gone further, but for the price on the Winter Sale of about $8CAD it's definitely a great purchase. I intend on playing this on my macbook when I need something to just pass a few minutes.

reviewText: Civilization in space this is not but what it is a great wee game. There's not a lot of nuance to the game but then, I think, that's the best time. It allows you to pick up and play without spending lots of hours figuring out research trees or particular bonuses. Sure each planet has a wonder you can build and a resource they'll produce more of but, if I'm honest, you don't need to pay that too much attention. The battles are the fun part and whilst the maps in which they take place are a bit repetitive they're fun, engaging and the part of the game I look forward to the most.\n\nIn the end Starships is a game for a quick session. If you set the difficulty level down you can thrash out a game in around an hour or so and moving up the scale, obviously, makes things harder. Either way if you're expecting some kind of 4X competitor to the likes of Sins of a Solar Empire you'll be disappointed. However approach this as a game to just have fun with and you'll have a ball.

reviewText: If you liked Civ 5, and if you loved Civ: Beyond Earth, then get ready! This game will likely dissapoint!\nSeriously, if you're gaming on a Windows Surface, you may find this a good time waster for $15. But if you, like me, are on a real PC and interested in a fun 4X experience, then know that this game greatly fails to live up to the Sid Meier name. It is repetative, essentially relying on a singular game mechanic where you pilot a single type of ship through about 5 puzzles. There is a maze, a capture and control, a hunt, etc. The ship types are naught, you get a ship that has a largely linear upgrade path. While I could have plenty of fun on the bus with my tablet, on my PC this game feels like solitaire plus. A let down. Now, while this doesn't cost as much as a landmark game it still could have more flavor. The civilizations feels like different theme colors, and the technologies and cash have a more passive feel than I'd like.

reviewText:
A lot of people expect this to be some sort of Civ clone, when it frankly isn't, and shouldn't be treated like one. Starships is a small 4X game, which I guess you could say is like a Mini Stellaris. It takes 1 - 2 hours per game, but doesn't feel like a slog neither a really rushed experience. It is quite balanced in that matter.  It is a nice game to play if for example your internet is having a rough patch and you want something to pass the time thats quick, and isn't like a full blown game like Civ V is.

There are obvious problems though. The first is a lack of workshop, dlc or any further updates to the game. What you buy is what you will forever play in Starships, which is a massive shame as it could really work.

It also lacks a tutorial, but it is easy to pick up, graphics settings (though it is pretty lightweight) and biggest one: Multiplayer. Now for some this is fine, but they did miss a chance to build a decent multiplayer, that doesn't go on like Civ  ones to.

In conclusion, I do reccomend this game. It is pretty fun to play, but does lack certain things. If you hate 4X/Turn Based Strategy Games, this isn't for you. But if you do, this may be a good pick up, but wait until a sale as the £11 price tag is a bit too big personally.

reviewText:
I never learn.

I told myself after Civ: Beyond Earth that I wasn't going to pre-order any more of Sid Meier's games, that I was going to wait and see how they were recieved first and then make an informed decision. But the lure of Firaxis is not so easily resisted.

Sadly, in this case it should've been. The sirens have once again lured us all onto the rocks.

Now, full disclosure, I am writing this review with less than an hour of play time on this game under my belt. It honestly doesn't take all that long to get a feel for the game, I'm afraid. The entire thing was obviously designed for the mobile platform release first, and then reverse-engineered for the PC relese as an afterthought. It was bad enough when this was being done with console games...

The interface is a joke. The game starts off windowed, has no graphical settings to change other than setting it to full-windowed" (And when IN "full-windowed" mode has no way to exit the game other than reverting to windowed mode or alt-f4... seriously

recommended: and everything inside of the game was designed with a touchscreen in mind. And then there's the gameplay...\n\nIf you ever wanted a "simplified" version of a civ game

column18: I'm not bitter.)\n\nPlanets have cities
column19: cities produce metal
column20: food
column21: energy
column22: science. You spend science to research tech. You spend metal to build improvements. You spend food to build new cities. You spend energy to build and upgrade ships. And... that's it. Everything else is going from planet to planet and fulfilling "missions" with your ships.\n\nOh

reviewText:
I would recommend this game whole-heartedly, with the caveat that this is NOT a full 4X game.

Rather it's a diet 4X game for when you want those warm fuzzy feelings that come from seeing your empire expand and grow, without all the time and setup of a full 4X session.

What is the main attraction of this game is the Starships (it's in the title). From fighting off pirate attacks, to storming the capitals of enemy civs, the spacebattles are the real meat of the game. And to be honest, there's nothing as satisfying as seeing one of your ships blast a Death Star knockoff to smitherens in a single blast.

Biggest con: the menus don't scroll to let you see all the options. Firaxis, would it have killed you to take a day or so to fix that?

reviewText:
It's a nice minigame!
Nothing more, nothing less.

This game is about your fleet. Caring about every ship. Caring about every move and turn.
I really like the aspect, that you can upgrade your ship, step for step. So that your initial small ship grows to a mighty battlecruiser. In order to do that, you need ressources. Planets. To get them you have to do initial missions and later on you can plain conquer them from other people.

There are some ways to vitctory, but most time is spent on the hexagonal battlefield. Playing a few games there is fun, but after some time its start to be repetive because you don't have much options to varify your strategy. Its like playing chess, but only with towers and pawns.

Nevertheless the game makes a lot of fun, especially if you want to play a more laid back game, than in other strategy games.

reviewText:
Fool me once, shame no you.  Fool me twice, shame on me.

Sid, Sid, Sid...I used to buy your games without a thought, now you've disappointed me two games in a row.

Starships is a simplified 4x Space Strategy game meant for IOS and ported to PC/Mac.  While there are elements of the game that are intrigueing, the replayability is limited by several poor design decisions and a complete lack of PC based options like hot-keys, resolution settings, and multiplayer.

If you are intrigued enough to buy this game, pick it up on IOS.

reviewText:
The game looks good and runs smoothly but there are things wrong with it. Trying to upgrade my fleet is impossible. It says I can buy upgrades but it doesn't register any of my clicks therefore my fleet is incapable of getting anywhere.

The tutorial isn't really a tutorial but if you know how civ works then you don't really need it. It isn't as big as any other civ game but it is a nice little game. Controlling your ships in battle is a nice touch in the civ series because you get to control how the battle will turn out instead of attacking a unit and letting the AI determine the outcome.

If they fix the bug where the fleet can't be upgraded then I will give this game a positive recommendation but until then I can't recommend this game.

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of Sid meier's games but this one is a stinker.....
It feels like an iphone game,has no real depth and can be completed in 30 mins to an hour and should you want to keep playing after the lazy victory/defeat message you are out of luck ,just takes you back to main menu.

If this had some tweaks such as being able to control multiple fleets,better tech tree eg more like civ or BE it would probably be an average game at best.

if this was on a 80% sale i would say sure get it but full price? no way!

reviewText:
Imagine Civilization Beyond Earth as a tablet game about spaceships, and you have this.

It's not bad, it's just shallow and lacking in areas that make a Civ game so good. Normally I would spend hourson this but... it's too simple. I understand the 'simple to get hard to master mechanic', but here its simply ' easy to get, moderately annoying to understand'.

The leaders are not animated in any way, there are very very few voice files, so expect to hear the same things on repeat.

The combat is an extension of Civ V's system aplied to spaceships, and not much else, some battlefield obstacles mixed in perhaps.

I'm glad they only charged £11 for it, because this isn't worth £15, let alone a full game.

If you take it as a concept mini-game, it's great. As a standalone, you'll be done in a couple hours, easy.

reviewText:
<Too Lazy To Read; Read This>
!!! Close this page and spend your money elsewhere, seriously !!!

This game doesn't deserve Sid Meier's name...are we even sure Sid had anything to do with this game?

And to add salt to the wound, this game is made by the people at 2K Games and Firaxis, great people who are responsible for one of my favourite games, XCOM: Enemy Unknown, is an utter disgrace.

The game feels like it was from an indie company, it plays, feels, looks, sounds LIKE an indie game. As a matter of fact, an indie company would make an even better version than this Android/iOS hack game!

Trust me when i say this, it isn't worth the money, isn't worth the bandwidth nor electricity bill, even if it was for $0.99!

This is the FIRST time in my life i regret buying a game....I wish i could get a refund.

reviewText:
Mediocre at best, this is a disappointing entry.  While I can forgive most of Civ:BE's flaws, especially in light of 2.0, this game largely plays like it walked right off of an Apple 2, with hardly any actual depth.

This is a tablet game or smart phone game, that should be selling at $0.99, and not a game that should be at the $15 price point.  The tie in to Civ:BE is poorly thought out, and is largely a sham.  However, the graphics are good and it's stable, which puts it unlike most of the releases from some vendors here.

But overall, repetetive, lifeless and smartphone.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
EDIT: As of today there are 41 PAGES of technical issues about this game. The issues thread was set up by a 2K moderator so that the community could help each other but there is no official developer presence on the Steam forums. When I mentioned that it would help us if 2K would at least give us a word about a possible patch I was told quite tersely that 2K devs do not READ the Steam forums.

I have profound respect for Sid Meier, but, that said, if the developers are not being made aware of 41 pages of crash issues about this game and we are told that we should submit a support ticket to 2K, then what is the purpose of the issues thread? Indie developers have a much better sense of customer satisfaction and 2K/Firaxis could learn a LOT from them.

--------------

The game plays well for some but there are some things prospective buyers need to know. There is a thread in the Community Hub for this game that is of this writing 33 pages of posts most reporting that this game will not launch or else it crashes after the logo splash screen. A minority - including myself - are reporting severe memory leaks. The game IS a lot of fun AS LONG AS YOU ARE NOT EXPECTING A 4X. This game is a tactical game reminiscent of Amarillo Design Bureau's classic Star Fleet Battles but obviously due to licensing is not set in th Star Trek universe.

Most people cannot launch the game, some of us CAN play it but is suffers a severe memory leak, others have had to adjust their mouse polliung or disable certain features in theor sound cards. To be fair, some folks aren't experiencing any issues at all.

Buyer beware. The game has been out for 12 days as of this edit and no patch or hint of a patch is fortcoming.

reviewText: This is a quick, lightweight game, but is amazingly enjoyable. For the cheap price, even when it's not on sale, I would recommend getting it. It brings the strategy of turn-based games we love not only to a galactic campaign of expanding space federations but also to tactical space battles above planets that introduce detailed elements of combat that you might know from non-Civilization Sid Meier's titles. Games can be short, but it's easy to jump into another one.

reviewText: I think that this game suffers mixed reviews not because it's a bad game, but because it comes with the Sid Meier label and gamers have come to expect that Sid Meiers games are deep, filled with management options, and usually long. This game, however, has streamlined management, a shallower tech tree, and can be very quick (over and done in 40 minutes on regular settings.)\n\nDespite the mixed reviews I bought it, played it, enjoyed it, and thought it was well worth the 7.95 I paid for it. I found it was good for about 8 to 10 hours of play.

reviewText:
Interesting lightweight strategy game.
Nowhere near Total War, Starcraft, Heroes or any of the Civilization games. It gets a bit repetitive quite quickly, and there doesn't seem to be much depth in the strategy either.
The game was designed to go along Civ : BE (there are some bonuses provided in each game if you own both), so I think the shallowness is intended.
Still, for $5 on a Steam Sale, I think it's worth it. Overall a 6/10.

reviewText:
This isn't a strategy game - or at least not one like Civ, MOO, SINS, etc. It is more like a role-playing game that uses spaceships and turn-based combat.

That said, for $10 (its initial release price), it's not bad. I actually quite enjoyed it, it has some replayability, and is worth a few bucks - especially if you can get it on sale. Comparing it to other AAA titles is a bit unfair because it started as a $10 game and isn't much more than that. But it is fun, unique, clever and will give a few hours of gameplay.

But it doesn't have the one more turn" additiction of other strategy games.

Also
date: lasers and fighters are overpowered. :) Torpedoes are too
recommended: but harder to aim (except against easy AI)."

reviewText: I think a lot of the negative reviews of this game may be due to people expecting a MoO/Civ hybrid, which this game certainly isn't.  However, it is still an excellent game in its own right, much faster moving and with better depth than Sid's Pirates, which is also a game I enjoyed.\n\nThis game is really quite reminiscent of a tabletop miniatures game combined with an extensive campaign system.  There really are three parts to the game:  resource development, resource allocation, and tactical starship combat.  The first two are accomplished during those times when you grant your crew shore leave" -- a fancier way of pressing the standard Civ turn button -- and watching the enemy players go through their turns.  You have to upgrade planets

reviewText: I figured this game would be a nice addition to Beyond Earth...I was wrong. In addition to the fact that the game is quite limited in scope, it doesn't particularly add quite the connectivity to BE as expected and it falls short in the enjoyment arena too. reviewText:
Let me start with this: I love Civ Rev.

If that statement alone makes you recoil in disgust, walk away from Starships and this review. I didn't come to this game looking for the depth that VI and V offer--or an experience which would redeem BE (I disliked it in fact). Instead I looking for something that can scratch that X-COMy, Pirates!-y, and straightforward Civ Rev itch which this game handily satisfies.

Bonust points: Really reminds me of the 4x tabletop game, Eclipse--gathering resources, upgrading planets--extending your influence. Also a simiilar 'rubberband'  (escalating cost worker placement) mechanic keeps you from expanding too far too fast in the form of your crew's fatigue level. If you undertake too many missions, or travel too far your combat effectiveness plummets. There are ways to extend your crew's fatigue, but at the cost of resources which could be better spent improving the planets you control.

The game also does a fine job during missions as well. The battles are fast paced and satisfying, even addictive. I often find myself absentmindedly going on another mission when I already decided that the last one was the last one.

Penalties:
They drop the ball in many places. To start, graphically, there's an appreciable difference between stylized and cartoony, and this game veers toward the latter. There's also ample room for imagination in the implemetation of weapon effects, and many missed opportunities to really differentiate the ship classes between affinities. The affinites are basically skin deep, and only add a starting bonus to the civ that chooses it. Another missed opportunity for depth is laying out the actual armament and defenses of your ships, ala Eclipse. There's no 'energy' cost however, for upgrading aside from the resource itself. Hence, with enough resources your could put every upgrade on one ship since there's no energy cap. Even FTL figured out a good balance in this regard.

This game isn't for eveyone but if you found anything I said forgivable or intriguing--for $15 dollars--this game is worth it.

reviewText:
Basically Civ Lite - you have only one unit available, but the unit is vastly customisable and upgradable - becoming very powerful.  The unit is used in missions, which give influence with the various planets you visit; and when 4 points of influence are accrued, the planet in question will join your federation, giving you access to all it's resources.

There are several ways to win the game:  domination, population (controlling 51% of the population of the galaxy), science, wonder (building 6 wonders).  You can choose to have them all available, or just one.

There are a good number of leaders available, each with different skills, and with three different versions of each leader to choose from, allowing yet more customisation.

Despite all this the game feels a little unfinished and clunky, and is frankly in need of a decent tutorial level - as it can be a little confusing to start with.  There's also no real warning when the AI's about to win, which would be nice - so something could be done about it, like in Civ 5.

All in all, I'd give this game 7/10 as once you get to grips with things it's a fun game.  I'd like it to be longer, but you can't have everything.  I consider it worth the money.  Took me about 25 hours to complete it on the hardest difficulty, which made it about 50p an hour.

reviewText:
I wish I knew what I was getting before I actually paid for this.  I have played Sid Meier's games off and on over the years, but this is one that is truly sorry in execution, playability, development, everything.

First experience:

I played what was defaulted small,Easy, 4 AI, All victory conditions.  The game lasted about five minutes with it laughing in my face saying: going through the tutorial noob...  oh wait there is no tutorial, or any of the sort of helpfulness to get into the game.

I gave it another go: Epic map, conquest...  my bad, I mean domination.  I had thought I had to mean conquer your enemies and all their territory...  Nope.  Just take over 42% +/- of the map.  this includes waiting for your galactic neighbors to become nice and ripe and take over their homeworld and all their space becomes yours...  and the A.I. knows this too...  and is horribly imbalanced.  An AI corvette can kill an AI battleship no sweat.
Which by the way, it should take a bit more work to conquer an enemy homeworld or enemy space.  Sure striking their homeworld could hit their moral, but an AI shouldn't just up and give up all their space at the loss of their home planet.

reviewText:
This game is WAY, WAY, WAY to easy. I think its because the resource gain is to high. You can get energy very fast and with that you can level you ships in 2-3 round so that they are unbeatable by the KI - after that you just fly around and get any system you want.

The problem with that is that you also can try out every module you want very fast - in games i saw and tryed everything and i dont really feel like playing a new round would be fun... thats sad.

If the resource gain would be lower, so that you can buy one or two modules each round it would be much more fun - because you would slowly get stronger and could try out much more stuff. With the given settings the game is barely replayable.

If a mod support would be integrated the game could become something really cool - but i dont think they will add it.

reviewText:
Had high hopes for the game after the failure of Sid Meyers's Beyond Earth... But this game manages to greatly exceed Beyond Earth in its failure.

This is feels like a $5 tablet game that they are selling on PC for $15....

* No Multiplayer
* AI is incredibly bad. Half the time three quarters of their fleet will fly away from me even though they have me ridiculously outgunned
* Missions are incredibly repetitive

I wasn't expecting a AAA game since it only cost $15... But given the number of FREE to play games out there that are amazing to play, this was a big disappointment.

Above all it is... boring.

reviewText:
Ive been contemplating how to write a reveiw for this game. Simply put this is an extremely simplistic, mobile game, with the desire to be something more. Truely this game falls on its face once you start, you will immeditly notice how much of BE/Civ 6 has been recycled. I would have prefered an expantion to BE than this. it a nice concept but it lack almost everything to do with CIv, other than idea of having similar names. If this had multy, i may have been swayed towards enjoying out chessing my friends.

This is a single only game with very predictable AI, making the torpedos broken as ♥♥♥♥. many of the wonders in this are useless because they provide benifits that would only fool a human and not the computer. The wonder victory is too easy to win as well, I inadvertantly won just by building 5 wonders on the impossible difficulty. needless to say it is an easy game too.

Out of all the people to select, there are all the sponsors from BE with the addition of one more person, many of them are pointless as there are some that are just simply more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t than others. The afinity system is back, but only as a shadow. Unlike in BE the afinity system is a passive mechanic that something that does nothing to change how you play.

........TL:DR.........

Worth $2-$5 MAYBE......
At $15 i feel like i wasted money.
Mobile game quality.
Single only.
Stupidly simplistic.
EASY
Worth about 3h of play before you forget this exists.

reviewText:
Simplified Tactical Space combat

What this game is:
This game is a very well done, highly polished, turn based, tactical space ship combat game.  It's lighter on the options than a lot of current space combat games out there. But it still gives you a good variety of combat options and choices, from upgrades to diplomacy to battle changing wild cards.  This is a game you can sit down, play for a little bit, and then walk away from when you've got some time to kill.

What this game ISNT:
This isn't the next evolution in the Civ games.  This game ISNT a 4x style strategy game, despite it's tie in with Sid Meier's Civizliation: Beyond Earth.  This isn't a highly complicated game with a lot of options.  This game isn't a game that allows you a massive variety of space ship upgrades and personalization options.

Biggest drawback:
Lack of multiplayer.  This is a single player only game.

My thoughts:
For the entry price, this game is worth it; as long as you know what you're getting when you buy it.  A lot of the negative reviews are people who didn't understand that this was a more basic turn based strategy.  I've enjoyed my time with it so far and look forwards to playing more.  But if you go into it expecting a massive array of options, and deep combat, you're going to be dissapointed.  The best analogy I can use is that sometimes you don't want to play Monopoly or Catan, but want to sit down and just play a simple game of solitare.  That's what this is, it's a simple, fun, engaging, non complicated single player game.   More than that, it's one that's done very well in fact.  Just make sure you know that's what you want.  Because if you want complicated 4x, epic space battles, or ship customization that takes you days to master, look elsewhere.   But if you want a fun, turn based, tactical, I'd reccomend this game.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First things first, this is a 90% positive review! I loved it!

A damn good little game...As a huge fan of the Ace Patrol games, Starships was right up my alley. Quick, brutal, and lightweight, it hits all the right notes for hex based combat with none of the clutter, something far too few developers seem capable of. What it lacks in the aerial flourish of Ace Patrol's dogfights, it makes up for with strategic depth, provided by the galactic map on which the player completes missions, sways planetary systems under his or her influence, and chooses either war or peace (war, let's be honest) with his or her neighbors. All of that, though, is contained in an easy to learn, easy to come back to little package of simple game mechanics we all know and love.

Still, some things feel missing...The game promises modular shipbuilding and doesn't really deliver. What you get is a simple fleet of ships (of which you can only have one) with a handful of stats to be individually raised. Ship look is determined entirely by your choice of the Harmony/Purity/Supremacy triad of Beyond Earth. As stats are raised, the relevant modules on the ship will beef up and become more characteristic. That's pretty much it for modularity. I played around with specialization of particular ships (destroyers, carriers, etc), but as long as the empire is stable and able to produce resources, all your ships will end up a little same-y.
Additionally, the lack of any kind of story or scenario mode isn't glaring, but it would be welcome. Ace Patrol had real wars to draw from, granted, but this sets up like a Civ game without being as deep or engaging in the long term. Even just more control over the rules or map generation would go a long way.

Why it's for you...->You've been itching to play a lightweight hex based game
->You played both Ace Patrols instead of doing real work until you ran out of game
->Starships are cool

Why it's NOT for you...->You're looking for another 4X
->You'd like to spend the next 10 hours glued to your desk chair
->You, for some reason, think starships are not cool. You'd be wrong, weirdo.

reviewText:
A leap forward ? Or a step backwards ?

When I think of Sid Meier Games, I think of complexity, good balancing,  time investment. If I think about the first day I saw Starships announced, I was very enthusiastic about a space game made by the creators of Civilization. I couldn't wait until the day it comes out on Steam, checking every day the time left.

And then the time came, and I made the leap of faith to buy it and play it. What happened next not only puzzled me, it saddened me quite a bit.

The first time I launch a new game I always check the options menu to set up my audio and video settings. This time I couldn't find ANY graphic options and I started thinking of Starships like I would an unfinished/unpolished game. It felt like an Alpha version of a future game.

Nevertheless, I still wanted to see the game mechanics and what was in this game content wise.

A couple of clicks and choices later I was in a brand new universe managing a planet and 2 starships.

5 hours later and a few restarts I already finished the game on domination and I slapped my face because of the lack of a challenge behind the game. I'm not even inclined to open it another time for another game. :(

If you are looking for a quick, skirmish like, march of war style, starship game, this is the game for you, if not, don't bother.

My packet thoughts :

- over simplified options (every option included ! actions/buildings/research/ship modules/wonders/even the EPIC galaxy is tiny)
- very stupid AI (shoot 5 torpedoes towards them and they will turn tail and run)
- few research options and too easy to reach
- lvl 8 capacity on every ship module (WHAT?!)
- 8 maximum ships in a fleet !
- only 1 FLEET !
- very weak graphics

I hope with all my heart this is not a finished game. It had potential and it was a very, very, very bad failure!

Overall feeling for a PC game : 8 year old mentality

I think this game is much more suited for tablets or phones. Even those are more complex..... did you know they developed MMORPG's on tablets?!?!?!??

Please tell me your going to make massive changes to this game !

reviewText: I feel cheated by this title. Anyone expecting a rich, rewarding, deep Civ game is going to be as disappointed as I was. This is a mobile game at best- not a great one either. The tech system is BS, no new trechnologies, just levels in existing ones, The ship upgrade system is BS, you don't get to design the layout of your ship, you just increase stats and the model changes slightly. The city building is BS, again it's just increasing stats with little to no progression. Missions are BS, they're either obscenely difficult or iunsultingly easy with no means to gauge just how hard they are. Not tried out the interface with Civ: Beyond Earth and I'm not sure I can be bothered attempting it.\n\nThis game made me sad. It made me feel like I'd been conned. 3/10, Avoid. There are better examples of games like this for less money. Come on Sid, we know you can do better than this.

reviewText: Having played Sid Meier's Civilization since its first incarnation, I was interested to see how a $15 combat focused spinoff would play out. Starships possesses minimal depth and is far cry from what fans of the series are acustomed to. This is not Civilization, but it also doesn't pretend to be. It is a fun $15 game that focuses almost entirely on fairly rudementry combat mechanics. I have been enjoying the game and I highly encourage people to purchase it. Take a look at some Youtube videos and make your determination from there. What you see is what you get. There are no surprises.\n\nOn a hours played to money spent ratio, Sid Meier's Starships is absolutely worth a buy.

reviewText:
Kyu's Review for this game, Sid Meier's Starships:

Me:  I play way too many games, almost all the time.  I grew up on RPGs and turn based strategies, but I would play everything given the time and money.  That being said, I mostly stick to strategy, rpgs, fps, arcade, rhythm, ccgs, lcgs, board games, fighting games, etc

I am going to tell you how I boiled the game down, and win relatively easily.  I don't have a sample size of 100 games, but I am 3 for 3 on easy, moderate, and hard, with max players, small and epic sizes, all 3 affinities, etc.  Impossible is the only mode i have yet to touch.

#1 strat:  Fighters.  The names may not be exact, but here is what you need:

Dual Command Wonder -- allows ships to perform 2 actions per turn (but cannot Fire twice)
Hyperlauncher Wonder -- allows your fighters full movement when launched

Upgrade as you normally would, engines, armor, shields, primary weapon.  Get more ships, 5 or 6 is a good strong fleet.  Then, get 2 or more fighters on every ship.

Here is why 1 starfight is not good --> If you turn is to move ships up, and launch a fighter from each, opponent can move up, and destroy them easily.  So nothing is gained, your fighters are dead, effectively a waste of your energy on that upgrade, right?

However, with the Dual Command Wonder, you can launch two fighters.  So even if half of them are destroyed, you are now up the other half on the enemy. If you have 4 fighters per ship, you can do that again next turn.  The Swarm is an achievement, and its a very real thing.  Make sure to science upgrade fighters 2 or 3 times for the random modules on them.  Even on hard, I had Fighters that could take 2 or 3 hits from enemy ships.  You can also use the Hyperlaunch to get a full move out of the fighters, and hit them, before they are destroyed, even if you dont have the dual command wonder.  Dual Command Wonder also applies to your Fighters, though all they can do is double impulse, or fire+impulse.

The rest of how to win" is upgrade sensibly from the bottom up
recommended: upgrade it first.  Get the most for your money.  BE SURE to get every planet a WARP NEXUS.  This will allow you to be able to protect all of your planets from any of your other planets.  You will be able to move between them without crew exhaustion.\n\nA note on torpedoes

reviewText:
Horrible game is horribly broken

I am rather dissapointed with this game. It is a nice idea but poorly implemented. Feels much more like a prerelease than a fully finished game from Sid - and I have been a great admirer of his for many decades!

Easy enough to pick up and play - the game comes without any kind of guide or tutorial.
Many achievements are not working - despite fullfilling described conditions, they do not activate.
Graphics could be a little more interesting. There are only 3 ship graphs for the player. Upgrading your ships does not change them in any way - only in their description.
The different starting characters and affinities do not really make the game play vastly different.
It is rather difficult to determine during missions where and when what ship will be able to move and shoot, which takes away greatly from tactical play and makes it too much about brawn rather than brain.
Missions while interesting almost always come down to the same boring tactics, which when mastered leave nothing to the imagination.
The calculations of success of missions are way off.
Diplomatic Negotiations are rather bizzare and often end up with player unable to tell what was concluded or how to improve matters.
Play in Starships button in Beyond Earth while present is permentantly greyed out.
A lot of the achievements don't work....

Makes one wonder - what sort of testing went on before this pre-alpha was pumped out on Steam as a finished result".

End result - I just hope Modders have enough to work with here so that they can turn this title into what it ought to have been!"
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have seen the mixed reviews and I too have mixed feelings.

Is the game fun - Yes
Is the game stable - Yes
Is the game replayable - Yes

That said, it feels like a work in progess.  The interface could be much, much, much better.  Also there is a significant lack of options.  Other than adjusting sound, that is it.  If there is an option to save every x number of turns, I couldn't find it.  For a game with Sid Meier's name on it, this is disappointing.  Seems like a good idea that was rushed out without all of the finishing touches that one would expect.  I still have to recommend it as it is fun, just hope the deveopers finish the game.

reviewText: 20 Mar 2015 - Wow, this feels like it should still be in Early Release.  This would fit better as a mod for Beyond Earth.  Map scrolling is horrible; either too little or too much.  No tutorial, though most things are easy enough to figure out.  No exit button.  No video options other than full/windowed.  Full screen not completely full screen, task bar still displayed.  I've not tried the cross game option with Beyond Earth yet.\nThis game has potential though, as long as they keep developing it.

reviewText:
After playing an half of an hour, I can say that - at the current stage - it's not worth buying.

A lot of serious issues on the PC version. There is already a guide available how to bypass/workaround the most issues, but some of this won't work for me. For example:

1. Borderless Fullscreen
The game offers a borderless fullscreen mode to play. When you activate it, you still have your Windows taskbar visible. You can workaround this issue by using the tool Borderless Gaming". This really works good.

2. Not able to save the game
In some circumstances you won't be able to save the game: special character in steam user name
recommended: running the wrong executable (i.e. 32bit on 64bit). Most of this is not working for me. I really don't want to change my user name to be able to save in a game. That is weird. They should be able to fix this
hoursPlayed: other games (also Beyond Earth) works fine with saving. Also in Steam Cloud
voteText:
so why?

The workaround described in the link below is not working for me. I need to just bypass the intro by clicking left mouse. If you forget to click
helpfulPercent: game over.\n\nFor me it seems the game had absolutely no testing at all. That would explain the price. My recommendation is currently to wait for a major patch that addresses the most issues. If you still decide to buy this game

reviewText:
I picked up this game on sale recently.  I have only just played around with it a bit but I will say that it is entertaining. There is the inherant boredom factor that comes with each and every Civilization game and this one is absolutely no exception. It has a similar feel and dynamic as Beyond Earth but I do feel....an almost...emptiness while playing it.  It's a fun quick game but I guess I wish it was a little more expansive.

I like the fact that it is a Civ game with a relatively short turn around as sometimes it's nice to just play a quick game and be done with it rather than spending insane amounts of time saving and reloading the same game to infinity.  The lack of multiplayer/co-op is either a massive oversight or a shrewd strategy to market it to the tablet crowd (Android capability please and thank you).

Overall if you like the Civ games, like Beyond Earth, and want something that is not going to take 5 days then this is your game.

reviewText: While I find the game to be entertaining at best, I can easily see why many people are completely underwhelmed and disapointed, especially for a Sid Meier's title. There is little to no story or character to the game, and the core gameplay is heavily lacking. If anything, this would have served as a nice quirky sidegame added to Beyond Earth, but is by no means worth $15, regardless of the fact that it has crash multiple times within the first hour of gameplay.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Having played Sid Meier's Civilization since its first incarnation, I was interested to see how a $15 combat focused spinoff would play out. Starships possesses minimal depth and is far cry from what fans of the series are acustomed to. This is not Civilization, but it also doesn't pretend to be. It is a fun $15 game that focuses almost entirely on fairly rudementry combat mechanics. I have been enjoying the game and I highly encourage people to purchase it. Take a look at some Youtube videos and make your determination from there. What you see is what you get. There are no surprises.\n\nOn a hours played to money spent ratio, Sid Meier's Starships is absolutely worth a buy.

reviewText:
My review of this is simple. Thsi is the description for the game. Taken from right here in this window:

Build and command a fleet of starships and travel between planets as you explore, build, negotiate, and fight to preserve your vision for humanity.


1.) Yes, technically you have to click a button that makes the ships get built". There is 0
hoursPlayed: zilch

votesFunny:
the maps are the size of ... well let me give you an analogy: If space were the size of say the Pacific Ocean than this game is the size of a drop of coffee spilled on the table this morning.
4.) Build - You already said build dipwads and saying it more wont make it any less of a disappointment.
5.) Negotiate.... ummm are you friggin kidding me. The "diplomacy" function in this game is about as in depth as a teenager's world view. Let's break down the options: I like you/I hate you - Let's fight/let's hug.
6.) Fight... HOORAY! finally something that is actually in the game. This game is about the tactics and only the tactics. It is only a $5 game being sold for $10 extra due to having Sid Meier's name on it. But as a $5 dollar game it is decent. It is mindless fun at smashing ships.
7.) And at last we come to "...preserve your vision of humanity" Yeah

reviewText: Sadly this is a large let down to the Sid Meier's IP. Where I was expecting and pre ordered what I thought to be a new type of Beyond Earth with the possiblity of a Horde mode or defence in classic Civilizations fashion, I got what would be good for an IOS or Andriod game. I beat the game within 2 hours on the hardest difficulty. It blended the Battles of Xcom with a hybrid and to be honest really crappy version of Civilization managment into one whole hot mess. While the battles were fun, they were incredibly easy and unsatisfying for a long lasting Civilization fan like myself. For a few dollars this game would be worth it, but sadly that would be charging a high price for it. The 22$ I paid for the pre order was a complete rip off. Overall I cannot recommend this game to nearly anyone, with the exception being the few games who only have an hour or so to spare every once in a while or those who have very low end PCs.

reviewText: I don't know what's going on at Firaxis, but their last two games have really been duds. I love TB Strategy games, and Firaxis was always my go-to for quality, fun TBS games. However, between Beyond Earth and now Starships, I'm beginning to wonder if the devs at Firaxis have thrown in the towel. Even at $15, Starships is woefully inadequate, especially with Sid Meier's name on it. The macro-planetary conquest game requires no thought or strategy to win and the tactical combat micro game requires onlly slight strategic thought - very slight.\n\nI can't help but feel there is only 1/2 a game here. It's a surprising shame this game came from such a great studio. I hope this and BE are not indications of where Firaxis is headed in the long run.

reviewText: Starships is a nice little game, but don't expect the same amount of game-play as in the Civ titles. This game is more sort of an arcade type of game. You have to move fast but smart in order to gain control of as big a chunk of the galaxy as possible, before the other factions have you completely surrounded and the only possibility for expansion is war. This is not a game with hours on hours of micromanaging your planets, establishing interstellar trade routes and high level politics. It's about using your highly customisable star fleet to turn other planets to your side, either by assisting these planets, or by conquering them. A normal play through is about 2-3 hours, and you can easily have the game running while you're doing something else.

reviewText:
I think this is an excellent game for $15.
If you enjoy sci-fi and strategy games, I encourage you to give this game a try. There are a fair amount of negative reviews out there, and they share valid concerns, but I believe they all had expectations that would apply to a full on AAA title. Unfortunately the people who enjoy the game most likely are busy playing the game instead of posting positive reviews.

Belly achers love telling people about their butthurt.

Do your research online before you buy the game, and if you like what you see, you won't regret spending the $15. It's a tactical combat game for starships, with a small portion of Planetary resource collection. Build a fleet of 8 ships or less. Research tech that improves your combat performance. Colonize planets to gain additional resources every turn to improve your fleet.

GOOD STUFF!!

reviewText:
It's a fun little game, bringing more tactical gameplay into the civ universe, but keeping enough of the strategy to let you know it's a Sid Meier game. I'm very hopeful that cross connectivity takes off in a big way, well done to Firaxis, 2K, and everyone involved for taking the plunge with it here.
It feels like a mobile/tablet game that's also been released on the PC, and so some will find the price a little steep - but if it's a mobile game, it's a HUGE and complex one with a surprising amount of depth and diverse viable strategies to experiment with.
It does have some technical issues, for me it crashes sometimes if I try to move the camera below the plane of the map, but has thus far always reloaded without losing any progress.
I recommend it for fans of Beyond Earth, and I think it's worth picking up on sale for anyone else who likes the concept.

reviewText: Despite all the negative reviews out here, I've got to give this one a thumbs up.  Simple and fun turn based strategy gameplay in space.  Game works fine for me, no technical issues.  So, based upon those criteria, it's a good little game!\nOnly down side is that it is NOT worth more than $5-10 at most.
