reviewText:
Sid Meier's Starships is a classic 4x strategy game, that plays very cleanly, and is very well thought out.  The first thing this game reminds me of is the old Master of Orion series.  It's planetary checkers with a touch of management thrown in.  With starships there is also tactical combat, which is where the player spends the majority of time.  That's fine because this phase of the game is also well balanced.

I sometimes shy away from starting up a Civilization game (been a fan of the series since it's inception) just because I don't always have 3 days to spend to play through my own space epic opera.  Starships has just the right amount of story, drama, combat and fluff to keep me hooked, but I can finish a game in a couple of hours.

By fluff I mean this game has components that draw you into the story.  Each planet has a personality, and each empire mirrors what it's planets produce.  Because you are limited to a single fleet, you become very familiar with which ship has which capabilities, and they become a team you care about.  I find that the intro, the voice acting throughout, and the score really add to the immersion.

While this game does remind me of MOO, I think many improvements in gameplay have been included, such that instead of making this the most complex simulation possible, its actually the most balanced and fun to play one that I've seen.  A single fleet at first seemed like a limitation, but it really only limits how long your turn can last, which means the game progresses quickly and smoothly.  Tehcnology tree is very streamlines, but it just makes it very clear that you need to spend your research points wisely.  Planet management includes one wonder option for some planets, and a standard set of upgrades for everyone.  You choose very quickly how to customize each planet, which for me, means you speed up gameplay.

Tactical combat benefits from slick, randomly generated systems, almost always with a plethora of asteroids to hide behind and navigate through.  Along with each combat, you are usually running a mission of sometype for the local planet, which helps give a purpose to the battle.  There is almost a rock paper scissors between beefy slow dreadnaughts, fast fighters, long range lasers, etc. that combined with random terrain and mission objectives works really well to deliver a unique and changing play environment, while still keeping it familiar with your fleet.  You can customze your ships entirely (at a resource cost of course) so you can build out what you need to defeat a particular foe, or try to hold the upper hand with your technology and wonder advantages.

Overall I'd say Sid Meier's Starships is a great, fast paced, space epic that you don't need a whole weekend to get through.

reviewText: I don't know what's going on at Firaxis, but their last two games have really been duds. I love TB Strategy games, and Firaxis was always my go-to for quality, fun TBS games. However, between Beyond Earth and now Starships, I'm beginning to wonder if the devs at Firaxis have thrown in the towel. Even at $15, Starships is woefully inadequate, especially with Sid Meier's name on it. The macro-planetary conquest game requires no thought or strategy to win and the tactical combat micro game requires onlly slight strategic thought - very slight.\n\nI can't help but feel there is only 1/2 a game here. It's a surprising shame this game came from such a great studio. I hope this and BE are not indications of where Firaxis is headed in the long run.

reviewText:
While I recomend Starships, I also give fair warning. This is NOT something you would expect from a Sid Meier's game.
I do enjoy playing it, but I also see the short playability of it. Other games from Sid Meier's I can waste many days worth of hours playing. However, after playing this for only a handful of hours, it is already becoming a bit stale.
The technical and tutorial issues expressed in other reviews are (as of this writing) are true and in many ways annoying. They do not greatly effect the overall experience though. That is, to me, probably the saddest part of the whole thing. The game is so shallow that even though there are some fairly glaring issues, they do not greatly affect the game. Were they all fixed this instant, it would hardly be noticable in the end. For example, the victory conditions only affecting the player and not the AI. It cuts the game a bit short unexpectedly, but the game play for the most part would be the same.
So yes I recomend Starships as it is. The price was reflective of its small stature of a game so it was worth it in my opinion. Try to suspend your disbelief in reguards to its being a Sid Meier's game, or try your best to completely forget it. If you can do either of those thigs you should be fine. Otherwise I suggest seeking professional help from either a psychologist or your local micro brewery.
It is at this point I would like to direct my words at Sid Meier and Faraxis ... please, oh please, redo this game in the grand history and style of every other Sid Meier's game made. It has potential and good ideas backing it in story and hope. Please do those things justice and meet the high bar you set for yourselves. Price it as you did Beyond Earth and Civ 5 and if it be as they are in grand stature and bredth, I would happily give my coin in trade.

reviewText:
The game is very simple. It took me about 1 minute to get the basics down, learned a few new things along the way, and ultimately cruised to victory on the moderate difficulty level.

Having said that... I had fun. I felt that there wasn't much depth to some elements, namely resources and tech. The diplomacy is minimal and wasn't worth pursuing in my playthrough. The combat was enjoyable and the missions seemed varied enough. The wonders work better than you'd expect, though are so expensive that many aren't worth getting.

Great game if you've got a few hours to spare. I'd definitely recommend picking it up on your tablet for plane/car trips.
Not so great if you're hoping to burn the midnight oil in a long, detailed game similar to Civ.

reviewText:
I think this is an excellent game for $15.
If you enjoy sci-fi and strategy games, I encourage you to give this game a try. There are a fair amount of negative reviews out there, and they share valid concerns, but I believe they all had expectations that would apply to a full on AAA title. Unfortunately the people who enjoy the game most likely are busy playing the game instead of posting positive reviews.

Belly achers love telling people about their butthurt.

Do your research online before you buy the game, and if you like what you see, you won't regret spending the $15. It's a tactical combat game for starships, with a small portion of Planetary resource collection. Build a fleet of 8 ships or less. Research tech that improves your combat performance. Colonize planets to gain additional resources every turn to improve your fleet.

GOOD STUFF!!

reviewText:
It's a fun little game, bringing more tactical gameplay into the civ universe, but keeping enough of the strategy to let you know it's a Sid Meier game. I'm very hopeful that cross connectivity takes off in a big way, well done to Firaxis, 2K, and everyone involved for taking the plunge with it here.
It feels like a mobile/tablet game that's also been released on the PC, and so some will find the price a little steep - but if it's a mobile game, it's a HUGE and complex one with a surprising amount of depth and diverse viable strategies to experiment with.
It does have some technical issues, for me it crashes sometimes if I try to move the camera below the plane of the map, but has thus far always reloaded without losing any progress.
I recommend it for fans of Beyond Earth, and I think it's worth picking up on sale for anyone else who likes the concept.

reviewText:
Bias warning: I love strategy games, and so I am more inclined to view them positively.

Starships is a good game for the price. Its based on an extremely simple mechanic with a few randomly shifting variables that try to introduce some variety (things like: environmental effects, mission types, etc) that can alter the gameplay on a per-mission basis. Its based on the Beyond Earth universe, and will actually read characters out of your Beyond Earth savegames. The whole game is squarely focused around Starships (hence the name), and everything else is built around giving starships modifiers and abilities to make them more effective. Its a turn based game, with the only reflect mecahnic being the push button detonation" ability on the torpedos.

The Good Fun
recommended:
addictive gameplay ("one more turn!")
Good pure-strategy game (no dice rolls! Whoooo!)
2D representation of 3D space much more useful than attempts to cobble together 3D UIs (I've never seen this work in a way that was felt native and intuitive)
Extends Beyond Earth for those of us who wanted a bit more
Interesting and new dynamic that we've never seen before (TBS with one "fleet"
hoursPlayed: the torpedo mechanic
voteText:
and others). Could spawn new genres
Game length is good for the size of the concept
The elephant in the room: THE PRICE
The Bad Graphics are lackluster. Its clear that this was made being co-developed for mobile.
Despite attempts to add variety to the core game mechanic via environmental changes

votesHelpful: maybe they could have tried to make it work

Vaunted unit customization is limited to "you have N of a thing"
Numerous non-game-breaking bugs. Defeated fleets hang out in the corner of the game map. In diplomacy

reviewText: Starships is a decent title. If you think of Starships as a fun way to burn a couple hours at an airport, you'll probably view it as favorably as I do.

reviewText:
This is not Civilization, Or Galactic Civilizato, Or Masters of Orion.
You are an admiral. You lead your ships, run missions, earn influence of the worlds you visit.

The emphasis is tactical. Expect to spend a lot of time on a battlemap.
Lasers are long range but planets block them and asteroids can block them or reduce damage. (There are a LOT of asteroids on a map!)

Plasma weapons do more damge but are shorter range.

Torpedoes are area affect and can pass through asteroids. Great for flushing quarry from a spot thats too good.

You also have fighters, stealth systems, shields...

You will build wonders, improvements and the like, but as I said, the emphasis is tactical or these elements are lighter fare.

The game can be small and played quickly. The hardest victory conditions on the biggest map is about a six hour affair on easy level.

A lot of people complain about the small window but playing full screen is trivial. There is a fullscreen button you can click in the menues...you can also simply maximize the window.

A lot of people want a longer game...I recommend if you feel that way you play a Population" victory
date: or "Domination" if you want an even longer game.\n\nIn the end there is not as much here as there is in Civ or Beyond Earth. Then again
recommended:
look at the price tag...

On a 1 to 10 I give it an 8.2

It's entertaining."

reviewText:
================================================================

NB: Steam's review upvote/downvote is meant to be used by mature and objective readers to indicate whether a review was helpful. Instead, many readers use it only to indicate whether they agree/disagree with the review. What that means is if a reader likes the game but dislikes a negative review of the game, they will downvote the review for that reason alone. People do this to make it harder for reviews they disagree with to appear on Steam and therefore harder for you to make an informed decision.

So a wise person will seek out both positive and negative reviews not based on upvote/downvote status.

================================================================

Unlike some other reviewers, I didn't come into this game with any expectations and assumptions - I like to limit the potential for dissapointment.

Pros: a simple galactic civ game for people like me who want to like the big 4x turn-based games but hate all the micromanagement and awkward UIs. Combat is fun. Easy to learn. Perfect for short gaming sessions.

Cons: cartoonish artwork. Little to no control over what your ships look like. Too simple.

All in all, a very fun little game and well worth the small price tag.

If you want to see some late game action, go here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pLqZfvZy9xo

reviewText: This game is quite interesting for the first few run throughs, but it totally lacks the addictive elements of Civ5 and Beyond Earth. The graphics and interface are much more basic than I was expecting, and not in a good way. It's not particularly challenging, even on the higher difficulty settings, there's not really much scope for changing your strategy, and the fact that you can't continue the game once another player has achieved a victory, the way you can in Civ5, is really irritating. Could be a good game but it feels much more like one made specifically for tablets or even smartphones than for PC gamers, or possibly a beta for a much bigger and more immersive game. Not really worth the cost.

reviewText:
================================================================

NB: Steam's review upvote/downvote is meant to be used by mature and objective readers to indicate whether a review was helpful. Instead, many readers use it only to indicate whether they agree/disagree with the review. What that means is if a reader likes the game but dislikes a negative review of the game, they will downvote the review for that reason alone. People do this to make it harder for reviews they disagree with to appear on Steam and therefore harder for you to make an informed decision.

So a wise person will seek out both positive and negative reviews not based on upvote/downvote status.

================================================================

Unlike some other reviewers, I didn't come into this game with any expectations and assumptions - I like to limit the potential for dissapointment.

Pros: a simple galactic civ game for people like me who want to like the big 4x turn-based games but hate all the micromanagement and awkward UIs. Combat is fun. Easy to learn. Perfect for short gaming sessions.

Cons: cartoonish artwork. Little to no control over what your ships look like. Too simple.

All in all, a very fun little game and well worth the small price tag.

If you want to see some late game action, go here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pLqZfvZy9xo

reviewText: This game is quite interesting for the first few run throughs, but it totally lacks the addictive elements of Civ5 and Beyond Earth. The graphics and interface are much more basic than I was expecting, and not in a good way. It's not particularly challenging, even on the higher difficulty settings, there's not really much scope for changing your strategy, and the fact that you can't continue the game once another player has achieved a victory, the way you can in Civ5, is really irritating. Could be a good game but it feels much more like one made specifically for tablets or even smartphones than for PC gamers, or possibly a beta for a much bigger and more immersive game. Not really worth the cost.

reviewText:
I really wish i could recommend this game, i really do... This is supposed to be my favorite type of game. Maybe i had too much expectations for it, some kind of ''tactical 4x'' like if xcom and endless space had a baby but the gameplay is way too redundant and shallow to play more than a few hours.

It could have been a lot nicer if it wasn't all about the combats phase and more about managing your empire and diplomacy which, by the way, is a joke : you can either be at peace or at war with other empires and nothing else. No spying, no trade, no borders tensions, nothing ! Oh and did i mention that science and warfare are jokes as well ? it kind of reminds me some browser game like ogame or some cheap smartphone game.

I liked the drawing that are used as cut scenes though.

Sorry devs, your game... sucks. I guess that's what happens when you don't have enough time to give all the love it deserve...

reviewText:
First let me say that I came into this game knowing nothing about it but being a huge Civ's and Ace Patrol fan.

This game is similar to Ace Patrol in its combat, though you dont have pitching and height mechanics, it feels the same.  Its out of combat screen however is a simplified 4x map.

You get one fleet, it travels between planets and does missions to gain trade routes (similar to Spore) if the planet is owned by someone else you go to combat with their fleet, simple enough.  The planets can have their facilities upgraded and more cities added, each choice gives you more resources per turn.

Your fleet can be upgraded, better weapons, shields, armor or change to new tactics like cloaking, torpedos, and launced fighters.  You will be able to do all of these eventually, you wont lock yourself out of any design, though you do have to balance your ships components with speed.

The tech tree is tiny unfortunatly, the prices scale quickly so you will be sitting there a while if you're trying for a tech victory, its small but not short.

The victories are done poorly, instead of a civ style advanced setup option you get to pick between all the victories (Population, Science, Domination, and Wonders) and any single one of them.  In practice the All games tend to end in domination or population quickly, wonder victories can come out of no where and science takes too long.

The starting options are a bit generic as well, each civilization has a unique bonus and each captain has a bonus, the captains are the same reguardless of race however their portrait gets a slight change.  Some say that its lazy I think its cute.

It has a pretty cool integration with Beyond Earth, you can earn starting choices for Starships and Beyond Earth by playing the other game.  For example because of some Starships gameplay I get a new starting option in Beyond Earth as well as a map for an achievement and for playing Beyond Earth I can choose hybrid civs with double the bonus abilities in Starships.

Over all I hope it gets polished because it does have short falls.  Its not a bad game, its pretty fun in fact, and the cross integration with BE is something I can't support enough I love it.
voteText: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The game runs well and it looks good graphically. it is really nothing like CIV BE whatsoever, there is a bit of resourse management and research, but all the research is for your ships. Really everything is about your ships, you fly around and do missions for other planets. There are a few different missions you can do, each giving a differnt reward, money, research etc... you have to do a few missions per planet to gain enough influence for them to join your empire. It gets a little old fast doing the missions, depending on what the mission is you may need to outfit your ship(s) diffently. Some missions you only get to use one of your ships, and in others you need to avoid combat more than provoke it. Once a planet has been claimed by an opponent the battles become slightly more interesting and it becomes more about the ship battling and tactics than the missions, which felt like playing minigames. In youre planets you are able to build cities and planet upgrades, the cities boost overall income and the upgrades range in different things like planetary defences and the like. you're crew will allow you to travel a certain distance per turn, limiting how much you can do, without certain upgrades traveling between your cities can eat up you're turns. I did not find much use in the missle weapons, though they seem interesting they are fairly useless, atleast in my experience. The missles travel a certain distance per turn, you may choose to detonate them at any time during their travel but i didnt find the range to be worth it, i rarely used them but when i did i used them to cut the enemy off. The combat zones are riddled with space debris and asteroids, both allowing cover and hindering or dissalowing fire comletely. they are filled with narrow passages between asteroids that open and close (for some reason) between turns. Overall, due to its lower price tag i will recomend it, but it would be best to get it on sale if at all. The game gets old fast but it should be fun to go back to every now and again. I give it a 5/10 and hope that they update it and dont charge for micro-expansions.

reviewText:
I have seen quite a few negative reviews on here, and that really surprised me. This game is pretty brilliant for what it is, a 15 dollar game. It is sorta simple on many levels. That being said, there are enough variables to keep it fresh as long as you want it to be. I have about 9 full play throughs so far, and am still playing.

Some of the achievements seem a bit difficult to trigger. The pirate one for example. I have taken the Pirate home world multiple times in games and still no cheevo. I see people have it though, so I am sure the game isn't broken. I am doing something wrong is all. I did manage to get my home world attacked on the second round of the game and lost, so that cheevo didn't happen. :D

I have to say, it delivers exactly what Sid promised. Nothing more, nothing less.  I am hoping that as time goes on, more content, multiplayer options and such are added. With the 15 dollar price point, I would gladly purchase DLC to keep Sid employed. He has kept me entertained since 1982 after all. Only seems fair.

TL;DR - Buy it. It is 15 bucks that will be well spent.

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Starships is a very light 4X game. You control star systems and move a fleet of upgradable ships around while competing with the AI doing the same. There are four victory conditions (wonders, population, domination, science). Once two fleets meet or you attack an enemy planet the game switches to 2D hex-based, turn-based tactical combat.  You can attack enemy ships with lasers, torpedoes, plasma guns and fighters. There is a simple stealth option and there are obstacles on each map that can be used as a cover for ships.
On the strategy map you can also upgrade your ships, buy new ships (but you can only have one fleet at a time) upgrade your planets, build cities and wonders and improve your tech level (there are different resources for each task).

Now before I start on listing my personal pros and cons I'd like to get this out of the way first: The game is in no way comparable to great 4X games like Master of Orion, Endless Legends and so on. It's a simply game, designed for tablets much like Sid Meier's Ace Patrol. If you want a large, complex 4X-game then don't buy Sid Meier's Starships. Starships is much more of a let's play something for 20 minutes" game than anything else.

That said
date:
here are my pros and cons:

Pros:
- Good Interface
- Fast paced combat and strategy map
- Fames don't take long to complete (I finished an epic game on normal in 2 hours)
- Enjoyable if simple turn based combat
- I really
recommended:
really like the artwork in the game.

Cons:
- Diplomacy is useless.
- The options are a joke (for example: Fullscreen mode only works on my system if I hide the task bar. If the task bar is   not hidden it's always visible and the game doesn't go fullscreen)
- The different factions really don't play all that different. And choosing an affinity is mostly about what color you like
- The turn based combat is simple. It's really easy to find a strategy that works for you (I enjoy mass torpedo spam for example) and stick with it. Once you have upgraded the first two ships to the max level there is almost nothing that can stop you)

Conclusion:
I recommend buying the game if you look for something to just play for a couple of minutes and if you enjoy simple turn based combat.

I do not recommend buying the game if you look for something complex or challenging."

reviewText: It is, as far as I know, a brand new subgenre of 4X games. Your singular fleet and its advancements are your sole concerns and unlike other 4X games you spend most of your time fighting based on a very fun and surprisingly deep combat system.  The addition of wonders" and battle cards makes a lot of difference on the hexagonal battlefield riddled with environmental obstacles and effects that are a lot more significant than in any other 4x games.\n\nHowever
date: people hoping to find complexity of a $40+ title are going to be dissapointed. There's been some debate if the game is worth the current price ($15) and my personal subjective oppinion is that a game with this degree of polish despite the lack of $20-$50 content such as "next gen graphics"
recommended: "unique races". "diplomacy". "religion" or "multiplayer" is well within it's 10-15$ range. It's a tactical combat game with 4X elements - not the other way around."

reviewText:
If you're looking for a Grand Space Epic, this isn't it. If you're looking for a quick, clever space battle RTS, this is a good choice. The fact that it has the familiar lineage of Civ makes it all the more enjoyable.

Graphics could be a little more elaborate, and I get why you're only allowed one fleet, but it can be annoying to have to run back and forth. A few ships for defense would sure be nice.

Good use of the (very limited) tech tree to enhance battle tactics. Very logical and everything distilled to its essence.

reviewText:
If you set your workers to automate or always put someone in charge of running your cities then this is a game for you.

Sid Meier is known for giving you the ability to micro manage everything. So understandably this game is really making people angry because it's not that kind of game. It has a lot of offer but doesn't take anything too far. For me, a person who likes to plan my attacks and be able to led my forces into battle while not having to go back to every planet, city, etc. I own each turn to make sure it's on the right path, this game is a ton of fun and more challenging than I expected. Sure it's not going to be a game you sink 200+ hours in but it's also not a day consuming march of tears and cheers that gets saved at 2am and never finished.

reviewText: Most of the reviews for this game are pretty poor and to an extent I can understand why. The gameplay is very simple, it isn't groundbreaking in any regard, the production values are average and even the largest map option can be completed very quickly. Don't buy this game expecting it to be Civilization in space or to be a AAA game or you will be disappointed.\n\nFor me this game is great, it's straight forward fun. It's got the same 'one more turn' appeal that Civilization and XCOM have but given that you can complete a game so quickly it is great for if you just want a quick game of something that you can see through to completion.

reviewText:
Strategy thick starship tactics with adrenaline stimulating tense action. Sid Meier's Starships has a incredible unique mix of elements which come together to create exciting suspenseful battles where fast skillful maneuvering to get in just the right sweet strategic position to fire hull shattering hits upon enemy ships then take off engines blasting behind a planetoid or some asteroids before the enemy can counter attack with devastating effect.

Sid Meier's Starships is the first turn based strategy game i may have ever played which felt fast and furious giving a fps shooter adrenaline rush in of all things a turn based strategy game. It was like playing a table top game with friends but against the ai instead.

Graphics have an old school style to them with a great hex map setup with many environmental variables which can mean the difference between life and death depending on how the player utilizes them to their advantage. Weapons have varying ranges and levels of damage with lasers delivering heavy damage from long range while missile weapons like torpedoes are usually slower with a chance of being avoided if one keeps their attacks fluid and mobile. Stay still and you are probably dead like a sitting duck.

You can buy and upgrade ships to become lethal space faring dreadnoughts of unstoppable destruction. In my first game as i was learning my way around i built two heavily armored ships which were able to take on a group of five enemy ships and fighters for awhile letting loosing terrifying barrages of laser fire into their midst before eventually being defeated with blood curdling audio and visuals during their horrific demise. Talk about getting lost in fun abandonment as if watching a starship battle in a episode of STAR TREK.

Planets you rule are used to get resources and do research to improve your battle prowess and keep your empire going. You will come across other leaders which you form alliances with or who will form alliances against you as everyone does their best to thrive and survive in the infinite vastness of the universe.

Audio and music is excellent bringing home those peaceful space traveling moments only to be shattered by battle inspiring man your weapons music. Voice acting is quite good and am glad to say the female robotic voice of the computer is quite informative and comforting :)

Cons-
Ouch that user interface is not intuitive to put it mildly. During my first game session i couldnt even figure out how to move my ships until i watched a Youtube video by AngryJoe who was doing a first impressions playthrough. Also i have to hover my mouse pointer above my selection when giving a command otherwise i will choose the command below it or none at all.

If your into fast paced turn based combat with plenty of thrilling tension while not expecting a CIVILIZATION BEYOND EARTH experiance then Sid Meier's STARSHIPS is the game for you. Just enjoy it for what it is and you will find its more then worth the few credits you have paid to enter the star ship bridge for.
voteText: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First let me just say that Starships is a decent and fun game to play for the low price it costs. The game has really good graphics which is what I have come to expect from Sid Meier's games.  The loading time into the game is a lot quicker than the standard civilization games which I also liked.   To me it was like a board game based in space using the basics from the civilization games. Their is some micro managing you can do in Starships but its not overwhelming like it is in other civ games.  I also like that the planetary jump gates allow you to keep moving your fleet without adding fatigue.  I played a game on the easy  level and had the largest map. I still finished it in under 6 hours, which is kind of cool considering their is no multiplayer option for starfighter.
I do feel their is a few drawbacks that I feel could have been improved upon.  The game seems to randomly shut itself down, which isnt that huge of deal considering it has the continue option when loading back into the game. The saves could use some work. I dont know where it saves it, I am assuming it is in some kind of cloud. I was unable to locate the save file directory on my computer for starships. I prefere to be able to manually delete my own save files without having to fire the game up first to do it. So if Starships is updated I would like to see a save file directory on my pc.  The in game maps do not seem to be that big in my opinion. The tool tips could use improving, it kept wanting me to develop my ion  engines even after i increased the tech and took ship engines to 5.  Finally their is no multiplayer option with starships. I think starships would be a lot more funner if i could have the option to play with my friends against the Ai's or each other.

The one thing I dont understand is why only 1 fleet? Im guessing that is because the fleet is used for visiting the planets and attacking while the planetary defence's are for when you get attacked.

So over all the game is fun to play if you dont mind playing it by yourself against the computer.  For the price of $15 I paid for it, I feel it was worth it and recomend it to play.

reviewText: I'll echo what others have said:  If you're expecting Beyond Earth II, or Civilization VI - that isn't this.  It's a light game with some 4x elements and some exploration elements.  There's a little colonial management, a decent tactical simulator (if you don't mind turn/hex based), and a variety of victory conditions.\n\nAnd that's really it.  It's true there is no tutorial, but there are a few help screens and that's all you need.  This is simple, light fare...and it does what it sets out to do.  In my first game I was one turn ('mission') away from a science victory, when one of my opponents conquered another one and was slightly over 50% population.  It takes 51 to win however and I managed to eke it out.  For all the lightness of the game, it was  a fun and entertaining game that took about 4 hours start to finish.
voteText: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
To some people it is a good game, and to others it is a bad one.

I, myself, find that it is a rather good game to spend a couple of hours on battling your way though astroids and fleets of starships launching torpedos and scrambling fighters.
I think I find this game entertaining mainly because of the battles. In most, if not all, of my Civilization games I end up being the passive diplomat whether in history or Beyond Earth but because of focus on battles and fighting in this game I can enjoy the otherside of conquest that I fail to meet under the white dove or neutrality.

However the game does come with a few flaws to those expecting a huge 'triple-A' title. Each game is short and missons do get repetative if you replay each game on the same difficulty. I believe there are a few minor bugs in the diplomacy and which leaders relaliate too who owns what planet (which is not fully governed by a single 'Empire')

However if you are looking for a quick Hex-based spaceship battle game you are in luck!
Otherwise just give this one a pass; There is no reason to moan at the developers for creating a game that some people like and some people just want to cry about like two year olds with tantrums.
voteText: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Strategy-Lite; 4x-Lite. More filler game than mainstay. A little lacking in the kind of depth one finds in GalCiv or Total War. All of these things are true.

And you know what? That is okay with me.

Because Starships is not trying to be any of those games. This is a lite weight affair with ample choices and sufficient depth for the game it is trying to be. And that is a game wherein a player can wile away a few hours enjoying excellent theme and some lightweight, enjoyable turn based combat.

If you're looking for the next GalCiv or Endless Space, no, this is not your game. If on the other hand you prefer your strategy lighter and simpler and a little less overwhelming - or you just want to kill a few hours with some lite fun - then give this a look. Especially if you enjoyed Ace Patrol, as this really is quite a good game in its own right.

reviewText:
Game doesn't run the OpenAL installer it needs to run. It wasn't running on my PC until I ran the OpenAL installer and I've installed the previous version of OpenAL many times.

Game doesn't have proper fullscreen, only fullscreen on desktop, so taskbar shows. This is absolutely inexcusable because it is stupidly easy to code full screen unless the library you're using doesn't support it in which case don't use such a stupid library.

No ability to redefine keys. Amateur.

Game crashes every time after you exit to desktop.

Game is locked to 30 fps. This is absolutely inexcusable because it is stupidly easy to fix.

No mouse scrolling on edge of screen, instead it's left click and drag.

Game was obviously coded with mobile as least common denominator.

See all these negative points?! And I haven't even started playing the game yet.

update:
The actual game is fun. It's basically a board game where you have your little band of ships and you go around between planets doing missions to get influence. The missions are tactical turn-based battles. It's not as deep as a proper 4X game but it is fun.

reviewText: Not a game that hardcore fans of Civ seem to like from the comments.  At $15, my expectations weren't high, despite the research that I had done prior (once I saw the price point I knew I had to shift my priorities or I would end up disappointed).  Some will generally not like the touch-friendly control, however it still works for the game as it is designed, and it still provides enough challenge to play through with different characters and affinities.  It seems as this is more of a sequel to beyond earth that wasn't meant to be a full fleged game - and in its own right it owns that.  In its current incarnation it could be cross platformed across all Win 10 devices once the OS is released at the end of the year, as the hardware on most if not all computers won't be taxed by the graphics engine used in the game.\n\nIf you're a hardcore civ fan avoid it - however if you want to give a slightly more casual incarnation of the Civ universe, this is it.

reviewText:
This is a great game, lots of fun!

It's NOT a standard CIV game... it's a light strategy, with a light tactical  combat system that has surprising depth (a lighter version of XCom).

The fleet combat (the main part of the game) is very fun, with many tactical options depending on your choices with wonders having a big impact on your play style. Tactics I've tried:
A fast fleet with powerful short range weapons
A fleet with lots of torpedoes and long range lasers
A slow carrier fleet
A small fleet with super ships (basically putting all your money in to 1 or 2 ships) think Mega Battleships
A fleet with 2 'tanks' and the remainder light long range ships
A fleet with 2 'tanks' and several carriersThese are just the ones I've tried so far... there are many possibilities, and you will have to responded the enemy fleet composition.

In general you'll be spending your time:
Placing facilities on planets to improve output for a single resource or getting a fleet bonus (via wonders)
Placing cities that will increase output for all resource types on that planet
Acquiring technology for your ships
Customisng ships (they change appearance based on your choices)
Expanding your empire, by doing favours for planets or attacking other players
And a lot of fighting (the game is all about fleet combat)
Everything in the game is purchased, so there is no building or researching, you simply decide what you want and buy it with the correct resource. There are 5 resources generated by planets and they can also be traded or purchased with credits.

So if you are expecting an in depth 4x space game you are going to be very upset (seriously read / view the marketing material).

When you don't want to commit to a 20-60+ hour 4x space game this is an easy choice with games lasting for 30 mins to 2 hours.
I can see myself playing this for many more hours.

For some other opinions, have a look at:

Eurogamer review [www.eurogamer.net]
Polygon preview

PS: I am confused why there seems to be so many ppl on here who expected Sid Meier's Gal Civ or Master of Orion, I found all marketing and previews very clear as to the aim / tone of the game!

reviewText: Sid Meier's Starships......an out of the blue title that generated a lot of anticipation and more than a little wonder at what the package would bring. Now it's here and while it's not socks from Grandma at Christmas, it's not quite the game you were hoping for either. Good but not great, worth the price but perhaps unworthy of the legend that is Sid Meier.\n\nThis is not a 4x game nor was it ever advertised as such. It's more Ace Patrol than Civ, something fun that won't require huge chunks of your life to complete but something you can come back and jump right in to. While lacking in chrome, this game retains Sid's famous one more turn" quality. The game is fun to play and the deeper you get into it the more strategies become apparent. I started it

reviewText:
So, Starships...

What is it? The background is a basic two-dimensional map as in, say, Galciv 2 or even Moo2. You have one space fleet, which you can add ships to. You can also upgrade the ships both by adding components and improving your technology (the 'science tree'). Wiith your fleet you take on missions with Star-Trekky names, to gain influence over other star systems and eventually add them to your empire. You can also attack the AI players, who are the same cast that appeared in Civ:BE.

You receive resources ech turn from your controlled systems; the systems can be upgraded by spending food to increase population, or metals to upgrade production. You can also build nexuses to get around more conveniently, and megabots to defend your systems. So there is an element of 'empire management', too.

Victory can come through: science, population, domination, wonders; however, you cannot force the AI players to select a particular choice, so you need to keep an eye on their progress as well as your own.

Game length is short; even spinning it out, you can finish a game with top-level ships (say, 6 levels of whatever components you like best) in 2-3 hours, and that would be a game you could have won much sooner if you'd chosen to do so.

The main focus of the game is on starship combat, for at least two reasons: first, because that is the only way to expand, and second, because every player/AI battle at a home planet is sudden death for the empire being attacked; if it loses, all its systems immediately join the winner.

So, how good is combat? Well, between equally balanced fleets (ignore what the game tells you about your 'prospects of victory) the AI will give you a challenge. Of course, if you have much better (fast, stealthed) ships, then the AI can be made to look foolish. But then, if the tables were turned, the reverse would probably be true also.

Price: there are a number of good older games for the same price or less, but for a brand-new game, this didn't strike me as unreasonably expensive.

Reservations

1.	The game can end suddenly and unexpectedly if you or another player acquires seven wonders -  a number that is not scalable. So you can find yourself tactically NOT building wonders or capturing planets that have them. The same happens if two AI opponents decide to combine forces, and it turns out they have 7 wonders between them. It's not obvious to me why '7 wonders' should even be a victory condition, and particularly not such an arbitrary one.

2.	There is the ability to link Starships and Civ:BE via My2k. It is quite fiddly to do (you need to open a My2k account and log on in both games). The reward is that you can take your Civ:BE persona into Starships against the same opponents and play on there. Also, you can obtain rewards (extra missions, more planet types and affinity choices). Having played 214 hours of Civ:BE and obtained nearly all achievements,it does seem like a bit of an imposition to have to jump through the hoops again on the off-chance I may get an Earth-type world, say, in Starships. At least there could be some indication of how to unlock the extras! More seriously, logging onto My2k while playing Civ:BE caused gameplay lag, and also a screen crash of my computer on restart. I believe you should get the bonuses automatically if you already have the achievements in Civ:BE.

Conclusions.

Mostly harmless. This is a perfectly acceptable, 'play over lunch' type of game. It isn't great, and it isn't terrible. It isn't hugely expensive, and it certainly isn't  cheap. It needs more content in terms of missions, and there are a couple of gameplay issues to sort out.

Overall, it's good fun and is a welcome change of pace from those labour-intensive 4x type games that go on for days. Thumbs up.

P.S. Thereis now a guide to the unlockables: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=406708978

reviewText:
See my Welcome to Starships: A Reference Guide for an in-depth overview of the game and its systems.

What you should expect A light-strategy game designed to allow you to do a complete play through in just a few hours. The tactical missions are fairly varied and fun. The strategic layer is very simple. With just a few resources you can upgrade your planets and upgrade your ships. There are some basic technologies you can research with each technology having a direct impact on your ships' effectiveness. All-in-all, a $15 game which isn't trying to hide what it is.

I, for one, appreciate the fact that it's light and quick as I do not have the time to put into a full fledged Civ game most of the time.

What you shouldn't expect It is not Civilization. It is not a 4x strategy game. You will be disappointed if you buy the game expecting that. This is far closer to Ace Patrol (with a dash of XCOM) than it is to any other Sid Meier game.

Watch some gameplay videos. If it looks fun, then you'll probably enjoy it.

reviewText:
A new Civilization in space? Something that expands Civ:BE allowing it to reach the glory it aimed at? Unfortunately, no. Sid M.'s Starships goes in the same direction XCom, franchise revived by Firaxis, did. And it goes much, much further. For those who may not know, the new XCom is an extremely simplified, tainted with tacky graphics ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of the original game. Although, unlike Starships, it's still very enjoyable. But let's not get ahead of ourselves.

What do we get buying SM Starships? Pitifully little. It's a typical tablet/phone game that could be distributed for free if the devs cut down on graphics, basic as it already is.
Tech tree does not exist. Instead, we get several options to improve cerain aspects by a % bonus. Boring.
Pretty much the same can be said about development of planets. Player is just adding numbers and %.
Combat looks like in XCom but is much less intuitive. Will I be able to hit my enemy if i move a little to the right? Will have to see. It's a guessing game, especially when distance grows. Torpedoes and their delayed explosions are a nice touch, even though AI can't handle them a bit. BTW, lasers" in this game act like tomahawk missiles. Curved lasers... Priceless.
Missions are simply boring. All are played on almost identical maps. Only details vary. Special missions
date: ie. hunt a ship or flee
recommended: only pretend to be different.\n\nAnother thing is pacing of the game. I've seen and done everything in 2 hours. Nothing left to explore. After half a dozen turns you've already been everywhere and done everything. What's worse
hoursPlayed: you've also upgraded everything worth upgrading and bought everything worth buying. The biggest killjoy comes from fleet upgrades. Cheap upgrades make you invincible. Spend one turn's income on lasers and bang! You are dealing 1000% more damage!\n\nAll in all

reviewText: I don't normally write reviews for anything, but it has been bothering me how poorly this game has been rated lately.  You can't look at the title and think it's a Sid Meier game, it will take me days if not weeks to beat. This game is short, maybe three to four hours on a good play through.  But thats what I want in this game.  I am a father, while working full time and going to college as well.  Nine times out of ten, I do not have the time to devote to a longer game.  This game is the perfect length in order to get your stratedgy fix in.  While there is some fine tunning that the game needs, it works great and does what you want it to do.  If you are concerned about it being short, go play another game, and do not complain about the price, after all a 15 dollar game will not have the same playability as a 50 dollar Civilization game.

reviewText:
Straight from the Science Officer:
---------------------------
Sid Meier's Starships is the continuation to Beyond Earth. While BE was more focused on 4x empire management, Starships shifts gear to commanding a fleet of interstellar vessels as you run around completing missions in turn-based strategy fashion. In-depth customization of your ships' systems is the center of the game as lasers tear through your hull because you thought having maximum sensors was the smartest idea.

While the tactical map is where you'll be battling, the galactic map is ultimately where you win the war. Here, you'll be competing for influence on various systems against your rivals from BE as you seek to rid the universe of their annoying one-liners. Victory is achieved by eliminating all of your rivals, controlling over half of the galaxy, researching enough technologies to the maximum tier, or spending enough industry to own seven wonders.

Yes Commander"
---------------------------
(+) Well thought out tactical gameplay - Do I stealth this turn? Fire my weapons? Launch torpedoes?  "Oooh let's hide behind this planet and when the enemy comes
date: charge guns blazing"\n\n(+) Great ship customization - With your fleet of ships
recommended: you'll be able to craft each ship to fit your battle plans. You could make a fleet of ships with many engines and long range weapons and kite the enemy or brawlers that hide behind a planet and charge out when the enemy nears. Maybe you'd like to have a stealth carrier that pops out
hoursPlayed: launches some fighters
voteText: and goes back into the void or a sensor ship to detect an enemy fleet that relies on stealth fighters. The options are vast. A bonus kudo goes to the fact the game auto-classes your ship based on its setup. A ship teethed with guns and armor will be labelled as a battleship while a fast ship with high damage would be an assault corvette. It just provides an additional
helpfulPercent: nice immersion feature.\n\n(+) Simplicity - While it can be argued that this is a negative as some people perhaps expected a complex 4x game reminisicent of MOO or Galciv
votesHelpful: Starships is a game focused on ...Starships. The focus isn't on managing a large empire but instead on controlling your fleet and completing missions with that said fleet in order to build your empire.\n\n(+) Missions - There's a decent variety of missions so you won't get too bored until a few playthroughs. While the mission types get similar
votesTotal: the map and the ships in each mission can change.\n\n(+) Price - $15 (in the US) is a great price for a game like this. You'll definitely get hours of gameplay and like most Sid Meier's games
votesFunny: once you figure out the controls
commentsCount: it's hard to pay attention to real-life.\n\n(+) Bridge Visuals - Each bridge depending on which faction (harmony
column16: purity
column17:
supremacy) you picked gets it's own unique bridge. It's a really small thing but it's something that definitely stands out.


"We'll get them next time..."
---------------------------
(-) No Multiplayer - One of the things I was hoping to do was get a nice game going with some friends. The game definitely has unexploited MP potential. A decent size map can be finished with some friends in a day. It's not going to be like playing a MP match of Crusader Kings or EUIV which can last weekends on ends. The AIs only going to be able to be so unique on designing fleets.

(-) One Fleet - Having only one fleet really limits strategic gameplay on the galactic map. There's not going to be any strategy where I can defend one location and fight in another on AI turns. I won't be able to create a fleet for defense and another for attack or specialize one fleet for certain types of missions.

(-) Squishiness of Ships - Hopefully this gets sorted out but ships seem like they are glass cannons no matter how you build them at the moment. Unless you're literally building all armor / shields (which makes that ship pretty useless since it has no weapons)
column18: most ships die in a few hits. Fighters die in one shot from basically anything short of a maximum range pea shooter. This makes the tactical gameplay more arcadey and will hopefully be improved upon in later patches.\n\n(-) Lack of 'One More Turn' - A fundamental Sid Meier's feature. Sometimes you just want to continue but you win
column19: victory
column20:
that's it. This was an easy feature that was just simply and unfortunately overlooked.

(-) Modding Tools - There's a lot of potential for modding a game like this. It's not a stretch to imagine someone trying to recreate a Starfleet or Star Wars based mod if the tools are provided. Some of the best additions that enhance the value of old Civ games were fan-made maps and mods.

"Close Victory"
---------------------------
Overall I'd give this game a 6.5/10. The gameplay is addictive and the tactical battles are in-depth. Ship customization and fleet design is well-developed and serves as the main anchor for this game. Nontheless some pitfalls exists
column21: mainly in the fact that there's no multiplayer in a game that would obviously benefit from having the ability to play a match against your friends. If you're expecting a big 4x game then you might want to stay away but if you want a quick game and you have a love of starships and fleet command then you should definitely pick it up. It's only the price of a dinner and you won't be eating tonight anyways when you're too addiced from playing.\n\nFor future reference

reviewText:
This is really sad that people were expecting a new 4X game and didn't care to try to understand what was acheived with this game. Guys if you are real fans of Sid's work go watch videos he did playing the game himself and explaining what it is and stop giving bad reviews to a great game simply because you didn't take 5 minutes to inform yourself before buying it.


Now, to the review:

This game is a fast paced strategic & tactical game with a very small learning curve, it offers to have great time on this type of game in a short period of time and it does it really well.

What other strategy game feels both elaborated in style, content and gameplay but is at the same time simple enough to almost feel casual ? (and no, there are no great mobile strategy games except maybe chess, and side note games of type build something and pay or wait aren't games and even less strategy games, they are a steal and should be deemed internationnaly illegal, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it)

In Civ: Starship instead of building an empire and the story of a world, you build a victory.

Game feels polished (noticed a couple tiny bugs but nothing anywhere close to game breaking, i'm just picky on this because i'm in game dev myself), and is really well optimized.

Ships are low poly and haven't heard of dx11 :( but visually better than up close models in BE and don't feel as disapointing.

Regardless of what people are saying, all this game misses is competitive multiplayer and that doesn't take away from it that it's an awsome game in his own gender, aside from the franchise.

To be honest, I thought I'd be as disapointed by this as I was with BE, but it turned out to be the complete opposite and I'm already loving the game. It's a total surprise how great it is, i didn't believe someone could pull it off.

My last game almost felt like playing a board game. I can't wait for the next half hour i'll have to poor into this :)




Sid if you ever read this, I'm really sorry so many people are blinded and don't understand it but you did an awsome job. Thank you.

reviewText:
tl;tr: It's not Civilization in space! It is a small and fast game, perfect to play after work for an hour or two and have fun. Not very deep but funny! Don't expect too much, if you want to play deep and long games go to Civilization. If you want to relax after work for an hour or two this game could be for you.

What is Sid Meier's Starships? You have an intergalactic empire and the goal is nothing less than to rule the galaxy. You can build some basic industry on planets which produce resources like food, metal and so on. With those resources you build your fleet and travel to other planets where you can do missions to gather influence. If you have enough influence the sytem joins your empire. Very simple.

reviewText:
As with all things, what you think about this game is really down to expectation management. I've read alot of the negative reviews and they focus on how they were expecting the game to be different in various ways. More or less related to Beyond Earth, more like a full game, more polished etc...

For my part I purposefully didn't learn alot about the game, I have enough faith in Firaxis to get their products without copious research, X-COM and Civ being the standup gems that they are. For my ignorance I was rewarded with a surprisingly enjoyable experience. The game isn't deep but it has emergent complexities in play. It isn't as customisable or strategic as Civ but that's what Civ is for, this is something different. In a way it brings the fresher innovations in game play some of us hoped Beyond Earth might bring.

If you wanted something different you can't help but be dissapointed, and I get that, but I guess my advice is to be open minded, go in with a clear head and experience the game for what it is, an interesting little adventure that won't require the hundreds of hours to master that Civ does.

If you're interested I'm doing a Let's Play on youtube: https://youtu.be/_ggv6so0sGk?list=UUVAUBrmofKasUbNIm0E2ktw Check out what the game is like!

reviewText:
This is a good game if you know what you are expecting. First, you need to put two things in mind: one, it's only $15, so don't expect some huge game like Civilization V or Beyond Earth; two it's not a Civilization game.

Now with that out of the way, Starships to me, is a unique game that takes the gameplay from many other types of strategy and space faring games. I stated before it isn't a Civilization game, but it still borrows some of the game mechanics from Beyond Earth. It's still mainly just a turn based clicking game, with many different options to start your new game with to spice it up a little bit and to offer some diversity, such as the affinity system from Beyond Earth and the same leaders from it, too. I also like the new feature where you can interact between the two games.
Now, to the pros. I've played a lot of Beyond Earth, and this game was still quite confusing when I started. It seems like it's very complex, but once you play the game for about fifteen minutes, you get the hang of it quite easily. Planets are like cities, and you can apply upgrades to your planets to increase science, metal (production), energy (money), and food. You also use the food to increase the population of your planet, which increases the production of all materials slightly, the only thing that's different in this aspect from Beyond Earth is it doesn't take time. The game is turn based, yes, but it mainly only applies to the battles. This game goes by much faster than a traditional Civilization game, which is good if you just want to kill a couple hours. The customization/upgrade system is pretty alright, too. You can use your materials to apply certain upgrades to certain ships which all have their own effect, you can upgrade the planet as said before, and you can instantly upgrade technology with your science points. There are also four ways to win: population, wonders, science, and domination. Also, another thing I liked is the map, I love the variety of planets and all the planets have their own special aspects to them that alter what they exactly do for you when you control them. And the missions you do for the uncontrolled planets are also pretty unique and fun. The game has no lag or glitches in it at all as long as you have a good enough computer to play.

Cons, I'll make this short. I don't like that you can't trade with the other factions, you can't go through their territory at all unless you are at war which is hard if you don't like having war all the time, and the interactions with leaders are just pretty limited in general, all you can do is wage war, be at peace, see their progress, and very rarely do they offer you a technology if you fight someone for them. Unless you consider the uncontrolled planets as secondary factions, there are no secondary factions to interact with. You can't name the planets or ships if you're into that, either. Most of the wonders are very limited in their use, and you can only build one per planet and it depends on the planet you control.

Conclusion, Starships is a pretty good game to play if you got a few hours to kill or are up at night and can't sleep and it's relatively easy to pick up and learn as well. While it has it's good things, it also has it's flaws, but in Starships, the good outweighs the bad for this one. For $15, you can't really expect a perfect game especially when Firaxis only put a few months into it, but they put good work into this game. While it serves somewhat as an expansion to Beyond Earth, it is it's own game entirely, and it's very fun and time consuming. Remember though before you buy, just because it has Sid Meier's name on the game does not mean it is a Civilization game, it is it's own game with it's own likeness. For $15, it completely worth it to me, and if you can catch this game on sale, I would definately get it.
voteText: 9 of 21 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Read lots of reviews before buying this!

First off, I do like the game and I think many others will too.  However, if you're looking for the usual depth people expect from Sid Meier, then this won't be the game for you.

It's a fun stratagy game, with some refreshing mechanics and a solid platform for interesting tactics.

The down side is that it seems to have been designed for tablets then ported, rather than the other way.  So the interface is simpler than PC gamers will be used to, and annoyingly (at launch) it doesn't have true full screen or full graphics/interface options.

If you want a more casual stratagy experience you can play in the background between other things then this is a cool little title. If you want a full emersive stratagy game that will steal hours of your life at a time, this won't do that for you.
voteText: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ever since Civilization 5, the Firaxis team has been focused on a casual, arcade-like feel for their games. Civ V never had the intensity that Civ IV and before had, yet it was very agreeable to the eyes and had decent replayability. Moving onwards, we got Civilization: Beyond Earth. A pale comparison to Alpha Centauri, but still a fun game if you were in that arcade mentality. Firaxis continues the trend with Starships, a very simple and pretty game that is practically a tablet app game.

Pros:

- The visuals are stunning as usual, and seamless graphics for the most part
- Very interesting use of tactics, looks like they took a page from their X-Com game
- Once you get rolling, the game is straightforward and can bring that one more turn... one more turn..." feeling that every Civ player has come to love and hate.
- the variety of planet missions are great and makes every encounter different.
- the save-link between Beyond Earth and Starships is a nice touch

Cons:

- If you hoped for a intense space domination game
date: this might not be the best bet for you\n- It is really casual oriented
recommended: and that does give the feeling of emptiness and being unfulfilled after playing a game (which could last up to 3 hours)\n- space combat  does get monotonous
hoursPlayed: and once you fire torpedoes enjoy watching the AI scarmble right into your lasers.\n- Controlling only one massive fleet takes a lot of tactical potential away
voteText:
especially on the large/epic maps if your fleet is on the other side of your federation and your planets get attacked.

verdict:

In the end
helpfulPercent: I did enjoy this game more then I hated it
votesHelpful: and I hope with some modest mods the game can really shine
votesTotal: just like how the mods for Civ V have made it a new game entirely. If you go in with a asual
votesFunny: arcadey attitude
commentsCount: you will not be disappointed and will find this game enticing and refreshing. Just don't expect any long epic campaigns."

reviewText:
I want to start by saying that I clearly put some time into this game, and I do believe that it is on the VERY EDGE of recieving a recommendation.  The bugs and obvious mission features need to be worked out.
The Decent Parts   Tactical Combat - Although it still isn't perfect, the combat sections of the game are actually very entertaining.  Ships can be outfitted with various modules and upgraded to your liking.  Whether your ships are damage sponges with devastating firepower, carriers that can launch numerous fighters at the enemy, or insanely fast scout ships with cloaking abilities to get behind enemy lines, you're going to need to use some strategy and use your surroundings to your advantage.  If caught in the open, you can withstand critical hits, which need a turn to be repaired and leave you vunerable to attack.
Wonders - On each planet that you capture for your federation, you will recieve the option to create a wonder, such as stealth torpedos, 360 degree shielding, and systems that can withstand critical hits.  These can open new strategies and may influence how you build your ships.
Mission Variety - Missions aren't always simply Kill the baddies before they pimp slap you to death".  While travelling to different planets to increase your federation's influence
date: you will often encounter missions that require you to escort civilian ships
hoursPlayed: and destroy stealth fighters that conceal themselves in the shadows.  While the missions to gain influence may often seem boring and pointless
voteText: it is often made up for by the epic battles between two warring federations.  These final battles as you attempt to capture homeworlds (or defend yours from an assault) often made me feel like I was actually doing something halfway important.  Instead of a 30 second mission where I blow up a fighter squadron

reviewText:
I actually really enjoy the game! If you're big on in depth strategy and resource management this isn't it. Managing planets doesn't have much depth. Build cities to up al resource output by a bit or build individual improvments to highly increase specific resource outputs. The game is mainly about building up your fleet and running combat missions.


One thing I really enjoy is the fleet building. You start off with two ships and some energy to upgrade them. The fun thing is that all ships start with roughly the same base stats, and depending on where you put upgrades it not only does it alter that ships apperance but also what role you're looking to use the ship in. As I said, the gameplay is fast paced, not a whole lot of depth but I still really enjoy playing it! Something to waste away the afternoon with for sure!

reviewText:
Played a couple of games so far on the first two difficulty levels and smaller universes, and enjoyed both.  The game is easy to get into and fast-paced.  It's reminiscent of Spaceward Ho! for the few of you who may have played it years ago. But with much more depth.

I suppose there is the danger of some fun aspects of the game bogging down as the fleets get large and you have to manage larger empires. But I haven't encountered that yet.

I do wish you could rename your planets and ships --- the planet names start to blur after a while, and I would like to be able to specialize my ships with regards to capabilities and name them appropriately.

I don't think the replayability of Starships will be anywhere near the Civ games, but seems worth the money.  I am looking forward to playing at harder difficulty levels.

And hey, there is a final animation for winning!

reviewText:
Just fininished my first playthrough, and it was fun. Interesting choices, nice concept, versatile missions: I like it!

However, if you are looking for a grand strategy game like Civilisation: This is not it. The focus is completely different.
The game also suffers from the usual day1 problems that should not happen: Mainly an imperfect tutorial (I highly recommend watching Sid Meiers IGN lets-play video beforehand...I do believe it improved my experience greatly) and some balancing issues. But it also felt like a gem...parts of it still raw and uncut, but the elegance of it shining through.

If you are turned off by such things: wait a month or two, otherwise I recommend the experience. (And seriously: watch the video while you download the game! ;)

Engage!

reviewText:
I watched the Twitch vids for this on the Firaxis channel and I liked the look of it so I preordered. I've waited till I got a few hours in to post this so as to do the review justice.
It's alot of fun! I'm actually surprised I'm enjoying it this much. I was hearing alot of negative stuff before the launch so was unsure but after playin it for a while I'm completely satisfied with the purchase!
The game is alot quicker than you're used to from a Sid Meier title, I havn't tried a small map (preferring the large) but I'd estimate you could Knock out a game on the train to work or the tube or whatever you're taking!
There's enough strategy in there to keep you thinking, between mission choices, planetary improvements, wonder construction and ship upgrades/ships.
Visiually its pretty but nothin special.
Audio is the same.
I was disappointed I could not rename ships and planets.
On the whole a great casual title perfect for me between stressful rounds on other games or a quick game of somethin when you don't have the time for a 3 week epic game of civ 5!
On the whole I like the game and I'm glad I bought it, Its fun!
I'd give it 7/10

etc et al

reviewText:
Simple and elegant

For the price I did not expect a game that would blow me away. I expected a polished simple single player experience and that is exactly what I got.

At first I was slightly disappointed in the introduction video. It should at the very least scale up to 1080p, but it is a minor aestethic complaint. Next I was confounded by the Settings". Basically you can only choose between windowed or fullscreen
date: and you can adjust various volume levels. Thats it. Further on it becomes obvious that you will not need any advanced settings for this game.\n\nVisually the game delivers a polished
recommended:
clean and smooth experience. Various icons and symbols ties nicely in with Beyond Earth. Aduio effects are also very BEish.

Strategically you manage planets and one fleet of spaceships through resources produced by said planets and rewards from missions. You have to choose missions wisely because you can only complete so many each turn and those you ignore will be completed by your neighbours.

Tactically you move around and attack enemies on various "maps" generated for each battle and there are a handful of random elements thrown in for each battle.  You configure your ships offense based on preferred range and utility
hoursPlayed: and you have a few defensive options as well.\n\nThe whole thing ties together nicely and offer a relaxed
voteText: balanced single player experience. I can easily recommend this game."

reviewText:
I must admit that I came into this game not expecting much.  But what I got is a game that is quite enjoyable.  Whilst the game borrows from the lore of Civilization Beyond Earth the game itself doesn't hold much in common.

The game works by having you perform missions at each planet you stop at.  Complete the mission and your influence on that planet rises till you control it.  When you control it you can improve it, gain resources and wonders, and generally have access to more stuff".

The strategy comes in utilising your fleet (you only have one) to your benefit.  You only have a certain number of actions per turn so make sure you choose well.  Do you do a mission on a nearby planet?  Make a run for an emey's home world?  Or spend a turn to repair and make new ships in your fleet?

Overall a really good game that ties "tried and true" Sid Meier concepts into the one game."

reviewText:
I have never reviewed a game before, but after reading so many reviews of others, I wanted to express my opinion.  Whether or not I can recommend the game is dependent upon what you seek, and what your expectations are.

The biggest problem, from what I have inferred from reading reviews, is from disapointed expectations.  Civilization V and earlier Firaxis/Sid Meier games are nothing short of brilliant.  The entire Civilization series (and I have been there since its inception) could arguably be labeled the greatest PC games ever produced, from every which way you might want to analyze it: quality, depth, re-playablility, customization, fun, and strategy.

If you are looking for Starships to have the depth, and strategy (long-term planning and maneuvering) to achieve the final victory, you won't find that here.  This is a simple game, almost more like an arcade game with some choice elements to be determined by your preference, such as do you want firepower or stealth?  But not the intricies of long-term grand scale strategy that Civ is famous for.  If you are anticipating even a scaled-down version of Civ, you will be disappoineted.  This is not a game of watching your grand design come to frutuion.   After having played several games of Civilization V, marathons that lasted more than 800 turns and a week of playing per game, I welcome being able to play a quick in-and-out game like this.  This is more complicated than Solitaire or Minesweeper, and can be similarly addicitve.  Starships is NOT trying to be Civ.  Perhaps Firaxis went too far away from strategy on this one, but I had fun with it.    Simple fun.

However, I was really disappointed the way ship design and outfitting work.  When I first heard about this release , I thought back to one of my all-time favortie games, Master of Orion II, and shrilled at the prospect of a Sid Meier version of this.  In MOO2, you selected a ship class, which was an empty shell, and you chose how to outfit it, based upon the research you had done.  And even if you were capable of adding your Class X shields to your ship, you could have instead installed Class V shields, allowing more space for other modules (such as another array of lasers) and reducing its cost.   And there were several choices of laser technology to add, based on research and function.   In Starships, there are only lasers (long-range) and plasma cannons (short range), with only a nebulous upgrade by incrementing a level.  I was looking forward to specialized intricate ship design.  There is none of that, as this is the simplest system.  For me, the ship designing  in MOO2 was the most exciting part of any Space 4X game I have ever played, and what I was hoping  Starships would be.  Based upon my expectation, my desire, this game fails.

Does this game have depth?  No.  Is the strategy a deep-thinking man's game like Civ?  No.  Was it fun?   Yes.    What you want from a game, the level of complexity and granularity you enjoy,  together with your expectation of Starships, will determine whether you think it is worth it ot not.    For some easy, casual and quick fun, Starships delivers.  But if you want this to be a CIv-like game, or somewhat like MOO2, complicated and full of strategic and tactical choices, it will not satisfy.

reviewText:
It's a good little game, I'd buy it full price, but would recommend people buy it for sale. Reminds me of MoO2, only less depth, and alot shorter.

It's the most basic of 4X games I've ever seen, and because, good. It polished its core very well, you need to explore to expand, and you need to exterminate your rivals to make sure you end up with a controlling majority of the galaxy. You explore other player by playing off know rivals, for boost in you tech or resources.

I've only complete the one play through, and it took me roughly an hour. The controls took me about 15min to learn.

Comparing it to MoO2, combat is hex-bases rather than square based, and you take on the role of fleet commander. Very similar to each other, and it was nice.

The game is really basic, focusing on the core of what makes a 4X game, well, a 4X game, you can gain tech/recourses from fighting for a rival of a allied faction.

I think we need to seem more games like this, games that focus on what makes a good 4X game, before we see another MoO3, or Galactic Civ game. Going to fair done the path of exploration, exploitation, or extermination.

reviewText:
First of all, this is the kind of game I wanted and needed. I needed something to replace in my heart the one and only Fantasy General and the Panzer General series to a lesser extent.
It has the exact level of casualness I was looking for.
It's light, it's windowed, it's user friendly.
It's perfectly upgradeable in the future (I hope so at least).
Don't look for deep strategy, this is first and foremost a tactical hex battles game. The difficulties are what they are and it shows. On easy you can pretty much outsmart every A.I., but as soon as you reach hard enemies in medium or even moreso in the higher difficulties it really shows if you're a tactical genius or not.
Oh, don't forget your torpedoes at home. They rule the space.
