reviewText:
Sci-Fi Digital Strategy Board Game
( I had to sit down with the game for a number of hours before coming up with the exact reasons why I enjoy it, and it very much earns it's positive recommendation. I'll probably edit this again)

It's all about enjoying a digital board game set in space and chilling out. This is a lite-tactical hexagonal space mission game. As captain of a federation, you are charged with bouncing the fleet between planets completing various types of missions and winning over the galaxy that resulted in the wake of Beyond Earth. From the rewards from victories and accumulated resources, you're able to upgrade your ships in a few different ways from increasing their basic health and strength to providing abilities like stealth, torpedo salvos and carrier-borne interceptors. Strategic diplomacy is extremely basic, and amounts to whether you want to deal with the AI directly opposing you or not.

The game is very simple, and I recommend watching a Let's Play" on YouTube before buying as it's a large departure from Firaxis' other games. The game feels like it'd be at home on a tablet or phone due to it's simplicity.
The gameplay pacing is well suited for short stints for people that want to relax with a small space tactical game. I think it's great to do a full voyage (about 4 missions) and then put the game down for a bit. It's not for great hour long marathons
date:
but a full game might take anywhere from 1-2 hours.
So does it reflect Firaxis' Civ "just one more turn" philosophy? Probably not. But is that really a bad thing? It depends on what you were looking for. It's great for those times when one is juggling other tasks.

There are very few areas where I'd nit-pick it
recommended: especially as a single player game. There are many player strategies which are very unbalanced
hoursPlayed: such as cloaking mixed with some of the Wonders. I would say that the most fun I have is when I pick it up with a particular house-rule for my gameplay that restricts a particular technology or strategy that I'd used prior.\n\nI would love to see the ability to mod in and out various aspects
voteText: such as to revamp the resources in a drawn out game
helpfulPercent: and more of the missions reminicent of the exploration phase.\nFrom a technical perspective
votesHelpful: if this was done in Ruby
votesTotal: I'm impressed and hopeful.\nI think it'd be a great project for even a scripter or programmer to step in and change things to suit their own tastes."

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Starships is like a cross between X-Com and Civilization.

I ran into no game stopping bugs.  The screen might freeze up if one clicks too fast but it should clear up in less than 30 seconds.

The game is easy enough to figure out and there is an advisor button if help or a suggestion is needed.  Buttons turn red if something requires attention.  There are action scenes of weapons firing for those with little imagination.

9 out of 10 for those who like turn based games.
voteText: 6 of 17 people (35%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I just downloaded starships and played a few games. This game is awesome! I don't get people who are complaining that this game isn't enough like the civ games...seriously...one of the biggest criticisms of critics regarding beyond earth was its supposed overly similar interface and gameplay (to civ 5). So sid releases a game that is only loosely based on beyond earth (factions, faction bonuses) and all of a sudden this game doesn't play the same as beyond earth or civ 5? wow..talk about hard to please....

Anyways back to my review:

The good

-This game is very tactical (the battlefield has asteroids/planets you can use as cover (to hide behind) and blocking players shots (some weapons can shoot through minimal asteroid fields but then the dmg you take is reduced (it feels good when the comp tells you you have only a 35% chance to complete a mission given your current situation (*ships/upgrades etc) and you still manage to pull it off!

-upgrades on planets provide good strategic options (as planet wonders affect your economy, ships, battle, income, repair costs etc the list goes on...)

-The ai is pretty sneaky and will come by and try to undermine your influence on planets that haven't been won over to your side yet

-upgrading your ships even has some strategy too it (do you upgrade existing ships to have more movement points, higher shield, better weapons, cloaking, sensor range etc) vs buying a completely new ship and thus increasing your overall fleet size

-fleet sizes don't seem to get too big, so its easy to manage, and the combat is really fun. of course you have to like turn based hex based combat to enjoy this (but what are you doing buying a sid meier game if you dont'? lol)

-the ai will ally with other players against you (but its still not impossible to win...just hard) - so the challenge is there if you want it (as i only played on normal and i found it challenging)

-the graphics are pretty good, and the animations look cool (lol its like  startrek but without familiar ship designs)

-various parts of your economy to manage (balancing metal (to improve defenses/planets, food (to increase city sizes (and thus increase resource generation), energy (to upgrade your ship) and science points (to provide general upgrades to your entire fleet

- all of the crap is pared away with this game..no random stats or updates on your planet populations mood/ or any of that garbage..this has been replaced with the morale of your starships troops (they fight less effectively until you give them shore leave (effectively this is the end turn button)..enemy does its turns and then you receive your planet income and start your new turn (with all morale restored). There is a wonder you can build on your planets so that your starship crew fights at max level no matter the level of fatigue (this is def something to research.).

-the defense of your planets is handled well (you buy planet defense upgrade (its called a megabot or something) and they are basically extra ships that will assistn you in defense of a planet (good thing to upgrade...lol).


the bad

-it would be nice if i could adjust the graphics options (even though it does look really good lol i like the ability to make it even better..thats why i bought an expensive pc....

-the trainer (i.e. tutorial) is ok...but doesn't tell you everything you need to know...(tutorial is only a few popups and ends with telling you to click the info button (and it then gives you a suggestion of what to do). Some things i had to figure out for myself (most of it is intuitive so you will figure it out just by playing a game or two) but a little more help would have improved the experience for people who don't want to waste any time figuring out little details (for instance i didn't know i could improve defenses...build cities etc until i started clicking buttons to see what did what), i also didn't realize i could buy a new ship (instead of just improving the ones i had), i didn't know if i could have more than one fleet (it doesn't seem like you can) and it wasn't super obvious to me if i had to manually change weapons in combat (lasers for long range, photon something for close range and torpedoes for really far) lasers/photons activate when you go to attack the enemy by themselves (i.e. if its too far for photons you shoot lasers and vice versa). Torpedoes are weird in that you do activate it manually but when you shoot them (at first they dont' do anything...you have to wait until your next turn to manually detonate it or move it forward more) you have 2 turns to either move it forward a bit more or detonate it (after 2 turns it detonates by itself). generally people see them coming but you can move out of the way...unless you get the planet wonder that makes them perma stealthed (which is awesome). (ok this was long but basically as you can see..woulda been nice if the game just told me some of that stuff..but you figure it out pretty easy.

- not much story here...at all (if you care about story this may irritate you)


Overall, this game is pretty awesome...its fun to play, different enough from normal sid meier games that its refreshing, but familiar enough that you won't be completely lost if you have played a 4x strat game before. Definitely recommend this game! just buy it already!...at 17 bucks its less than half of what i paid for beyond earth and is just as fun so its a great price point for a game that has a surprising amount of depth at a price thats cheaper than going to a movie at the theater.
voteText: 5 of 15 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
TL;DR I wasn't sure I'd like it at first, but then I got into a tactical battle and enjoyed myself. Kind of a mix between Master of Orion and a tactical board game. Not a normal Sid Meier game where you can sink 100s of hours into, takes 1-2 hours to win and worth multiple replays. Not bad for 15 dollars. 8/10

===More In Depth Review===

Simple Space 4x where you have to get enough of the galaxy fighting for Team Player Character to win the galaxy super election.

You start off with one planet, and venture out to other planets to win their allegiance (either through doing quests, buying influence, destroying their factions fleet or simply ending your turn there). On each planet you can make upgrades that will either increase their resource output or add a warp gate (giving you free movement to the planet) or constructing a defensive fleet. Each planet rolls 1-2 random strategic attributes that give it an advantage (such as +50% energy output or 1/2 cost on resource buildings). Each planet also rolls a random tactical attribute such as torpedos being undetectable or more powerful cover from asteroids. A planet also has a chance of having the ability to have a wonder being built on it. All of this is somewhat simple, but there is a real swing factor in gaining or losing a planet with a great combination of attribute that adds a lot of fun to it.

Combat is great and where most of the enjoyment is. It's hex based TBS that has a heavy emphasis on cover and positioning.  Ships have three weapons at their disposal- Lasers (long range light damage), Plasma (short range medium damage) and Torpedos (Long Range Massive damage, but very predictable). Ships can also activate stealth (can't be hit with targeted weapons, enemy has to use sensor to find you) activate sensors (for finding stealthed units) or activate impulse drive (trade an action for a single movement in any direction without turning). Effectively, how combat goes is you use asteroids for cover while denying cover to enemies with your torpedoes.

Unlike plasma or lasers, torpedoes don't lose damage when fired through an asteroid field. They can't explode the first turn they are fired and continue moving in a straight line for up to three turns. As they automove on the second and third turn you are allowed to make them explode remotely as they move in real time". Being near the center of a torpedo explosion is usually a one shot kill. The explosions also clear asteroids. Torpedos almost never directly get kills against you so long as you move out of their path. The AI doesn't seem to respect them enough though - in the last battle of the game I played I got a triple kill with a torpedo as three ships maneuvered close together to take pot shots at one of my fighters.

Your army is a persistent fleet of ships that you purchase upgrades for. Upgrades are pretty predictable (engines give you more moves per turn
date: lasers do more damage) and there's no real incentive to specialize other then you can't afford all the upgrades at once. There's also a fairly mild experienced mechanic tied to a ship's performance in battle. Science ties into all of this as well
recommended: but it's just more simple upgrades to laser damage paid for with a separate currency that effects your whole fleet at once.\n\nWonder balance seems a bit wonky

reviewText:
Let's be upfront about something: This is not a Civilization game, nor does it pretend to be. If you're looking for Alpha Centauri 2 or a rehabilitation of Beyond Earth that isn't a weak Civ5 mod, you're in the wrong place.

If you want a board game to play on your computer, then this is exactly what you're looking for.

Starships is a compact game probably designed primarily for mobile devices. And you know what? There's nothing wrong with that. Where Starships excels is in its vision and execution of making a game that recreates the board game experience.

What's so elegant about Starships is that it takes common board game mechanics and takes advantage of the fact that since the game is being run on a computer, it can develop those mechanics to new heights. Developing planets as your resource generators very much mirrors how a board game might have a chart where you move tokens around to determine how much you get per turn. Special abilities function like cards drawn out of a deck, and the map looks like a game board. Even the victory condition, Control 51% of the map" sounds like something out of a board game.

The combat is simple but deep. You get full customization of your units
date: and you move around on a hex grid shooting at each other with stuff like line of sight
hoursPlayed: and cover to calculate. It would be unmanageable as a tabletop game (unless everyone playing is a total Warhammer junkie)
voteText: but as a video game it's very easy to let the computer do all the calculations for you.\n\nLike any game worth its weight
helpfulPercent: the rules are very simple to understand after a turn or two
votesHelpful: but there's enough nuance to them that you'll be spending quite a few hours understanding how to optimize everything and adjust on the fly.\n\nMajor strikes against the game: Missing a lot of basic computer game functions (come on
votesTotal: let me up the resolution!) and no multiplayer. The latter is pretty bad
votesFunny: but then again
commentsCount: it takes a very special group of people to have the patience to sit through a multiplayer 4X game.\n\nIn short: It's a board game. Don't fool yourself into thinking otherwise. But it is a great board game that takes advantage of not forcing the players to calculate anything on the fly

column17: this is probably a game you'll enjoy.\n"

reviewText:
Sid Meier’s Starships is simple and to the point. It's a hex based strategy game focused around fleets of starships. Don't expect the moon, but what's here is pure and well developed. The mechanics are clear and intuitive, as with any Sid Meier creation. You use your fleet to garner influence with planets by either performing missions or taking shore leave there. The planets provide resources and can be upgraded in a few ways. Combat is turn based. Your ship's shields are weak in the back and strong in the front. Asteroid fields either block sight completely or reduce it. Weapons vary with long range lasers, short range cannons and torpedoes that cover a finite amount of space per turn. Researchable technologies are tied to specific ship systems and planetary wonders affect a given gameplay mechanic. It's streamlined down to a fault, but it's a fault they're not trying to hide from you. This is a $15 game made with tablets in mind as much as a PC. The games are quick in comparison to the ‘oh it’s dawn now’ syndrom that’s inherent to the Civilization franchise which is refreshing.

I’ve only played two games with harmony so I haven’t played around with the other two affinities. The easy difficulty is extremely easy, so I’d recommend going hard or in the least normal. Though easy is a safe way to get a feel for the game. I’ve also only used a couple of the commanders, but their special bonuses seem balanced enough tied to the right playstyles.

This is a good and purposely small game. It’s fun and quick and I really can’t say anything too negative about it. There’s no deception by Firaxis trying to build it up into something more than it is. But it’s inevitable that the game’s disinterest with being bigger than it is will bother a number of people. Thankfully it’s interested in what it is beyond the backlash.

reviewText:
I want to start off by saying I gave this a good recomendation - but only just good.

The game is fun - there's no doubting that; but there's something missing from the game.  It's too damn simple and the AI is ridiculous.  My first game was a test (didn't do the tutorial) and just started winging it.  I had no problem playing and the concept is easy to understand.

Now my second game was kinda crazy.  I was a bit into it and suddely it's game over: the AI (I had only run into 2 of the AI players) won with a wonder victory.  No clue how it was over so fast... :(

The graphics are great - the sound is fine - but there's something lacking and so far, I can't put my finger on it.  I really hope firaxis rebalances and puts more ... well, whatever it is that's missing that I can't just put my finger on... into it.

The end result:  It's not civ v, it's not beyond earth.  It is fun, but it's just a lunch break game that you probably won't win most of the time (or so it seems)

reviewText:
This game is obviously designed to be a tablet game that would have run alongside Beyond Earth. This is most obvious by the apparent lack of a simple exit button on the main screen, something very common on tablet games.

With that out of the way, this game is a decent PC game and the strategy is very well done. The war game events seem at first glance boring and strightforward, but they are quite complex if you plan it out right and adapt in game.

I have tried it on a Surface Pro 3 and it works fine. Once you start it on a device with touchscreen then the options gice the choice for the controls to be touchscreen.

Overall it is a good game. I would recommend waiting for a BE/Starships combo sale as it is worth about $15 in my opinion.

reviewText: If you like turn-based fights on tiled (hexagon) maps there's a lot of fun to be had in this game.  Not super complex, but enough so as to make you consider which planet to invade or which upgrade to buy for your ships or which wonders to build in your empire. Games last anywhere from about 30 minutes to a few hours depending on difficulty and galaxy size. If you remember the ship combat from Master of Orion 2, this game is similar to that. The wonders in this game taking the place of some of the more exotic ship components from the earlier game. No one aspect of the game would be enough to win an award by itself, but everything is competent, pretty and the level of polish is excellent as you would expect from Firaxis. All in all, a really good value for just $15.

reviewText:
Despite what others have said this game is great. Why they link it to Pirates is unknown to me, it is more like Civ meets Air Patrol. The civ part requires very little management and the fleet system is so much fun to customize. By customize I don't mean the look of the ships, rather how tough, fast, how many hangars, etc. And if you want to reduce points you spent from say stealth to engine, you can in no time flat.

It does lack fullscreen mode at this point. But I've played worse games in fullscreen and some awesome games in windowed mode. I'd like to see it added, but I am not gonna whine and say it ruins the whole game. That's extremely petty when the game has much to offer to keep you busy.

I think some folks are getting a bad impression of this game because of the lack of micro-management. To me that gets you in to the action that much faster, which is the point of this game. I've already spent hours conquering the galaxy. The maps aren't very huge, in this type of game they don't need to be. You don't have to exhaust yourself building 40 structures from the ground up like you do in Civ, that's a major plus for me. Although I love Civ, I didn't need another one so soon.

For the current cost of the game, it is great. It can use some polish, what game can't use some 5 years after it's launched?

Update: I expected to get some down votes, can't expect children to understand simple logic with out getting their panties in a bunch I guess. Bottom line, the game is worth the money, don't expect to be wow'ed. It's a simple game, lots of fun.

reviewText:
Coming into this game, my expectations weren't super high. There are some features that could be better, no doubt, but for what it is, and the short time that I played it at the time of writing this review, I do recommend it.

Compared to other Civ games, it's light, but the features that are in it make it pretty fun (even though they could do with some touching up). It seems like most people don't like the game very much, but for it's price, if your a fan of Civ games and other space games as well, I'd say give it a shot. It's not the greatest by any means, but still worth a look. I'm sure with future patches, the game will get better (hopefully).

Pros:
-The ships for each affiliation (Supremacy, Harmony, Purity) look pretty good and when upgrading them, their look changes with each corresponding upgrade.
-The way you get control of different planets is pretty cool (in my opinion)
-A decent amount of leaders to choose from each with different bonuses
-The battle and movement animations look nice and fairly smooth
-Tactical battles are pretty fun, but may get boring quickly depending on who you face. (Pirates are a constant thing when it comes to the quests)
-Easy to learn and understand the mechanics.

Cons:
-The camera control is pretty awful. I get it was made for mobile as well as PC, but really? You can only move the camera with the arrow keys and it's pretty bad, especially in battles.
-Quests to control planets can get repetitive; most of the time it's just beating up pirates of some sort, though since I've only just started playing, it may change as you go along (doubtful though).
-There are no graphical options at all, and the fullscreen mode (at least for me) shows my taskbar still at the bottom of my screen. Minor, but can be annoying.
-The affiliations are cool, but I wish there was a little more variety with them. The only real difference I've noticed so far are different looking ships and a different starting bonus.
-The research tree" is...lackluster to say the least.

That's about all for now. I'll update this review further as I play and as they patch the game in the future.
Personally

reviewText:
I spent a few hours playing this today. I have not played Beyond Earth. I've enjoyed the game so far.

What it is:
A $15.00 space title, with tactical combat, decent graphics, and some compelling aspects.
Ship customization (modular)
Tech Tree
Lightweight turn based system
Low maintenance.

This is a great game to play on your ipad or machine when you have a couple of hours to burn and want to unwind after work. It is not a Civ game and will not have that level of cmplexity. I think it has potential to be very moddable if they make that an option.

Now with that said there are some things people need to know:
The tech tree is very imited and has no appreciable effect outside of combat
The game centers around space combat and gathering territory
You can only have 8 ships and they always travel as a group
It can feel a little rinse and repeat in the late game on Epic stick to shorter games

None of those things surprise me this is not a $50.00 game. What it does not have is any bugs I have found, it performs perfectly, and I have had fun playing it. I like space games, I like to unwind, I do not like to feel like I am managing an empire when I get off work during the week. This is exactly what I expected when I bought it, I watched a lot of game play videos from the creators before buying.

I suggest if you like science fiction and want something to play thats simple and fun. Give it a try, watch a few videos first if you are unsure.

If however, you are expecting the next Orions, Civ in Space, Galactic Civ or what have you then you will be dissapointed. It plays like a lightweight X-Com in space. This would not be a game for you.

Hope this helps!

reviewText:
Sid Meir's Starship may not at first seem to be the be all end all for a PC game.  You are playing a Sid Meir game, you are not here for the textures or graphics but rather the gameplay, and oh boy the gameplay does deliver. In a short quick game session you can finish a type of victory (I use type because if you go all dominiton and alliance the game can be won in about 3hrs). However, replayability is high.

Where it fails to livy what Beyond Earth failed to do, it does however stay  true to it's true purpose. Being Admiral Adama and fighting the Cylon in a race for time to stay alive...Well it's not about BSG but you get the feel of it. Every time you are in a battle, you get the tense feeling. Constantly studying the battle field and thinking 4 moves ahead. Should you place your fighters there in hopes they get the brunt force and not your destroyer, or maybe yet use the torpedo you launch 3 moves ago to wipe out a hub of enemy. When not in battle, you get to grow your Planets with cities, buildings, improvments, money/science making improvment, buying influence in order to gain control of the galaxy vastness of population.

You want a quick fun game that has core Civ gameplay with additional Starship Admiral Fleet battle, this is the game. If you are somewhat left with a MEH" after Beyond Earth and think this game will make you love it

reviewText:
Sid Meier´s  Starships

The good

Its a fast pace Sid Merier´s game, it uses alot of mechnics featured in Civ V and Beyond Earth, however its simplified in order to make turns faster and easier. Which i feel make it a good addition to the CiV franchise for those day you dont want  to spend hours or days to play a CiV campaing. Building and maintaining your fleet is easy and quick, upgrading cities and building improvements are easier then ever.  I find it alot of fun.

The Bad

Just like Beyond Earth the different faction personalities lack character, and arent that interesting, unlike its more historical predecessor,BE and Starships dont have humanitys rich history to draw upon in the players imagination and give us instead a barebones universe. I love sci-fi but there is so little lore in this game that can draw you in it quickly becomes a very sterile experience.

Starships also lack true fullscreen and a decent options menu.

The Ugly

The graphics are functional and colorful, but i cant say the game is especially pretty.

The Verdict

Sid Merier´s Starship is a lightweight mobile game that aimd in providing a on the fly fast CiV experience. I think the game achives it goals. It lacks the strategic depth and richness of the other civ games, but it has fairly enjoyable in shortbursts. Its the Sid Meier´s game you choose to play on  the train, before you go to school, a late friday night before a date or a party, If you dont like that idea and want something more substantial, i would not buy this game. However if you want affordable, fast paced tactics game Sid Meier`s starship provides that.

reviewText:
So first off i dunno what people are expecting with this game.

This is an IPAD game that they released on pc. So go into it thinking that it's an ipad game.

So yea it's missing some key things for a pc title, namely resolution settings and a borderless full screen mode.  It also currently doesn't have multiplayer, it's biggest flaw i feel and one i hope they patch asap.

So gameplay:

You control a fleet and click on planets completeing neutral missions to try and convince the planet to join your empire, the harder the mission the more influence you get.  2 influence and they start trading with you, 4 influence and they join your empire.   The reason you want these planets is they produce 4 resources and you can upgrade these planets, build wondes, and increase their population as you see fit to get more resources to buy more things.   In addition you can completely customize your fleet.  Do you want 10 capital ships or 4 super beefy ones, long range guns or short, speed or stealth.  All can be customized indivdually.  And it's really nice.

Like civ there are other players doing the same thing, and you can be peaceful with them or you can fight them. The neutral planets are actually kinda cool in this aspect because you might have went did a quest and got 2 influence but the other players are going to get another quest to go there and might take it from you or knock down your influence.

Again like civ you all repeat this process with better and better things until a victory condition is met either by population, galactic domination, or science.  First person to one of those wins.

All in all it's fast paced you only get 1 fleet so at most you can only do a couple things on your turn and planets can change hands quite quickly if you don't build up defenses.  The ai isn't amazing but it does ok i haven't tried the harder difficulties yet so perhaps they get a lot better there.

This game would be amazing if it had multiplayer.  This game is made for pass and play on an ipad or online multiplayer for pc.  Why they didn't include this in the game is anyones guess.  If a firaxis person is reading this please please give us multiplayer!

If you're looking for a quick paced game that you can pick up and put down after 10-30 min and a full campaign takes about 3 hours then this game is a lot of fun.  Could it be better?  Yes, but it's solid and plays well.    Most of the negative hate on this game seems to be centered around the fact that this is a mediocre port of an ipad game. But if you can get over that you'll have fun with it.

reviewText:
BYTE SIZE REVIEW:

I don't post a lot of reviews, but I have long been a fan of Sid Meier's games.  That being said, despite not playing this game for very long (and I will updated this review at that point in time), I don't have much time to play games anyway so thought I would share my thoughts thus far.

This game is amazing.  It so far reminds me of a space version of Pirates! which is fun in and of itself.  The object of the game is to control over half of the galaxy.  This can be accomplished, by spreading your influence, completing missions, etc.  You get to choose both your faction (for lack of a better word since I don't recall what each group is called) as well as your hero (much like nations and skills in Pirates!).  I'm really looking forward to playing more of this, but I am definitely recommending this for now.  :)

reviewText:
I knew before it was released that this game would be ranted and raged about on release. Why? Because a number of people had expectations which were completely out of line with the game that Firaxis promoted repeatedly on their YouTube channel.

Sid Meier's Starships was announced as a tablet game with a PC version from the get-go, but a certain segment of gamers saw the name Sid Meier and convinced themselves that this game was going to be Civilization In Space (a.k.a. Sid Meier's Master Of Orion) despite all evidence to the contrary.

Here's what it is: a simplified tactical space game with colorful graphics and impressive music. It has some depth -- it might be worth reading the in-game rules section to understand the game's strategic layer -- but it's basically a tactical starship battle game.

Does the game have problems? Yup. The lack of a true fullscreen on PC, for example, really annoys me (you have to manually set your taskbar to auto-hide) but there's nothing wrong here on day one that a few, inevitable post-launch patches won't fix.

So, if you're undecided, wait for the patching. Some people report not being able to start the game at all, but I've seen none of that here. (If it won't start, I've heard that skipping the opening cutscene may be a work-around)

Day One Verdict? The things I like about Sid Meier's Starships outweigh the things I don't, by a fairly wide margin. I expect a number of issues to be corrected with patches, going forward. This isn't the next great strategy game -- it's a play it for fast
date: fun starship battles" tablet game.\n\nYou won't devote days and weeks of your life to this game
recommended: but I think Sid Meier's Starships does what it set out to do very well."

reviewText:
This game is underatted by far yes its a simple game but absolutely solid in AI performance and core mechanics sure the settings and window could be improved sure they will with a patch.

Its to simple they say yes its supposed to be I found the most fun in the fleet battles and different missions I really did enjoy this game that moment when your best ship gets blasted to peices by three enemy ships at once, it seems well balanced.

The main map is well designed easy to understand lack of tutorial is helped by simple advisor mechanic and initial screen shots showing the basics of the game so you don't need a tutorial this game is already easy enough to understand.

I played and beat very quickly well thats the point replayability setting up your own game victory condition choosing your difficulty through games can last a few hours.

Building a fleet is easy you start with base ships and through various options you can choose to speciallise them I.E ship carrier, heavy Battleship so on reccomend long range.

The A.I seemed very competant just played on easy so far to get the feel of the game reccomend you just dive in and have fun with it well worth the price of £10.99 not £30 so don't be exspecting a AAA game.

To most of the negative reviews there was plenty of Videos information about the game to know what it was about hell even the steam store page pretty much sums up the game well so you have only yourselves to blame don't put people of who would like the game.

overall solid 6/10 high replayability easy controls hard to master, look forward to more games like this very refreshing

reviewText: Fianlly being able to play Starships after watching hours of livestream from Firaxis, it's exactly what I was expecting it to be. With a not-too-complex playstyle, Starships is a fun short-game alternative to the Civ:BE universe akin to Ace Patrol (only with a bit more simplistic battle mechanics). Also, there's the added bonus of cross-game rewards between Civ:BE and Starhips, although I've yet to figure out how that system works precisely. Some bonuses are straightforward, and other pop-ups I've gotten saying I've unlocked something left me a bit perplexed.\n\nI've found that in order to have a worthwhile run of a game lasting more than an hour I have to restrict myself to Domination victory, at which point one can accrue a rather sizable fleet which on harder difficulties can make for interesting battles with the AI. So, bearing in mind the $15 price tag, understand what you're getting into if you're on the fence about this one. And not that there's multiplayer plans I'm aware of, if such a thing happens that would add leagues of value to the game overall.

reviewText:
Fast, fun little space 4x.

Initial impressions are that this is Sid Meier's take on a remake of Master of Orion 2.

The pros are this game has very little learning curve with a pretty easy to learn interface. Easy is easy, hard is actually hard, just as it should be. This is the kind of game you play if you don't have time for a game of Civ, but still want that hit of strategy.

The cons are lack of flavour and options. The game at times feels a little generic, like the bare bones were built, the skins were drafted, but the complex flavouring was left out. At times it's like going to a 3 star resaurant for a burger and fries.

reviewText:
Because bullet points are cool:

---Advantages---
+Simple, but not overly simple gameplay mechanics: Click and move. Click and shoot. Resources = fleet upgrades. Get more planets = get more resources = more ships and upgrades

+A nice variety of starting customization

+Lots of starship upgrades for those who are into that

+Battles look cool

+Buildable Wonders that grant additional tactical capabilities

---Drawbacks---

-Really short

-Poorly balanced: Let me elaborate on this one. Some wonders are just too overpowered. 2-non-attack-actions-per-turn wonder+Full-Fighter-Movement-On-Launch = Swarm all your enemies with fighters on turn 1

-Really random at start: Every wonder have a few specified planets where it could be built, so you can get some nearly-useless wonders at your first planets on your first run, and the above-described combo on the next one. Some with missions, as some missions are easier than the others.

-No multiplayer
--------------------
Overall, i have enjoyed the game because i love turn-based strategies and because i simply ADORE upgrading stuff. Despite some serious drawbacks, it is still really enjoyable and i would give this game 7 points out of 10

reviewText:
After reading some of the other recent posts about this game I have edited my review:
This game is for casual gamers not for veterans of Galactic Civs or Sword of the Stars are anything remotely on that level. I am a little disappointed that some gamers compare epic games (that cost 60 USD) to this 15 dollar offshoot of Beyound Earth. If you are looking for a an hour to kill this could be for you. If you are looking for 3 hours to get lost in go Mod a copy of Sins of a Solar Empire: Rebellion.



One hour in and counting:

Pros:
15 USD excellent value
Starship customization
Graphics are solid
Munition animations
Good Voice Acting
Intelligent Diplomacy with aggressive AI
Planetary missions have a sense of urgency (if you wont help them a rival will and soon)
Lots of detail without being overwhelming
Very Fluid Gameplay (not nearly as micromanaging as some 5x space strategy)

Cons:
Surprising hardware requirements (Less stable than Endless Space)
Cannot Rename Planets or starships (There is a reason for this, planetary names are spoken aloud adding to voice acting quality)
Limited scope compared to space strategy genre

Overall: Excellent buy for 15 USD. Simple to enjoyable to those outside the genre. Detailed enough for regular strategy players. In summary: More than the sum of its parts

reviewText: Fun game but not very deep. If your looking for a Civ in space thats not this game. More a guilty pleasure game with great graphics and some stratedgy working the battle field. I am currently third in ranking as far as the percentage I need to win but all I need to do is attack the ones ahead of me to correct that. reviewText:
This game does not have as epic of a scope as the main CIV games do, but its still a very fun game to play.  Its very simple and it took only a couple turns into it before I could get all of the mechanics.  The game goes by quick, but if you like strategic combat, this game does pretty well.
Everytime you build a ship, you start with the same template, but the amount of customization you can put into it can lead you to some really interesting tactics in space battles.
If you were hoping for a 4x with a lot of empire managment, dont get this game.  The game revolves almost solely on space battles.  But if you love intense strategic turn-based combat, you will enjoy it.
The only real things I would change about the game is:
1) Allow fullscreen. (You can maximize the window, but that doesnt really count)
2) Subtract $5 from the price.

Despite these two things, its worth trying out if you dont mind spending $15 on it.  Just dont expect to be spending hours on it in one sitting.

reviewText:
Starships is simply brilliant.  The game is tightly focused on the tactical missions, which is the whole point. The strategic layer is intentionally light to keep most of the playtime in the battles, where it belongs.

The missions and ship configurations are varied enough to keep the game interesting through many iterations.

Starships is short.  A standard map game can be finished in a few hours, even a huge map game will take a tiny fraction of the time needed to play Civilization. Short is good. I love Civilization, but I can count one hand the number of games of Civ5 I've actually been able to finish in the last two years. And more often than not  Civilization ends with a grinding game of attrition or acumulation of culture points that is simply not that much fun. The strategic game in Starships does a good job of avoiding this kind of slog. The action in Starships builds steadily throughout the game until a satisfying climax in a decisive big fleet battle (at least in my games so far.)

There is no multiplayer. This is also a good thing. If you really want a multiplayer online TBS game with both a strategic/political level and a tactical battleboard, then IMHO you really, really have way to much time on your hands and need to get a life.

I strongly recommend Starships.

I do have two minor quibbles.
First, players cannot rename their ships (or I haven't yet figured out how.)
Second, the game could use an empire management screen/table to make it easier to find and develop your planets on the larger maps.

reviewText:
I have owened every Sid Meier game made.  I am a fan.  I am a Civilization Fan as well.   I am also a turn based fan in general.  That said I haven't been near the fan of Civ: BE as prior Civ games, and was a disappointed with it.  That said when I heard about Starships I was interested though I didn't jump on it like I would normally have done.  That said when GMG offered a great sale on the game for just over $10 prior to release I went ahead and figured what the heck and picked the game up.

First off I do believe that Starships was going to be an expansion or even part of Beyond Earth.  Does it feel like a AAA game?  No, but then again it is not selling at AAA prices.   Does the fact that it is tablet friendly make it less of a fun game? No I don't think so.   Is the game complex?  No, but it is fun for when you want to kick back and just have a relaxed turn based game.

I know that the game is getting mixed reviews, however I haven't seen any bugs in the game, and have enjoyed it for the small amount of time I have been playing it so far.  Is it ground breaking?  Not  in the least.  But for even the asking price I have hundreds of games that I paid double the price for and found far less entertaining.

The game isn't something I see myself playing every day.  To me it is going to be one of those games that I turn to when I am watching TV and have other distractions yet want something to do when I don't feel like forwarding through commericals.  That said if you like space games, and like Turn Based games, I personally feel the game is worth the money as is.

Here are my first impressions:

+The gameplay and everything concerning it that I've played thusfar (ship building, combat, quests, etc.) is spot-on and very enjoyable. Hard is hard as it should be so I've got some work ahead of me which pleases me (I was worried it'd be too easy.)

=I can read most of the font if I downsize my resolution or squint. That's very important but only to me.

-The user interface and options as a whole are downright terrible. If I hadn't been told in countless videos that this was developed for PC first, I would have thought it was an IPad game first. No fullscreen, no WASD panning, no edge-scrolling, no remappable keys, and I could go on and on. Also the turn ship" system is wonky.

As it sits RIGHT NOW
date: I rate the game a "good" out of "ADOM-levels of awesome!"\n\nIf the UI issues get fixed
recommended: this looks to be upgraded to a solid "great." If there are new features added (more quests
hoursPlayed: longer gameplay options
voteText: etc.) alongside the UI fixes
helpfulPercent: this game could go all the way to "Played Once A Day.""

reviewText:
For what it is, this is a decent little game. The combat has a surprising amount of nuance for the simplicity of the rules, and the visual effects, while being light enough for older systems, are nicely pretty.

The range of starting options also means that there's a lot of different approaches in the game, different starting conditions that you can control - as well as all the random variation that you can't control.

It's not a civ game, it's not MOO-like (or GalCiv-like, or SotS-like) - it's all about the adventure and tactical combat, with some light 4X-like elements to tie it all together.

And I'm having a lot of fun with it. There are some rough edges, like the lack of an 'exit game' control on the main menu, and no true-fullscreen (only fullscreen window, and that isn'r borderless), but then it's not a game to play for hours and hours on end, but 20-60 minutes here and there.

But I'm also going to have to go back to BE to get as much as I can out of it - some minor content elements are locked until you do something in BE to unlock them.

reviewText:
- No fullscreen
- No resolution settings
- Framerate capped at 30FPS yet it does run 60FPS in the menus.
- No tutorial
- Custom win conditions only valid for player
- Very lite on content
- Tooltips?

+ Looks ok
+ Nice artwork
+ Starships


You would be better off buying this on your tablet in it's current state but even then I can't recommend it.

UPDATE: Fullscreen Borderless does work when hiding the taskbar but only in default desktop mode. Classic will not be borderless.

Still not worth the price. Wait for a sale and grab it for at least 50% off. Not much to see here at all really. If only it had been a full blown Civilization Starships 4X starting off where Beyond Earth ends. You could pickup Endless Space for around the same price or even less and have a much bigger more complete epic tbs 4x instead of this tablet crap. The cross game connection is so lame I regret the changes by Firaxis as I have to look a a giant 2K button on the main menu of Beyond Earth.

So not impressed with Firaxis right now... I'm ashamed I actually pre-ordered this game. I thought it would be much much better even if it was lite on content. Last game I pre-order with Sids name on it. If you want to release shovelware so be it. I know he has some pull at Firaxis but come on this game is just not that good.

If you come to it expecting something on the scale of Beyond Earth, you'll be disappointed.\n\nWhat Starships IS, instead, is a fun, simple game. A few simple elements of management, and fun tactical battles. I've been enjoying it so far quite a bit, as it definitely has that one more turn" quality that Civilization games are infamous for."
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
It is a nice pocket strategy game more suited to a tablet than a PC but that is if you play the small maps. It is much simplier than we are used to from Firaxis however it does have a certain quality about it. That quality however is not in the UI or the graphics. They are clearly there for a tablet to run and that alone.

I have enjoyed the games I have played so far and while I wasn't expecting Masters of Orion or Galactic Civilizations I was sad to see the empire aspect so dumbed down. I had it on normal my first game and didn't even have to upgrade my planets. I just did it because I could. The wonders however are where it is at. Take the Reactive Armor wonder it makes you immune to torpedo damage, another great wonder is Hyperlaunch which allows your figthers to use their full movement after launch. These are where the planets really shine, it sadly it would be better if there was a multiplayer because then the usefulness of these planets would create natural battlegrounds.

That is if you had muliple fleets, but you don't, you get one, one that will ALWAYS be there to defend if you get attacked. Making flanking your enemies, or catching them out of position completely useless. You also don't actually destory your enemies fleet, they just get knocked for a time, as do yours.

Overall I enjoyed it for what it is, if I could do it again I would wait for a steam sale.

Oh one last thing, as you play this and Beyond Earth you unlock little perks in the other game. This is a nice little extra however I have no idea what I am unlocking for Beyond Earth as that game doesn't tell me what I have unlocked.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Just a smaller, more compact, less in depth version of Sins of A Solar Empire.

Starships is half the price, but less than half the value.
If your looking for a quick sunday afternoon galaxy takeover, then its ok, if your looking for in depth, tech tree, fleet fueled combat, then get Sins. In this you only have one fleet, and rescources are gathered fom the planets you take over and develop. Combat is ok, but everything in this game is very 'lite'.

The lack of a tutorial is not as bad as it seems, as its not that dfficult to get the hang of, but things could definitly be better explained. There is a help area, but this realy feels like one of those websites where you go to the 'contact us' page and they keep throwing FAQs infront of you before they will give you a number.

There are also some decent bugs i.e. when you set a skirmish game to the winning condition of 'domination' (which you would think is enemy wipeout), but the enemy can win by building wonders.. despite there also being a 'wonder' mode.

Sins is a complete game, bugs have been solved, its tried and true and has in depth gameplay.
Get that and forget this exists.

reviewText: Starships is legit, old school Sid Meier.  He programmed the game, did it his way, and it feels like Civ 1 with X-Com style combat (using asteroids as cover).  I've only played it on easy, and it is as easy as a game of Civ on Settler difficulty.\n\n$15?  I wouldn't pay that for this game (sorry Sid).  It's solo player and seems to have relatively little to do for a video game.  I recommend trying out a demo if you can, or watching gameplay on YouTube, but get it at a discount; don't spend more than $6 on it.  I was fortunate to get it bundled with Beyond Earth for $27, when Beyond Earth was on sale for $25, so it's like I spent $2 on this game and it was worth it.

reviewText: I dig it, but of course, I bought it in a Beyond Earth/Starships bundle when both were also being offered on a Steam sale, so I paid $27 for both titles total.  Since BE runs $25 during a normal Steam sale, I ended up paying $2 for Starships - for $2, this game is AMAZING.  It's light...nothing at all like Civ or BE.\n\nTo me, to give a perspective/description to what the game feels like or what you should expect, you have to start with a baseline - for me, that's Civ 5 with all the DLCs/expansion packs.  If you start there, Civ 5 gives you tons of options and playstyles...then you simplify when you move to BE where you have a fairly young game with fewer options that still feels more or less like Civ 5 without any of the major DLC packs...then you move to something like Pandora: First Contact" - a Civ-style 4x game that almost completely focuses on battles

reviewText: If you are looking for a casual turn base game that has a lot of replay value, this is a great game for you!  I played Civ 5 and a few other Sid Meier's games. This game has a lot of the one more turn" addiction as most of the other titles’.  With random maps that can be played each turn. New changing conditions and many ways to win each map. I would recommend this game to anyone that has played or like other Sid Meier's games
date:
if you would like a fast game with hours of replay.

A few things to keep in mind with this game are that it was made for the I pad. With that in mind there are many this in the game that don’t seem full realized to their fullest potential. There are clearly areas that need improvements for the PC but the limits imposed by the I pad put many improvements too far out of reach.  The price is right for this game. A real good buy!!

reviewText: This is a mobile game being masqueraded as a PC game. It's extremely simplified and lacks any real depth. The games only options are by increasing the ticks in your weapons and by adding more ships. The planets have ticks as well that give more resources and a unique ability. Combat is grid-based, with asteroids offering cover an unknown amount of cover, you won't know until you fire on an enemy - visual clues are limited to greater or lesser. I'd expect this to be a game for no more than a dollar or two with banner adds. The price point doesn't match the game play.\n\nOnce upon a time if a game supported the Sid Meier's" prefix I would preorder it in a heartbeat (and that was one of the few auto preorders for me)
date: but lately Firaxis has been releasing games that don't have anything new or substantial in the games they develop. This was the game that stopped that for me
recommended: friends have been telling me I shouldn't preorder games anyway - this is the proof in that pudding."

reviewText:
A fan of Master of Orion 2, well this is more or less Master of Orion 2 Lite.

Is it good? Not really, Is it bad? Not really.

In short it is entertaining enough for the money it costs.

The reason i call it Lite, is because of the simple set up of ships, technology and building cities on planets.
I would rather play Master of Orion 2 again if it was possible, or Stardrive.

Why I recommend it? Well it is entertainment value is higher than the price which is the only criteria I follow if I recommend a game, but I have to be honest there are a truck load of other games you could spend money on that would be far more entertaining than this.

reviewText: I was skeptical about this title based on some of the negative reviews, but really wanted to check out a new space game.\n\nMy short take would be : it's basically a boardgame. It's fun, easy to learn, relatively short to play, has multiple win conditions, and the graphics are nice to watch. Being turn based makes it pleasantly casual and easy(ish) to come back to over a few play sessions.

reviewText: While sharing story elements with Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth, this is *NOT* an empire builder game. I would call it a turn based tactical/strategy game. It's a good game, although several things about it just don't make sense. First, you only have 1 fleet of ships. Second, every planet's combat environment is filled with asteroids. Third, lasers and cannons are graphically homing missiles, not lasers and cannons.\n\nThe flaws don't really matter though, it is a good game. And even though it was obviously designed for tablets, that doesn't hold it back on the PC.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a civilizations game in space, this isn't it. You might enjoy Galactic Civilizations if that is what you're looking for. This game is based in the same universe as Sid Meier's Civilizations but the mechanics are much simpler.

Story:
It's based upon a future almost immediately proceeding Civilizations: Beyond Earth. You are just beginning to foray into the galaxy with the ability to travel faster than light, thus enabling interstellar commerce. Your goal is to win via military might, cultural or diplomatic prowess, economic finesse, population sustainance, or scientific transcendence.

Mechanics:
Basically you build up a fleet of ships and upgrade them to fill roles you want them to fill. You then use this fleet to win the loyalty of other planets in the galaxy. It's turned based, so once your fleet has exhausted it's resources you will pass the turn to the other players or AI's. The combat is very reminiscent of civilization, but more tactical. It throws in objectives and obstacles and environment hazards. Your ships will have certain abilities based on the upgrades you outfit them with. They can range from Carriers, Battleships, Destroyers, or Corvettes. You start with a corvette, then outfit it with heavier weapons, better sensors, faster engines, stealth, or fighter bays.

When you have influence on a planet, they contribute resources to your pool and you may build improvements on them, such as increased metal production, or science, energy, or even building a wonder to boost your fleet.

Conclusion:
It's a fun game! Not quite as in depth as Civ 5 or BE, but Sid Meier did well with providing us a new game for the universe. I recommend it.

reviewText:
Oh, Sid Meier, why did you put your name on this game?  Seriously, why?

This game is a mix of Spore Galaxy and dodge the asteroids.

You control a single fleet of spaceships going from star system to another, and then when a battle happens you are dodging asteroids.  And fire a torpedo... which can amazingly dodge the asteroids, but couldn't track on to any enemy ships.  Seriously?

And for a space game, every world is already colonized.  Really?  You can't send a colony ship?

And what's up with the technology tree?

And every world only has one planet to it.

I could go on, but the bottom line is that this is a terrible game.  Very dissapointing.

reviewText:
As a big fan of the Civilization series I had high expectations for Starships & hoped it would emulate the same fundamental style of gameplay as other games in the franchise. Sadly the finished product feels like a rushed attempt at trying to create something that could have been great but falls short in so many way and ultimately feels like a Civilization: Beyond Earth mini-game.

The game revolves around conquering planets with a single fleet of starships & engaging in repetitive battles that feature an uninspiring AI that can be easily defeated once you (quickly) discover a simple formulae for defeating opponents (You can quite easily hide your ships in cover and cripple the enemy with waves of torpedoes & fighters).

I don’t explicitly dislike Starships, however, there is very little replay value and almost no scope for variety in terms of how you play the game, due to the almost identical factions and simplistic victory conditions (I’ve found myself winning a population victory by accident on several occasions).

Although the game isn’t anywhere near as engaging as I hoped, it does have good touch support and is a pleasant enough game to play on a tablet when on the move or sitting in bed. As much as I hate taking the price into consideration, as I would have much rather paid three times as much for a far deeper experience, I do think that it’s a decent enough arcade game for killing time in short bursts.

In summary I’m going to (only just) recommend Starships based purely on the fact that it’s a cheap and cheerful game to pass an hour or so here-and-there, just don’t expect the same engaging experience that you might expect from other games in the franchise.

reviewText:
First lets just put this out there, this game lacks a lot of depth you might expect for this type of game.  It also makes itself perfectly clear in that it was developed for a tablet, be that an ipad or a windows tablet it matters little.  The only reason this is on steam is because there are windows tablets out there.  Making this painfully obvious is the lack of any graphics settings at all other than windowed or windowed full screen.  Clearly this game is aiming at the lowest common denominator and calling that good enough.  Don't get me wrong the graphics in this game look fine over all, but if they were really making this for a regular pc there would be at least a option to change the resolution and play at full screen.

What also stands out is the size of the maps.  Mind you I have just played an 'epic' sized map and cannot comment on any smaller size maps, but if I were to put a label on the size of this 'epic' map I would maybe put it at medium in a range of tiny small medium large epic.

One interesting change from normal 4x games is that all upgrades, ships, wonders, or really anything you have to buy is all made instantly.  No having to wait for several turns for tech to research or a new city to build.  The only nod in that direction is the amount of turns it takes to gain control of a 'system'.  Which even that can be bypassed biased upon the level of difficulty rating of the mission at the planet.

The fights were somewhat interesting in how they were done on the grid like final fantasy tactics.  The only real issue I had here was the computer gives you a rating on what it 'thinks' is your chance of winning.  This possibly is correct on your first few battles, but after that its totally useless.  I had fights that it was telling me I had a 25% chance of winning where I totally steamrolled the enemy, or never even encountered the enemy because of random placement on the map and the mission type.

Overall the game matched up well with what I would think of as a mobile game, but there is a lot left lacking for a game that would be designed for the pc.  Note however, that does not make this a bad game even on the pc, as there have been much worse ones made.

My biggest complaint with the game comes down to its cost.  This is not a game worth 15 bucks, not even on mobile.  I would expect a bit more work, and replay ability for that.  Knock 10 bucks off however, and this game would probably be in a pretty good place cost wise for both pc and mobile.

I would say I'm fairly neutral on the game itself, its neither good nor bad, however it is outside of its price point should be by quite a bit for what it offers.

reviewText:
It could really use multiplayer (with some serious balance work) and continue after victory. Overall I'm pretty pleased, I think it fills it's niche very well. Most of the critics seem to expect a full AAA $60 game experience for $15 and that just isn't fair. I think this game would be better thought of, and later expanded upon, the way so many great tabletop games have a core module with a ton of add ons. Catan does it, Dominion does it, Arkham does it, Warhammer sure as ♥♥♥♥ does the hell out of it.

If possible, a little more depth and diversity would be nice, but I'd be perfectly happy with this becoming a platform for DLC or open it up for modders on the PC. Adding an endgame alien invasion mechanic would be awesome; you've united the galaxy under your banner, now lead it! Or add a ground combat miniscenario in a DLC pack. Rig one of your capital ships as a troop carrying drop ship they way you currently can have a fighter centered carrier. Maybe they can launch boarding parties to capture vessels? Bringing in something like the crew specialists from Pirates! is something I think would be really cool, too.

I'm sure almost all of this is just wishful thinking, but I think it is a testament to a really great game that it inspires all kinds of ways it could (realistically) expand and be even better.

reviewText: Starships is legit, old school Sid Meier.  He programmed the game, did it his way, and it feels like Civ 1 with X-Com style combat (using asteroids as cover).  I've only played it on easy, and it is as easy as a game of Civ on Settler difficulty.\n\n$15?  I wouldn't pay that for this game (sorry Sid).  It's solo player and seems to have relatively little to do for a video game.  I recommend trying out a demo if you can, or watching gameplay on YouTube, but get it at a discount; don't spend more than $6 on it.  I was fortunate to get it bundled with Beyond Earth for $27, when Beyond Earth was on sale for $25, so it's like I spent $2 on this game and it was worth it.

reviewText: Nice little strategy game. Its set in space. Theres a load of planets that you can capture and develop (like Civ cities) . There are other races trying to capture those planets before you, and you can ally with them or attack them. Fleet battles are simple, reasonably quick,  hex baseed wargames. Some planets have 'wonders' . And you have a fleet (that you can also upgrade) to fly around exploring and capturing. So far so good. Only issue I have is that you only get one fleet - so its a bit like playing Civ with just one army (and the bigger the map you set the sillier it gets). An update  that allows multiple fleets (plus an option to 'auto fight' fleet battles.) could make this good game great. Certainly doesn't deserve all the bad reviews its getting.

Blah. Just blah.
If this were an IOS game I wouldn't say its pretty good. Because you never really exact a whole lot from IOS, right?

this game is a rushed, under polished, money grab that will more then likely never see attantion from the developer now that its been released.

reviewText:
This game may be of the Civilization heritage however it sorely lacks much of the polish and depth that its predecessors have.

The game is very easy to pick up and get playing and doesn't have much of a learning curve. The visuals of the game are ok but that is not why people play strategy games. Customising your ships is easy and can lend it self to creating different specilisations of your ships.

This game is lacking in depth for a real strategy fan. The battle system is similar to XCOM (turn based) however there now real sense of cover. You can use asteroids to bottleneck your opponent into a sort of kill box but then you might end up being shot through the asteroids anyway. The random environment effects that disable certain features of the ships can be annoying but do not really factor into any kind of strategy.

Lack of information when mousing over various aspects of the game is very annoying. You have no way of knowing what exactly is happening when you are spending energy upgrading your ships. What does upgrading fighters do? Make them stronger? More fighters? There is no way to tell easily unless you commit to it. Upgrading fighters just gives more fighters to that can be deployed by your starship.

The world map portion of the game is another feature lacking any real depth. You can control planets for more resources and wonders but that is all they are good for, you can specialise them for more of a certain resource but that is it.

The map sizes are very tiny and are meant for quick games nothing long and drawn out like the Civ games. I was hoping for a massive epic length battle like in civ but sadly, that is not the case.

Victory condition restrictions only apply to the player. If you wanted a massive conquest style game that allows you to get your starships to the end game you will not see it. The AI can easily win with a wonder victory or science before you have any real chance to see the full glory of your starships. Would really love those victory conditions to be applied to the AI as well.

I cannot recommend this game to any strategy or civ fan.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Anyone who was thinking of buying this game: wait until at least May 2015.  Hopefully by then the major bugs will have been fixed.  And don't buy it for over $10.

It runs for me, but apparently not for many.  One bug I did run into was achievements not unlocking when they should.  (Granted, I fulfilled the requirements for a couple by conquest, when apparently normaly building was the intended way.  But still, these things should be checked for.)

It's generic science fiction that tries to be 4x, but really is all about your single steadily growing fleet rolling over the galaxy.  Upgrading your planets is almost inconsequential compared to upgrading your fleet.  Energy constraints heavily favor optimizing for just one form of attack; in particular, lasers 4+ and 0 cannons, torpedoes, et cetera mean you can destroy most targets from a long distance, often times even through asteroids.  (Just make sure you are strong enough before attacking homeworlds: the defense ships that any homeworld starts with will maul a starting fleet, but they don't upgrade over time.)

As of this writing, the non-military victory conditions are only feasible if you disable the military victory conditions.  (The UI lets you enable all victory conditions, or only one specific condition, with no option to, say, only disable Population.)  Otherwise, someone's probably going to win a Population victory first.  Even the Domination victory is usually preceeded by a Population victory, unless someone (probably you) launches an early attack on the other empires, to score a Domination victory before enough of the galaxy has been claimed that reducing the galaxy to 2 empires (a necessary prelude to reducing it to 1 for Domination) triggers a Population victory.

I do not recommend this game at this time, but if you are reading months or years later - after the bugs have been fixed - and you can get it for under $10, it might be a cheap diversion for a weekend or two.

reviewText: This is the kind of game that could astound on a tablet, yet falls a little flat on any desktop.  It's quick to learn, simple to jump into, and the gameplay is simple.  Combat is pretty straight forward with the emphasis on menuevering and flanking other vessels and landing a more powerful shot.  Even though the combat is simple, the developers did a good job at making it still engaging.\n\nThis game would be fun on a tablet.  It is not, however, worth the full price.  Wait until it is drastically reduced with a sale, or added as a savings bundle with another Sid Meier's game.  This one has none of the depth that is normally attached to the Sid Meier name.

reviewText: Fantastic little Game. Well worth the price tag. Although it has got a lot of negative reviews, I think those reviews were from people who were expecting it to be Civ with starships. It isn't at all. In Civ a game may take 10+ hours depending on what settings it is on, and it takes a lot of thought and tactics. A game on Starships takes around 2 hours, and it's a lot more easy going. It does still require thought though, enough so to keep you engaged with the game. It's a great game with what looks like a lot of replayability. Its perfect for that half hour before going out or that 1 hour in the day that you have spare. Would thoroughly recommend.

reviewText: While the game is quite obviously a port from a tablet (evidenced, in part, by the fact there's no quit button, oddly enough), it's entertaining. While not nearly as good as most other Sid Meier's games (I beat it in a couple hours, while multitasking), nor as in depth (you really don't get much in the way of build options, not creativity), it's not a bad little game. Could do with a LOT of polish (and maybe some swiss- I mean, upgrades and additions), but, like I said, not terrible. Would recommend, however, picking it up when it's on sale rather than the base price.

reviewText:
Bottom-line up front: I'd give this a solid 1.5 out of 10. This is an expensive version of a free Facebook game... read more to find out why.

I REALLY wanted to like this game. From the pre-order description, and the fact that Sid Meier does an amazing job with about 95% of the games that they produce, this had a ton of potential.

Branded as a 4x game that related to Beyond Earth, I was a bit hopeful to see something that played like Master of Orion 2 and had the space-ground gameplay of Star Commander. Alas, I got my hopes up too high.

Also, before you go too much farther with this, just know that I haven't read the other reviews. This is my own take on this game.

Everything from the tech, to the resources, (lack of) diplomacy, (generic) space combat, and AI feels flat.

TECH: The tech tree" is just a menu of upgrade. There are no new capabilities to introduce and no real choices that force you to examine tradeoffs and benefits. After playing BE
date: you'll likely be especially let down because NONE of that innovation exists in this game.\n\nRESOURCES: Four resources
recommended: and four very narrow things to do with them. Like most campy Facebook games
hoursPlayed: using your resources requires no more thought than a button click.\n\nDIPLOMACY: My main complaint with most Civ games is that you have options that the AI will not accept... in this case
voteText: you don't even have those options. Your two basic negotiating stances are a) war
helpfulPercent: or b) peace. Given the combat
votesHelpful: neither has any particular advantages.\n\nCOMBAT: This is probably the only (slightly) redeeming part of this game. For about the first 20 turns
votesTotal: the combat and the missions are challenging. Once you've pumped enough resources into your ships
votesFunny: you can pretty well steamroll the AI with impunity.\nOh yes
commentsCount: the ship customization (and the reason why I was excited about this game)... yawn. Again
column16: like the tech tree
column17: the characteristics of each of your ships can be leveled up to attain greater advantage. There is no researching of new ship hulls
column18: engines
column19: weapons
column20: or shields; just leveling. Facebook flash games have more options than this... such as Battle Pirates.\nFinal thing that I'll say on combat is this: one fleet? If SM was trying a new twist on 4x games to limit player to one fleet and up the challenge
column21: this was a terrible choice. Any potential challenge is wasted because they let you construct warp gates so that you do not use up movement points while moving between your own worlds.\n\nAI: Now for the AI. Like the rest of the game
column22: the AI is stale and offers no challenge. In three different play throughs of the game (each at increasing difficulty)
column23:
I have as yet to have an AI player declare war on me or attack me. I can roam the galaxy with my large armada of heavily armed ships and tear through pretty much every other empire with little effort.

What could have been a stellar game (see what I did there?) is really just a black hole for your wallet (even at $13 - as of this writing).

Save your money. Save your time. Don't save this galaxy (or SM's bottom line)."

reviewText:
Oh, Sid Meier, why did you put your name on this game?  Seriously, why?

This game is a mix of Spore Galaxy and dodge the asteroids.

You control a single fleet of spaceships going from star system to another, and then when a battle happens you are dodging asteroids.  And fire a torpedo... which can amazingly dodge the asteroids, but couldn't track on to any enemy ships.  Seriously?

And for a space game, every world is already colonized.  Really?  You can't send a colony ship?

And what's up with the technology tree?

And every world only has one planet to it.

I could go on, but the bottom line is that this is a terrible game.  Very dissapointing.

City building, planet improvement and research are just linear purchasable upgrades and you only get one fleet with which to explore and complete missions.

The rounds are short and there  are some bugs and issues but for the price it's quite an enjoyable short civ like experience.

Why I recommend it? Well it is entertainment value is higher than the price which is the only criteria I follow if I recommend a game, but I have to be honest there are a truck load of other games you could spend money on that would be far more entertaining than this.

reviewText: A fun little game, but seems to be stuck between Civ in space and a turn based wargame. Personally I'd like to see this fleshed out into a full on turn based combat game rather than the small scale mish-mash it is at the moment.\n\nFun to play with a nice mix of units and tactics available, though sometimes let down by dodgy AI. Looks nice, doesn't over-complicate things, a good way to spend the odd half hour.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Disappointing. I expected it to be a 'lite' Civ game, but even as such it is woefully inadequate. Even largest sized galaxy is tiny, you only get 1 fleet to move around, quests disappear only after a few turns once all the systems are explored, and what remains is a tedious mopup operation where you fight the exact same battle from system to system. This game does absolutely nothing to address the age old problem of steamrolling the enemy once you become powerful enough (or get steamrolled by), which means every map ends up playing the exact same way. Sieze a good chunk of territory, make peace with everyone, declare war on the weakest and conquer them, and repeat.\n\nIn the end, Starships is nothing more than a tech demo or proof of concept with the actual gameplay almost nonexistant.

reviewText: I enjoy a number of games and this one is somewhat like Master of Orion but just when you start getting into it, the rug is pulled out and the game is over.\n\nThe game mechanics are a good base for a game.  However, the game is restrictive in the victory types and gets old quickly.  The replayability is low and the game can be lost with any of the win methods though all battles are won.  The difference between the map size is close to null.  There is no victory by conquest option.   I've been able to max out science and fleet on domination win method but eventually the enemy won though they only controld 1 planet.  I wish this game was still under dev. and in beta.  It isn't.  There is no multiplayer network or hotseat so playing with friends is out.  Maybe $1 to .50  per hour of gameplay.  Value to time is low.  At a few bucks it would be a worthwile value but the current price is too high for this unfinished game.

reviewText:
I have played every single Sid Meier's game that has been released to date and this is by far the most dissappointing of them all.

Resolution isn't correct on Windows, there is a gap at the bottom of the screen, and you can only play in full-screen. If you switch to windowed mode it goes to 4:3 aspect ratio. This cannot be changed.

There is no difference in gameplay between leaders.
There is no difference in gameplay between affinities.

Map size does not change tactical gameplay - it only increases the amount of time it takes to overrun everything.

I was able to complete 40% of the achievements within an hour of playing.

By far the most simple and horrible game I have played from Firaxis games to date. I think this was made for children on tablets.
