reviewText:
Bottom-line up front: I'd give this a solid 1.5 out of 10. This is an expensive version of a free Facebook game... read more to find out why.

I REALLY wanted to like this game. From the pre-order description, and the fact that Sid Meier does an amazing job with about 95% of the games that they produce, this had a ton of potential.

Branded as a 4x game that related to Beyond Earth, I was a bit hopeful to see something that played like Master of Orion 2 and had the space-ground gameplay of Star Commander. Alas, I got my hopes up too high.

Also, before you go too much farther with this, just know that I haven't read the other reviews. This is my own take on this game.

Everything from the tech, to the resources, (lack of) diplomacy, (generic) space combat, and AI feels flat.

TECH: The tech tree" is just a menu of upgrade. There are no new capabilities to introduce and no real choices that force you to examine tradeoffs and benefits. After playing BE
date: you'll likely be especially let down because NONE of that innovation exists in this game.\n\nRESOURCES: Four resources
recommended: and four very narrow things to do with them. Like most campy Facebook games
hoursPlayed: using your resources requires no more thought than a button click.\n\nDIPLOMACY: My main complaint with most Civ games is that you have options that the AI will not accept... in this case
voteText: you don't even have those options. Your two basic negotiating stances are a) war
helpfulPercent: or b) peace. Given the combat
votesHelpful: neither has any particular advantages.\n\nCOMBAT: This is probably the only (slightly) redeeming part of this game. For about the first 20 turns
votesTotal: the combat and the missions are challenging. Once you've pumped enough resources into your ships
votesFunny: you can pretty well steamroll the AI with impunity.\nOh yes
commentsCount: the ship customization (and the reason why I was excited about this game)... yawn. Again
column16: like the tech tree
column17: the characteristics of each of your ships can be leveled up to attain greater advantage. There is no researching of new ship hulls
column18: engines
column19: weapons
column20: or shields; just leveling. Facebook flash games have more options than this... such as Battle Pirates.\nFinal thing that I'll say on combat is this: one fleet? If SM was trying a new twist on 4x games to limit player to one fleet and up the challenge
column21: this was a terrible choice. Any potential challenge is wasted because they let you construct warp gates so that you do not use up movement points while moving between your own worlds.\n\nAI: Now for the AI. Like the rest of the game
column22: the AI is stale and offers no challenge. In three different play throughs of the game (each at increasing difficulty)
column23:
I have as yet to have an AI player declare war on me or attack me. I can roam the galaxy with my large armada of heavily armed ships and tear through pretty much every other empire with little effort.

What could have been a stellar game (see what I did there?) is really just a black hole for your wallet (even at $13 - as of this writing).

Save your money. Save your time. Don't save this galaxy (or SM's bottom line)."

reviewText: While sharing story elements with Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth, this is *NOT* an empire builder game. I would call it a turn based tactical/strategy game. It's a good game, although several things about it just don't make sense. First, you only have 1 fleet of ships. Second, every planet's combat environment is filled with asteroids. Third, lasers and cannons are graphically homing missiles, not lasers and cannons.\n\nThe flaws don't really matter though, it is a good game. And even though it was obviously designed for tablets, that doesn't hold it back on the PC.

reviewText:
This is a tough one.. really wanted to like the game, but it's got some issues.

After playing thru a few games, the biggest problem in my opinion: Regardless of what you select as a victory condition, it apparently does not apply to the AI.  So, the game is going to be a race to get to 7 wonders nearly every time.  You can set the game up to the largest, most epic map that settings will allow,.. and if you don't rush and build 7 wonders, one of the AI will.  This causes the game to be over far too quickly.

Some other issues:

Lack of customization/variety in your available ships.  You have one type of ship available, and you can alter the appearance a bit based on the loadout you select,.. but they all still look basically the same.

Some of the Wonders are a bit over the top.  Stealth torpedos, permenant stealth ships, and a wonder that gives you two actions instead of one,.....battle over.

I don't regret buying this game for the price,.. but it falls painfully short in my opinion.  The game seems over simplified.  Not sure if this was because they wanted to pander to the tablet crowd, but I'm not looking to buy a tablet game to play on my PC.

Maybe if there are future updates/addons that add more to the game I will adjust my review,... but for now, the game comes up way short for what I expect from a Sid Meier game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Starships is a fun game where you play as the admiral of a small fleet. It simplifies the technology and resource managing aspect so that the player may focus on their fleet and the missions that they go on. If you are expecting a 4x game then you will be disappointed because this game was not designed around resources but around space tactical combat and does a good job with it. In the galaxy you do get some resource management but all of those including the techs are strictly focused around building and maintaining the fleet. Then there are the missions the player sends their fleet on, they play out like a good game of chess involving a few varied sets of moves and abilities for each ship. With the longer games taking around 2-3 hours this is far more casual then the Civilization franchise it spawned from which makes it easy to pick up and play on a random day as opposed to a civilization game which takes a little bit of commitment to get through.\nNow for the ugly. The game does have some balancing issues at the moment of release but nothing game shattering. The only 2 victories that you ever go for are population and wonder victories as science victory takes forever to get and when you go for a domination victory you will inevitably conquer over half the galaxy (population victory) before you wipe out the last player. There is also a very sad lack of multiplayer which could have done very well especially if Firaxis set up a single mission game (kind of like what they did with X-Com Enemy Unknown). I am hoping they eventually give us a multiplayer because that would drastically increase the value of the game but even without multiplayer this is a fun game and for $15 ($10 if you wait for a sale) it is not a bad buy.

reviewText:
I would not recommend this game. As a standlone INDIE tactical space strategy it might have worked, if not all the bugs. But as a continuation of the Sid Meier's title line it doesnt. There is prectically no tie-in with BE, as was promised, the affinities are meaningless and provide very little diversity, there are no unique fleet options and even the leader choice offers extremely little variety. The UI offers too much basic info and very little in depth data where it is needed. Victory conditions are modelled in a very weird way, I ended up getting the Wonder victory by accident many a time when trying other options.
It is not worth the asking price, which clearly is based on the Sid Meier's" being a part of the title.

Also bugs. Many bugs."

reviewText: Nice little strategy game. Its set in space. Theres a load of planets that you can capture and develop (like Civ cities) . There are other races trying to capture those planets before you, and you can ally with them or attack them. Fleet battles are simple, reasonably quick,  hex baseed wargames. Some planets have 'wonders' . And you have a fleet (that you can also upgrade) to fly around exploring and capturing. So far so good. Only issue I have is that you only get one fleet - so its a bit like playing Civ with just one army (and the bigger the map you set the sillier it gets). An update  that allows multiple fleets (plus an option to 'auto fight' fleet battles.) could make this good game great. Certainly doesn't deserve all the bad reviews its getting.
